author: {'steamid': '76561199103864568', 'num_games_owned': 41, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1708711979}
review:
this game is going into my suicide note 



so good though, the mechanics are complex and interesting but can get very challenging and its not often rhythm games have interesting/unique stories, if any at all.         also its way too good to be so cheap ! 
fyi dont pick the harder game levels youll lose your sanity

author: {'steamid': '76561198034547196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1709519085}
review:
This game is hugely nostalgic for me - I played it back when it was called "Sequence" and it was on the Xbox 360's XBLA service. It's a really creative concept, though in execution the progression can feel pretty padded with reliance on grinding RNG items by playing the same songs over and over again.

Absolutely worth a play if you're looking for an original take on a rhythm game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039078367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1705959799}
review: Decided to try and play the game after years of not touching it, will not start and unable to find a fix for it.  Cannot recommend due to the lack of support and no real fixes (as the only fix I could find does not work anymore).  Is a real shame because I remember having fun playing it for the short time I was able to in the past.  Will update review if this issue ever gets fixed though it seems it is almost abandonware in the eyes of the dev.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130764776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 552, 'last_played': 1703984387}
review: I am having way too much fun with this game! It's not really a one-session thing, so I get to enjoy it in little pieces of an hour or two each. It's a very interesting combat system and great music! If you love music, arrows, cute monsters and some tactical magic, this definetly is for you! It can be a lil  bit grindy at times, but not too much!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045518920', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1702810455}
review: Before the Echo combines rhythm and strategy in a way that is extremely clever and novel. On the whole I found the game to be very well-balanced and the progression is satisfying. Sadly the story and writing is a little lacklustre, and some floors can become a real grind due to the low drop rates. Nonetheless, I had a blast playing this, and for ¬£3.99 it's an absolute steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998543056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 623, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1327219200}
review:
[b] > Be me
> Hear about this game, "Before the Echo" (formerly Sequence)
> Think, "RPG-Rhythm game hybrid? Is it like Final Fantasy meets DDR?"
> Decide to give it a whirl
> Start the game as Ky, drugged and left for dead in a tower
> Tower's like, "Surprise, you're stuck here!"
> Only escape is to follow the voice on the intercom
> She could be the tower's evil mastermind, but what choice do I have?
> Get jumped by a monster
> It's like my first day at Monster-Fighting School, and I didn't study for the pop quiz
> No idea how to fight
> But then Naia, the savior, pulls me out of the battle with a spell
> She's like, "I gotchu, fam!"
> Learns how to fight
> She's basically my Gandalf with a better hairdo
> She sends me on a quest to the top of the tower
> It's either that or become Monster Chow
> Challenge accepted!
> "Before the Echo" is more unique than a unicorn riding a rainbow
> It's like an RPG on a wild rhythm rollercoaster
> Battle is all about rhythm and strategy
> Take control of three beat fields for spells, mana, and enemy damage
> Gotta swap between them faster than greased lightning
> To cast spells, I need mana
> Patterns of arrows fall when I cast spells
> I gotta hit 'em all for the spell to work
> Spells can do all sorts of cool stuff
> Damage enemies, heal me, boost my next spell, or shield me
> The more effective the spell, the crazier the arrow patterns
> Fail to hit the arrows, and I'm out of mana
> Need mana? Head to the mana field
> Arrows drop, I groove to the rhythm, and mana fills up
> Missing arrows here doesn't hurt me
> But gotta keep an eye on the defense field
> Arrows here represent enemy attacks
> If they hit, I lose HP
> Gray arrows hurt less, red arrows hurt more
> Now I'm in a dance-off with abominations
> Gotta switch between fields like a DJ with a turntable addiction
> Defense field to stay alive, mana field to build up magic
> Spell field to unleash that magic on my foes
> Defeat enemies, grab their loot, improve my gear
> Repeat until I'm ready to face the boss
> Game was originally called Sequence, but they changed it to Before the Echo
> Some legal nonsense with a board game publisher
> Whatever, the game is lit
> It's a unique and rhythm-tastic RPG experience
> I'm addicted, and I can't stop dancing and casting spells
> 10/10 would rhythm-battle again! üéÆüéµüòÇüëæ [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041708165', 'num_games_owned': 1099, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1682955273}
review:
I played a little bit of Before the Echo years ago and enjoyed it, so I thought I'd come back and give it another try. As others have said, it's kind of like DDR/Guitar Hero but with some RPG elements. You're battling through enemies in this tower to try and get materials to craft items (including the key to proceed to the next floor each time). At the end of every floor you unlock the door and face a boss before moving on. 

Battles are almost like playing 3 mini DDR games at once, because you have 3 screens you need to rotate between:
[list]
[*]Defensive (hitting notes prevents damage from enemy)
[*]Spell (you cast spells to do damage, have to hit all of the notes or it fails) 
[*]Mana (to regain mana for more spells). 
[/list]

Successfully winning battles requires you to triage what notes on what screens are most important to hit, and balance going on the offensive with maintaining your mana levels and not taking too much damage. It's a neat little system that I haven't seen in any other game before or since. 

Unfortunately, there are way too many sources of irritation in this game for me to want to continue playing or to recommend to anyone. The TL;DR of it is that there aren't enough songs, the game is too grindy, and the writing is incredibly cringey. For more details, read on:

[list]
[*] There seem to be about three enemies per floor. Each enemy has a song associated with it that you'll be battling them on. Each enemy also has 3 drops of differing rarity levels that you will want/need to collect to craft things like the key, new items, new spells, etc. In order to get everything, you'll have to battle enemies multiple times and thus repeat the same song multiple times - particularly if you aren't getting the drop you need.
[*] It's extremely uninteresting to fight the same enemy a bunch of times, particularly if you are able to defeat them relatively quickly and are just hearing the beginning of the same song over and over again
[*] I got to the second floor and the one enemy is using the same song as the boss I just fought, which isn't too bad because I had only heard it once so far. But the other 2/3 enemies have recycled songs from the first floor that I probably already heard like 10 times each. That was a big disappointment.
[*] To craft items, you need to get the requisite materials and spend exp. The amount of exp you spend increases the success rate, up to a maximum of 95%. Thankfully you don't lose the materials if it fails, but you do lose the exp you spent, further contributing to the grind.
[*] It sucks that at the start of battles all of your spells have to finish charging up (they have a cooldown at the start of battle and between uses). You're often not even really having to defend much in this time, so it's just dead time where you can't really do anything.
[*] I think I would've preferred it if the spell system was slightly more forgiving/rewarding than it is. After you start a spell you either successfully clear all the notes and cast the spell or you don't. I wish there were more nuance to it where maybe you could crit or have a chance of some special effect for getting it perfect but that if you missed 1 note it didn't necessarily fail the entire thing, because then you're just on cooldown. Especially early on in the game you just might not have that many other offensive options so you're just sitting around waiting again. 
[*] The game tries way too hard to be funny but just makes me cringe. I'm not against vulgarity for the sake of humor but it just goes way over the top constantly in a way that's incredibly unfunny. One of the first things said is that your character's head is pounding like you were stabbed by a hobo. Shortly after there's a joke about date rape. Believe me, it just goes on and on. 
[*] The story is not that interesting from what I saw of it. 
[/list]

review: A fun little rhythm adventure / RPG game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005656643', 'num_games_owned': 1310, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 1426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1426, 'last_played': 1596211351}
review: Understanding that the game isn't maintained and some users are having issues running it, the review is focused on the gameplay, and what awesome gameplay. In a weird way, reminds me to TWEWY, where you need to balance playing multiple games at once. You are looking at the enemy, responding and predicting their attacks, while casting your own, all while running through DDR patterns to successfully attack and defend. Story is serviceable, but that's not really the point. One of my favorite rhythm games, and fused the genres is a way nobody had before. Hoping we get further expansion on this idea in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046773252', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 975, 'last_played': 1674032026}
review: I like rhythm games, despite not being good at them, and RPG is one of my favorite genres so of course I had to try this. It took me maybe 10 years to do it but still, it was a pleasant surprise. I loved some of the ideas, especially how the combat works, with the three different panels. The story is interesting as well, and the ending was good. The achievements are also quite fair and fun, if a bit grindy. The only thing I didn't like that much was most of the dialog, although a few lines made me chuckle. Overall, I'd say It's an unique indie gem from 2011 that held up pretty well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049278202', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1339, 'last_played': 1655086520}
review:
I got this game years ago and forgot about it, and when I came back to it just a week ago, I was pretty surprised how interesting it was. I was never the best at rhythm games, or RPGs, but both of them together worked perfectly. The dialogue can leave much to be desired but it had me hooked until the very end and secret ending. The guardians at the end of each floor were interesting characters on their own as well, Concerning the plot and ending, [spoiler] I don't think Ky and Naia really got together by the end, they seemed more like siblings to me than lovers, and it really isn't a battle worth dying for so at least nothing was really at stake and nothing was bad. So at the end of the day it was a win. It didn't leave me wondering too much. [/spoiler]

So go check this game out, for both the RPG and the rhythm game, a great story, and it's incredibly made for a crowdfunded passion project.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043915372', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1651793310}
review: Remembered a song from this game and decided to give it another play after not touching it for 10 years. I recalled this game having some Reddit writing but boy howdy does it have some [i]Reddit writing[/i]. This game has aged like milk in a swamp. Whether it's the memes that were dated when this was new or the incredibly unfunny Reddit-/v/ hybrid jokes. Cool idea for a rhythm-based RPG that has you juggle multiple charts, but good fucking lord is every other textbox questionable. Would not be surprised if I ran into outright slurs if I progressed any further.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995788914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 243, 'playtime_forever': 1357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1357, 'last_played': 1445115026}
review: A really cool take on using DDR mechanics in a RPG game. One track follows the musical beat, one track is used to cast your own spells to fight the enemy, and the other track is used to defend yourself from enemy spells. This forces you to navigate three rhythm charts all at once to win fights and progress through the game. There's also equipment and upgrades as you move forward. Really unique and cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198186530370', 'num_games_owned': 2632, 'num_reviews': 571, 'playtime_forever': 1332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1332, 'last_played': 1641244701}

Well, beat the game with your arrow-keys-pressing-skills and rest, just enjoy the dialogues. author: {'steamid': '76561199095056892', 'num_games_owned': 66, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1640603761}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018830215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2193, 'last_played': 1537667715}
review:
The gameplay is extremely good and unique as a combo of rpg style real-time-turn-based esque fighting and falling arrow rhythm game. The writing is delightful and funny without being too goofy and while telling an interesting story. The music is great, and all the artwork is great to see as well.
Unfortunately, there is a bit of eugenics apologetics included. It's the "what if there was a way to encourage Good Stock to breed that didn't involve killing at all" kind, and it's the antagonists that are doing it, but it's presented as gray morality and at least successful in getting the desired people together.
I think they realized they fucked up with that bit of writing, because they heavily walk it back in the sequel, which is why I'm still recommending the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107479303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1635748801}
review:
I really love the rhythm-RPG mechanics here. That almost saved the game from the rest of itself... but not quite. There's the awkward grindiness, there's the story being edgily-written garbage. The voice acting is wooden and inconsistent and sometimes badly recorded. But I was willing to bypass a lot of that. (Also the 2D art isn't bad! Even if it gets repetitive with the palette-swap enemy designs. Much like some of the music.)

But just now I've reached a point late in the game (I think) where the badly-written story gets *much* more annoying, and uh. I may still go through the rest of this, but I can't say I actually like it anymore after that.

Bleh. I really wanted this game to be good.

I forgot to add the first time: the lag calibration only gives audiovisual feedback rather than taking a tempo tap input (though there's a bit that lights up if you push the controller button), and it seems to be kind of not enough. But then, that could just be bad calibration of the charts themselves? I'm not sure, but unless I adjust it to minus 50 or so, in a way which doesn't quite match the audiovisual, the beats don't quite line up in the actual game, which gets to be much more of a problem later. (Yeah, I know, DDR did that too, but.)

Oh, and it seems like if you hit a note, then are still holding the button when you switch boards, which is easy to do when you get to the harder levels because you will be switching boards a *lot*, then the original note doesn't count anymore? I'm not sure about this either. So many whiffed spells due to that.

(I really wanted this game to be good.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197971103804', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 730, 'last_played': 1617134855}
review: An original mix of RPG and rhythmic game. The gameplay is fun and fairly fresh, and surprisingly managable even for me (on easy difficulty). There is only very limited set (3) of enemies on each level and fighting might get a bit grindy, especially if you want to unlock all craftable items (and bonus boss and ending). The art is beatiful, although static. Music is overall excellent and fitting well with the combat. Special mention goes to the music in the final boss encounter, which is at the same time great and deviously frustrating to try to sync with it. The story is interesting and there are some clues that foreshadow events in the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025554313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 849, 'last_played': 1613050967}
review:
I wanted to like Before The Echo, but while initially showing promise, the game starts to drag the more you play it. 

First off, the writing is... not good. It is clearly someone‚Äôs earlier work and it detracts more than adds to the story. The protagonist is unlikable, his personality is 'snark' and 'blows up at people for little to no reason', and he is treated as the smartest being in existence by the story. Not the mention he sort-of supports eugenics. His ally only differs from him in the fact that she has her anger issues under control. The first boss is racist and the second is a quasi-racial stereotype. both are played for laughs, but both fall flat. There is this weird out of place rant against astrology that has more development than some of the characters.

The art is tolerable, but some of the characters look weird, like in proportions. the music is alright, at least the first few times you hear each song. 

Onto the gameplay. It starts decently enough. When you start the game, you are presented with three enemies and each one has a different soundtrack associated with it, then you get to the next floor, and find that some of the enemies there share music with enemies, and that really sets the tone for the rest of the game. 

The game feels stretched. The reused music, the forced grinding, the chance-based crafting, some of the enemy models are just reused and recoloured, to learn spells you need to play music that you have already heard many times before. The designer sat down and thought about how he could squeeze more hours out of the players. 

If you strip away all padding, the bad crafting system, everything that necessitates grind, any enemy that reuses assets, there are some good bones there. But unfortunately, everything that builds on the foundations makes it worse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272672547', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1026, 'last_played': 1612806658}
review: I love this game. The voice acting, the songs, the story, I just love it. I really do. It's pretty simple, and I love the gameplay. It's a nice way for me to just sit down, vibe, and have a good time. I love the characters, and I love the designs of everything. I highly, highly recommend it. Worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043766217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1612456585}
review:
Definitely worth a try for fans of rhythm games who are looking for a extra technical complexity and a bit of story to add spice to their styling. Something like a meeting between Elite Beat Agents and The World Ends with You with a lower budget and killer chiptune electronica.

The primary gameplay - having to watch multiple Dance Dance Revolution screens and switch between them to attack, defend, and heal - feels extremely empowering once you get into the flow of it. I haven't found this combination before anywhere, and planning a sequence of attacks and trying to adjust on the fly to enemy attacks within the context of a rhythm game was an awesome challenge.

This isn't a perfect game by any means - I'd knock the writing, which leans into the indulgent or discourteous at times, and some of the less fun design elements such as the artificial challenge of the final boss track and the reliance on random drops - but these elements weren't enough to completely cloud my enjoyment of the game.

I'm not an extreme challenge seeker, so I can't vouch for playing through on harder difficulties or hunting for achievements. Playing through once on normal mode satisfied me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025823574', 'num_games_owned': 3338, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1609543750}
review:
Gave the game another try after years left it on the backburner, but it did not got better.

The game is a rhythm-based RPG which mixes a puzzle-like rhythm game and a very generic and base RPG system with loot, equips and stats, and the oh-so mandatory crafting system. 

The game offers you a safe room from which you can explore The Tower and fight enemies of your choice to grind resources, to craft equipment and spells (Generic attack also comes from a spell) and then make a key to open a door and get to a higher level.

The combat is spent on a 3-window screen, you change between them with the Q and E buttons. Directional arrows fall from the windows, each doing different things - defense window's arrows damage you if not pressed at the proper time, mana window's arrows recharge mana on hit, and you cast your spells by pressing all the correct arrows of the selected spell in the spell window.

One of my main problems was that the game tries to be "hip". Or "radical". By being so clever and sleek that it plays the self-awareness card, and the "lame hero who got transported into world, and who has a woman sidekick who constantly mocks him". 
Conveniently, she is  the narrator as well, who has a varied amount of knowledge, based on what the tutorial or plot requires. And she talks through only an "intercom" I think? I wouldn't be surprised if there'd be a reveal-surprise-twist later on the line.
Anyway, it was a bit jarring how many times various drugs were mentioned even before the tutorial, at one point the protagonist accusing the narrator of being a date rapist, which is a very, very weird tone one wants to set in a rhythm RPG with colourful and silly characters.

The final nail in the coffin was how tediously stupid menus are, and how often button presses do not get recognised in battles. Not super often, more like 1/10-20 times, but it adds up, and makes the game feel really sloppy.

Likely there's an okay, tolerable game under the surface, but it's just not fun to play for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017750448', 'num_games_owned': 466, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1904, 'last_played': 1609216825}
review:
I recently started replaying this game again, the first time I played and completed it was back in 2011/2012. It has a lot of charm, is witty, and has an interesting concept. I would also suggest just playing through it without the use of a guide that shows you everything, it's much better that way. Right now I still cannot play on the hardest difficulty, Spasmodic, but I can get through Hard just fine. It offers a decent challenge and has an interesting story with secrets to be found throughout. It has a pretty deep battle system that allows for many different types of play, which you may just find yourself constantly tweaking as you go. Which I enjoy, it doesn't trap you into one set role.

That being said it isn't perfect. It does have a bit of a grind and there aren't an overabundance of enemies, but that's something hard to really fault it on. Given the time it came out and the small team behind it. It is impressive none-the-less.

I've been having a great time playing this again, it took me around 30 hours to fully complete initially. If a rhythm RPG sounds like something you'd be interested in I'd suggest picking it up. With the sale prices it's a steal in all honesty.

8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561199075086738', 'num_games_owned': 23, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1707227252}
review:
This is one of my favorite rhythm games. Although it's not exceptionally well polished It has a great concept, and the music is beyond dope as hell. I'd only wish the stepcharts were a little better synced; I know there's not really any judgment timings like in DDR or ITG so it's not a fundamental issue here, but as a seasoned rhythm game player over the last decade I could definitely feel which song's beats were early, and which ones were late. Again it's not a huge issue, but I could feel it.

Still though this is a fantastic game, and if the developers have any interest I would definitely encourage a 2nd game that polishes the mechanics as a whole and adds a whole new perspective to the world that this game built. I think it would be a great endeavor to consider.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020051183', 'num_games_owned': 430, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1114, 'last_played': 1493838520}
review:
The biggest negative comment that I can make about this game is that it was too short.
I'm a huge fan of rhythm games and the way that Before the Echo combined that with RPG-esque mechanics was wonderful. Having to manage switching between 3 different "tabs" for attacking, defending, and gaining mana was a really cool design choice that helped keep songs and "spells" from getting overly repetitive. Would highly recommend

author: {'steamid': '76561198036280684', 'num_games_owned': 5888, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 791, 'last_played': 1594418057}
review:
My only disappointment is that it took me this long to [i]really[/i] get into this game. The very beginning was a huge hurdle, with few options and little room for error; but once it opened up and I fell into the rhythm I was rewarded with more great music and a refreshing story. 

The gradual transition from 'struggling to stay alive long enough to beat the enemy' to 'struggling to dish out enough damage before the song ends' also kept the game from getting too monotonous. Overall a ton of fun, and well worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062546602', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1588726161}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024725286', 'num_games_owned': 687, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1588404176}
review:
Interesting concept, but there's not enough music, and not enough thought put into the design

You'll be doing a lot of grinding due to the unnecessary chance of failure during item synthesis that results in the loss of experience and levels which is vital for making progress
In addition, the note detection, while isn't the worst I've seen, is far from accurate enough for a rhythm game
The game tries to claim there's strategy involved, but because enemy attack patterns (not their attack charts) aren't consistent you can't plan to cast spells during specific parts of a song. This could have added a layer of depth that allowed you to plan out an efficient strategy to take out enemies, like in JRPGs

The writing is hit-or-miss, but the main issue is how dreadful the gameplay is
The game is just so obsessed with RNG that it really kills the entire enjoyment of the game
I want to love this game but it doesn't hold up as well as I remember

review: This is a convoluted QTE/rhythm game with a poorly illustrated visual novel slapped over the top of it.   QTE gameplay is unsatisfying, controls are meh.   Games need to be fun to play, and the strange RTS/QTE hybrid just doesn't work.   This is too lacklustre to recommend to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098947326', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1357, 'last_played': 1577057969}
review:
[h1]PROS:[/h1] Innovative game play, interesting story, beautiful art
[h1]CONS:[/h1] Lack of song variety, animations in battle sometimes obtrusive

[h1]OVERALL SCORE: 8/10[/h1]

Before the Echo is a strange game, a mashup of rhythm games like DDR or UtaPri with an RPG. It sounds like an odd combination, but it's actually wickedly fun once you get the hang of the system.

In the game, you play as Ky, a graduate student trapped in a deadly game. He's forced to fight seven bosses in The Tower, for unknown reasons. Through the game, we get banter primarily between Ky and Naia, a woman tasked with guiding him through the tower, and the various bosses. The rest of the tower is chocked full of enemies you must farm for ingredients used to make stronger weapons, spells, and key items.

Combat is super fun. It also gets varied per floor, as each of the bosses has a unique talent that changes the game. For instance, one boss speeds up the arrows, another one hides some of the game boards from you, and so on. It kept things interesting and I was always wondering what the next challenge would be. 

Overall, I thought this game was super fun and I quite liked the system once I got the hang of it. My only complaint is the number of songs. Each floor of the tower has three enemies, each with three items of various drop rates. In order to get the items and experience points, there is a certain amount of farming needed. And while the songs are good and work well for the game, there's just not enough of them to keep it interesting. What's more, although a couple new songs are introduced through fighting bosses, most of the songs end up being recycled several times. It gets tiresome. I would have liked a more expansive song list for sure.

The other issue with the game that I had was the animations that play after you cast a spell. The combat is done purely by casting spells, which is done by successfully hitting a number of arrows based on the spell's requirements. When you do succeed, an animation will flash onscreen. However, some of them take time to dissipate and they end up clouding the screen. If you're casting multiple spells in succession, this can throw you off and make it difficult to see the arrows. I'm not sure if that was intentional as an added bit of challenge, but it could be frustrating from time to time.

Despite some issues, I definitely recommend this game. The story is enough to keep you interested and the battle system is great, despite some minor issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031791945', 'num_games_owned': 466, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1497, 'last_played': 1408922862}
review:
How to mix RPG mechanics with rythm gameplay ? This game is an example of how this mix can work together.
If you know Dance Dance Revolution / StepMania, you know the most principle rule of this game : pressing the direction of the arrow at the good time when he goes down. But the game turns out to be some fights with monsters and boss, so you have 3 fields to manage. It can be confusing at the beginning, but after some tries, you will get the hand and master the management between defense, focusing mana and casting spell.

I really appreciated the game because i like rythm games and RPG games. It doesn't have much music to play, but enough to have a good time. The grinding didn't affect me personally. The story is quite fun to read. Give this game a chance, because it will be worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989008061', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1186, 'last_played': 1574293926}

I had 19 hours on it and even soo felt more and enough. As to say, as a good book, it had it place and time, no need to strech it.



It's a great fun game as it should be,

author: {'steamid': '76561198025909807', 'num_games_owned': 564, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 985, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 907, 'last_played': 1572793892}
review: What's not to like?  It's a well balanced, progression based rhythm game with rpg elements.  I was never at a point where normal difficulty seemed either insurmountable or unchallenging.  The voice acting was good and the music was enjoyable.  I've paid way more for far worse games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062352118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2427, 'last_played': 1655855694}
review:
Such potential, such... mediocrity. The integral gameplay conceit is really fun and switching between all three fields on higher difficulties makes you feel like a genius...

...but the grinding and similar enemies can become stagnant late game, and the storywriting feels like it was done by a 15 year old programming student who just read Ctrl+Alt+Delete or another similar gaming webcomic and thought that consistently snarky, quote-unquote self-aware writing is charming and not just cliche and annoying.

That being said, some of the music is a standout; it doesn't debut until one of the final battles but Guitar Sound especially is a bop. Overall, I want to rate this a 7/10 because I'm a sucker for rhythm games, but please take that with several grains of salt.

(Edit: Upon reflecting for some time, I've decided the game probably isn't the type I'd recommend to others, despite me personally enjoying it.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197991458714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1569108810}
review: Very unique concept. The UX could use some work and the soundtrack lacks some much-needed variety considering this is a rhythm game. The voice acting and character design are well done for a game of this scope, but in my opinion that time could have been better spent improving the core game loop. That being said, I really enjoyed trying out new spell combinations and multitasking between the defensive/mana/spell screens.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009671450', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 945, 'last_played': 1674684837}
review:
This game deserves far more credit than it receives. Not only are all the mechanics for attack, mana gathering, and blocking perfectly balanced, but the controls make the experience smother than melted butter regardless of your preference for keyboard or controller. As the beautiful buttercream frosting on this moist rhythmic butter cake is the brilliant story. It left me in stitches laughing, left me with baited breath from fear, and inspired me to fight through some of the most intense boss battles I have experienced fueled by righteous fury and a need to win for the sake of my friends in the game.

Not to mention it's the prequel to There Came an Echo, by far one of the best military-style strategy game. These devs are ones to keep following for years to come as it becomes apparent that they are creating an amazing immersive universe through their broad genre range, and I look forward to more installations of the Echo series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002674594', 'num_games_owned': 757, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1563998536}
review:
Imagine three games of Guitar Hero going at once that you switch between, but Ronald Jenkees is your DJ and every note you hit either keeps you alive or contributes to the casting of a spell that will destroy your enemy. Now add a character stats/level system, a whole lot of spells and items and crafting. Dance battle magic-sling your way out of a weird and goofy series of creatures and bosses.

This game is seriously great fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130487478', 'num_games_owned': 1007, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1018, 'last_played': 1554564846}
review:
Before the Echo is an RPG rhythm game where you must fight monsters to escape a mysterious tower.

If you've ever played a rhythm game before, then you know for the most part what to expect. Arrows will fly down the screen and you must hit the corresponding buttons on time to succeed. This game does have some different mechanics that set it apart though.

When fighting monsters, you have three different fields that you can switch back and forth through. There is a mana field, a spell field, and a defense field. Each field has a different purpose.

The defense field is your main one. If you don't match the rhythm on this field, you lose health. You want to make the enemy lose all their health before you lose yours. This is where the spell field comes in.

In Before the Echo, you have the ability to craft spells and then use them in battle. With the spell field, you don't have to interact with it until you cast a spell. Once you cast a spell, the arrows will show up on the spell field. If you mess up hitting the arrows, then the spell is not cast and you must recharge it again. If you hit them correctly, you cast the spell.

Lastly, there is the mana field. Arrows will be falling down this field all battle. You get no penalty for not hitting them. You only use this field if you need to collect mana to cast spells. Once you collect enough mana, you can ignore the field until you need mana again.

Maintaining all three fields in a tactical way is the main focus of battle.

It sounds complicated but it's very simple. You can see all three fields at all times and it's very easy to switch between them.

There were a few reviews complaining about a large amount of grind you had to do. I personally didn't have this problem since I barely had to grind. In the game, you have to get items from each monster before entering the next level. I always got the items fairly quickly, but there is a small amount of grind for people who don't like that sort of thing.

Another positive about the game is the voice acting. It's far from perfect but It was apparent the devs enjoyed doing it. (It's especially apparent in the after game credits.) The story is interesting and there are plenty of goofy and entertaining characters.

Overall, if you need another rhythm game to scratch your itch, then Before the Echo is a good choice. It has some flaws. It could use a larger monster and music variety (the music is just so-so) but it's a well-made game with a lot of love put into it. It's currently on sale for a dollar so I recommend it if you enjoy rhythm games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198173279130', 'num_games_owned': 883, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1561737274}
review:
Note: I completed the entire campaign in the easiest mode (I am not skilled in rhythm games and was not interested in a difficult challenge)

Before the Echo is a story-driven rpg rhythm game that defies expectations with its colorful artwork and attention to detail. Although you should not expect the utmost fidelity, the game is easily worth the cost. The story follows Ky as he journeys through a mysterious tower and meets quirky allies and enemies. While the story is relatively straight-forward, the game flows at a comfortable pace such that the story is neither short nor overly long and thus boring. The game loop is relatively simple-grind materials from monsters to craft items to prepare yourself for the floor boss before moving forward. However, the grind is relatively painless (most materials you should be able to get from 1-3 battles) and the variety in music and monsters covers this mechanic well. Moreover, the game is entirely voice acted (a major surprise and feat for such a cheap games) and fits well within the world. One weakness of the game is the battling and UI though, although simple enough, the weak graphics jar with the otherwise well-crafted characters and backgrounds.

Pros:
* Game is relatively simple and easy to pick up.
* Cheap - easily get what you pay for
* Music is good, while not the most memorable it will stick with you in the moment.
* Artwork is great, everything blends well and looks great.
* Voice acting is surprisingly fantastic (and the game is fully voice acted).
* Did not experience any bugs!

Cons:
* UI is below average and while functional, not particularly enticing.
* Battling graphics/effects follow this trend, while readable they are fairly weak and look somewhat unpolished.
* There is a grind to the game that does artificially increase game length (though it handles it better than most other games) 

Before the Echo may appear at first to be a cheap indie game, but looking beneath the hood and spending time with it showcases the amount of love and support that went into crafting it. The passion and effort shows in the high-quality of such a inexpensive game. Rhythm games may not be for everyone, but the barrier to entry to this game is very low.

Score: 7.5/10 -> You get well-above what you pay for! Pick this game up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198190380543', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 602, 'playtime_forever': 854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 854, 'last_played': 1549628492}
review: Before the Echo, or Sequence (the original name) is a pretty cool rhythm-based RPG. The gameplay consists of hitting inputs at the right time though 3 different grids: one to cast spells, another to recover mana (to cast more spells) and another to defend yourself from enemy attacks. Also, you can only be on one grid at a time, so you‚Äôll be juggling between them a lot. Those are the basics of the game. For progression, you have the standard RPG stuff, in which you level up to get stronger and also you can gather, craft, and equip better and better equipment. A key difference is that you don‚Äôt have money here. Instead, you spend your XP to craft new items. Likewise, selling unwanted items nets you extra XP. This means there‚Äôll be times where you‚Äôll actually decrease a level or two, but that doesn‚Äôt detract from the experience. However, crafting items isn‚Äôt a guaranteed success, so you‚Äôll be gambling your XP and sometimes you‚Äôll get nothing. It‚Äôs frustrating at times, and the main problem I have with the game. For example, to learn the various spells you also have to gamble XP, but the success or not depends entirely on your skill. You can even practice it first in a simpler rhythm minigame. The spell variety is also nice. Also, the game is a bit grindy, especially if you want to have everything in your possession. You‚Äôll be fighting the same enemies over and over. But these design decisions are only a bit annoying, and won‚Äôt ruin your experience with the game. The songs are pretty cool, but the game would benefit from a few more. The art style didn‚Äôt impress me, but I enjoyed the story and, for an indie title, the voice acting was surprisingly good. You‚Äôll want to keep playing to see who it all plays out. Also, there‚Äôs a few secrets, including voiced credits. And that‚Äôs how you keep people interested in the credits! The game is cheap, lasts around 10-15 hours, and I can recommend it. In the end, I was surprised by it, in a good way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034883253', 'num_games_owned': 1004, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1548009945}
review: This is a hard game to review. I love so much about it but at the same time they did so much wrong. I quit after the 5th floor and just looked up a walkthrough of the game to see how the story ends as that what was keeping me playing. The gameplay is extremely good but the grind gets to be unbearable. I don't mind battling the same 3 monsters a few times over but when you need to grind for an hour just to get to the next floor it gets too boring. Also the song choice was pretty weak. I get that music is expensive but I can't honestly say I enjoyed a single song in the game. The voice work was surprisingly decent and as I said before I looked up a walkthrough to see how it ends because I was that interested in the story. Overall it's a good game but the grind needed to be reduced a lot and the song choice could be a lot better but if you can get past that it's very fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052007123', 'num_games_owned': 6823, 'num_reviews': 1308, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1545775173}
review: Take a rhythm game, add some RPG elements and voila, you get "Before the Echo". This game looks much better on videos (and while playing) than on screenshots, trust me. I was sure it will be either a boring game, or something for hardcore DDR players. But it's not, so if you enjoy interesting combination of genres, this is a good choice. Before the Echo is also cheap during sales (up to 80% off).

author: {'steamid': '76561197970338557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 5952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5862, 'last_played': 1542215414}
review:
Before the Echo (aka Sequence) holds a special place in my gaming library because it's one of the first games that tried to add rhythm game mechanics to another genre (JRPG). Crypt of the Necrodancer and others came later, but none integrate the rhythm game as well with their respective genres. Crypt, for instance, just makes rhythm another layer of difficulty on top of a roguelike. Before the Echo bases its combat on rhythm, but in ways that scale. What I mean by this is that when you cast a spell, you input some moves. You block by inputting moves. You regain mana by inputting moves. But all this happens in realtime so you have to prioritize what you're doing. Can you block that red attack in the space between two streams of your own spell? Can you grab a little extra mana during that block string? That's up to you as a rhythm game player. It would've been so easy to take a standard JRPG and just make dance inputs, so that every attack is like Sabin's blitzes from FF6. Instead it did something way more interesting and better integrated.

On the other hand, the story is weak, the progression is highly linear, and the playtime is padded out by a moderate amount of grinding. It's by no means a perfect game, but I'm giving it the thumbs up based on the strength of the mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009847919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1327219200}
review:
Bought way back when.

When used to such rhythm games it's a good challenge towards the end, but the joke is that at some point you're required to grind ridiculous amounts of stuff to be able to finish a boss before: a) The song finishes due to not being able to deal enough damage b) The available RPG elements make you fail due to not grinding enough.

Besides the already mentioned terrible dialogue and whatnot. Not memorable, do not waste your time.

Get StepMania instead!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056803097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1692954686}
review:
I played this to completion on the XBox (back when it was known as Sequence). The game is an interesting mash-up of JRPG and Rhythm Game. Graphics and sound are functional, but the gameplay is fun and the experience is unique (which is all too rare these days).

The game is admittedly very short: I completed it in a couple of days and there isn't much replay value, though at this price point, I have no problem recommending it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991182403', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1372225535}
review: I received this game from a give-away on a forum, and I'm really glad I did.  Mixing a rhythm game with an RPG was genius, the tracks are good, even the aesthetics and the storyline are fantastic.  I loved it just using a keyboard, and I can't imagine how much better it would be on a pad or a guitar.  I know we'll never get it, but I really hope we see a VR expansion of the idea, using Beat Saber as a base instead of DDR.

review:
Waaaaay too grindy at the end, which is ridiculous if you look at it balancewise at the start and at the almost end.
Going from 1 to 100 out of nowhere on floor 5-7
music sounds almost like midis? Like bad midis, plus the same song is used over and over again, wtf? a MUSIC game with such a small amount of music that the same songs are used on multiple floors? holy shit, I'm sorry but the idea of this is great but jesus christ, could've atleast thrown a couple more songs in there.
For the price? Maybe, if you're really looking for a timewaster where it makes you feel like you've almost made no progress at all. Thats what it feels like for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052000382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 767, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1532954782}
review:
The game has a rather limited soundtrack, and it is a game almost entirely built on grinding for materials.

Despite this, Before the Echo has a solid battle system, and the battle music you'll be listening to as you play is certainly some good stuff, even dated as it is seven years later.

Play it in short bursts, and you should have enough fun to get your money's worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198319572897', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1531714666}
review:
I don't often review games but I figured that this game deserves one.

I bought this during the 2018 summer sale along with a load of others and I have to say that this is one of the strangest rythm games I've ever played.

the style reminds me a lot of VOEZ for mobile which I would definitely suggest getting over this.
you have 3 ddr style pannels with falling arrows. I'm not sure if this is compatible with a ddr mat but if it is then that would make it a much better game.

the art is very nice if a bit monotone and that works well to describe the whole game. it's nice, but it feels like a robot made it. mana lane is a nice idea but I don't think it was executed well. and the controls feel obnoxious on keyboard.

my main problem with this game is the music. I don't want to dodge the point so here: the music is absolutely trash. I think my granda's appartment's elevator has better music than this game. it's just so bland and boring. If I could use my own audio files that would be a great update but until then I have to call this game almsot unplayable. 

Don't touch anything has a better sound track than this game and it only has one song.

and don't even get me started on the characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988172345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1868, 'last_played': 1649533068}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049640264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1529871707}

author: {'steamid': '76561198090120063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 870, 'last_played': 1530872596}
review:
A well done niche game. Dance dance revolution or Guitar hero style prompt matching with the addition of 3 screens to balance matching from to stay alive and deal damage in the battles.

I played it on medium difficulty (2/4) and found it quite well balanced, the jumps I noticed between the difficulties are quite large though with easy getting 4 mana per mana prompt and faster attacks vs mediums 2 mana slower attacks and hards 1 mana even slower attacks.

It can be a little repetitive but one should play this game for the gameplay which is very enjoyable. Its also easy to play for up to 4mins (1 battle) then stop and play again later. 

The story is a nice well done bonus, the voice acting is good and the flavortexts are quite comical.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044464577', 'num_games_owned': 568, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1432990152}

author: {'steamid': '76561198061543320', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1530207359}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197992496262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1552, 'last_played': 1384324061}
review:
I played this back before it changed names, so it's been a while. So when I say it still sticks in my brain as a unique thrill of a game years later... I want you to understand my full meaning. It's been at least 5 years if not longer, and I still think about it sometimes.

The game blends RPG and DDR-like elements with good music and a decent story. It has some replay value, too: there are multiple difficulty levels, should you want to go back through and play on a harder mode. Slow reflexes? Carpal tunnel? Not a problem -- just play on the easiest mode and enjoy the ride. Keyboard dance master? There's a difficulty mode for you, too.

It's well worth the price even when it's not on sale. When it -is- on sale, it's a steal. Get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198232773484', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1593225711}
review: Spasmodic - For those socially challenged. Beautiful

author: {'steamid': '76561198418549470', 'num_games_owned': 1154, 'num_reviews': 651, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1588546487}
review:
Clever idea for a game, but the gamepad controls did not work for me. Having to press the D-PAD and ABXY buttons at the same time would often fail to trigger at the same time. And I tried two brands of gamepads. This was especially troublesome where songs required chording-combos.

During the long tutorial, I was intregued by what might be another decent rhythm game, because I enjoyed playing the Frederic games. This seemed to be a dexterity-rhythm game, resource-crafting, with decent voice acting. Unfortunately, even the keyboard controls were a bit of a mess, so the battle gameplay was not a fun experience.

I played this game on ubuntu linux 16.04 & 19.10 with radeon mesa drivers. The game uses XNA engine. The game plays more accurately with the keyboard, even though it was obviously designed for the controller and heavily recommends one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198307014804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1529044240}
review: edgy, unfunny, badly balanced. a mix of my two favorite genres that left me dissatisfied times two. dont get this game. especially if you arent an edgy kid who laughs at offensive humor that crosses the line many times. from the very start you get sentences like 'getting stabbed by a hobo' and get greeted by a rape joke. cool concept but terrible and deeply unpleasant execution

author: {'steamid': '76561197961197022', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1528466182}
review:
Loved the premise, and style initally. Tutorial a bit of a drag, super easy and does litearlly nothing to prepare you for the real game. The first true battle after the tutorial was such an immense difficuly spike I failed after about 10 seconds repeatedly.

Utterly game breaking

author: {'steamid': '76561198015278081', 'num_games_owned': 2666, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 1021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1387248240}
review: Sequence, aka Before the Echo, is a really good rhythm game. I came for the gameplay, stayed for the story, the grind could have been easier, but, hey, I only have positive memories about this game. I haven't touched it in a while, but back then, it was delicious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040604849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 726, 'last_played': 1526806985}
review: Great game. Usually don't love rhythm games but this is really fun. Shame the title got changed from "Sequence."

author: {'steamid': '76561197997453217', 'num_games_owned': 707, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1567467324}
review:
Stepmania: the RPG. This game has a ton of personality, is meta af, and does pretty much everything right in terms of storytelling, character design, but just playing a keyboard dancing/rhythm game as a way to fight monsters and cast spells is innovative enough. It's been done a few times since, but this is the first time I ever saw this concept executed, and the additional charm and personality of the sci-fi setting and clever writing made me fall in love with it. Full disclaimer: very hard on the highest difficulties. I've been playing Stepmania for around 10 years, and I couldn't progress to the end of the game on my first try. I do suck though, so there's that to consider.

Was better when it was called 'Sequence' though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020720029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 1345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1604825125}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979464751', 'num_games_owned': 259, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2327, 'last_played': 1535358343}
review: If you think you're good at DDR, FFR, or StepMania, you're probably not, and this game will prove it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986291714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1517789031}
review:
I generally don't play rhythm games, for the sole reason that I am more or less tone-deaf. I recieved this game (among a few other indie-titles) as a complimentary bonus when I bought my first AMD graphics card way back, and after sitting untouched in my library for almost 4 years I decided to give it a try.

The RPG/rhythm mix was unexpected, but appreciated. The game has crisp graphics and artwork, witty writing (the biggest plus in my opinion), and great voice acting. The biggest downside is the scarce amount of tracks avaliable to choose from, but it is an understandable issue. It gets a bit repetitive. For this reason I find the game best to play in shorter bursts, instead of for hours at end.

But I do recommend the game, without a doubt. It's a funny, casual experience with likeable gameplay and characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042762107', 'num_games_owned': 521, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2004, 'last_played': 1707625037}

author: {'steamid': '76561198084415854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 835, 'last_played': 1514647413}
review: https://walkienotalkie.wordpress.com/2017/12/29/before-the-echo-review/

author: {'steamid': '76561198094033276', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1516560091}
review:
I have had no technical issues with this game.

I can see what they were trying to do heree but the execution has not really worked. Story tries to flip between intriguing and campy schlock but it does not succeed in either completely makig it feel lack lustre.

The attempt to make a story based, RPG, rhythm game is admirable but the problem with this combination of genres is that none feels fully satisfying. There are not enough songs and you are asked to grind songs to gain items to craft more items to move on to further levels. Grinding a song should not be enforced but should be enjoyable and it is not to me which leads on to one of my main complaints.

The way the rhythm game works is flawed. There is not enough feedback to let yoou know if you have hit a note or not which is a tad frustrating (not as bad at this as some othr games). However the mechanic of flipping between three rhythm tacks (think a 3 instrument song in something like Rock Band Blitz or Frequency/Amplitude) would be fine if there was a feeling of groove which continued between tracks but with the randomly generated button promps (at least in terms of directioon) it is impossible to achieve this.

All this being siad - I do not hate the game it just needs some improvements in too many areas for me to be able to recommend it. May be worth a pick up in sale (it's currently 79p and it'd be worth a go for that) but don't expect to be finding a new rhythm game obsession here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122787031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1472344192}

review:

Rather than redownload this game, give it another shot, I'm just gonna write it off here. If nothing stood out to be, nothing at all, then I don't think it's a very good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036100074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1131, 'last_played': 1344754800}
review:
DDR as a RPG. It's fun switching between the three screens along with the beat, along with practicing for even crafting materials. Normally I'm pretty terrible at rhythm games but I 100%'d this one. I really enjoyed it.

It's worth the 5 bucks if nothing else. If you see it on sale, pick it up faster.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016716928', 'num_games_owned': 691, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1349593200}

author: {'steamid': '76561198242841244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1203, 'last_played': 1537430477}
review: Our protagonists are awkwardly charming, a bit of quirkiness added onto stock character types. The dialogue is often times hilarious. Be ready to screenshot. Compelling music, fun bonus level. The list goes on. But simply? This game wins because it's just... very fun to play! It's been years since any work has been done on this game, but this is my favorite game out of my entire Steam library of 134 titles. I will remember this game for a very long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010827889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1890, 'last_played': 1509541969}
review:
This is a recommend with a lot of caveats.

The core gameplay is exceptional. Rhythm and RPG are a surprisingly effective combination, with the game rewarding good spell and tactical choices as much as mastery of the rhythm mechanics.

HOWEVER

The story is, at best, cringe-worthy and cliche, written by someone who clearly thinks they are incredibly clever. There's a few good moments, but nothing that's worth it. So, if you play it, after the tutorial, skip every single cutscene and rush through every single bit of dialogue.

And expect a lot of grinding for random drops. You need drops to craft items, and you need XP to craft them. But you don't just spend XP, you choose how much XP you spend to improve your CHANCE of crafting that item. So even once you have all the materials, a couple of unlucky breaks and you're back to grinding again. The worst thing about it is that there is actually a much better mechanic for it ALREADY IN THE GAME. When you learn a spell, you pay a certain amount of XP to take a short trial, and if you succeed, you get the spell. Why couldn't this have been done with items? To pad for time! Of course.

In summation: Before the Echo is a fantastic core game with an awful story and a lot of grinding. Once upon a time, when this was $30? I'd never recommend it to anyone. Right now, at $5? Probably worth it if only so you can see what it could have been.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970761123', 'num_games_owned': 2953, 'num_reviews': 896, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1503774345}
review:
I played this game once, on normal and stopped at level 6 (out of 7) ...  

I played this game a second time and stopped at level 6.  

And yet I'm going to give this a thumbs up.  Before the Echo is what happens if you take DDR and make the player use the controller (So Stepmania), approach it from a multi lane system (like frequency or amplitude) and then add in RPG elements (puzzle quest). 

And the end result is... well pretty impressive.  The game is played like an RPG, with the main character exploring floors.  Well "Exploring" in reality he chooses one of three monsters on each floor to fight, and is sent to a combat screen. 

The combat in this game will be recognizable to anyone who has played a rhythm game before.   You press buttons to trigger different directions on three grids, each doing a different task.  If you are on the defense grid, you're blocking attacks, if you're on the mana grid you're gaining mana, and if you're on the spell grid you're casting your magic.  And you'll be switching between the three grids as you play the game.   

There is also a similar mini game to learn spells.  The entire time there's quality music being played, a selection created specifically for this game, and while I won't be humming these songs later, the music is enjoyable.

There's also a rather solid story to this game, the player is locked in a tower with 7 floors and must reach the top level to ... well honestly I don't know because I never reached there, however the first 6 floors had a relatively engaging story, even a few twists that worked well.

However the first problems with the game is around the 5th level the game gets annoyingly tedious.  Enemies get too much life, and there's a time limit to every battle (the length of the song) but they also start throwing VERY powerful attacks that the player.  Wait long enough for a really good spell? Well you might have to choose between taking massive damage (20 points where you might have less than 150 total points) or skipping that spell that's lost forever and needs to be recharged

On top of this, the enemies start having 3 digits of life, usually more than the player, and they will be punishing. 

There's even four difficulties of the game which is a good start, it does add notes and movements to songs, and that's a cool feature, but even on easy, the sixth level is tedious.  In fact it's always tedious. It's not impossible, but... well then there's the other part of the game, crafting. 

At first the crafting system is cool and new.  You kill monster get items (up to three different items per enemy, though on item per type)  and then can make stuff out of it.  On Level 1 there's only 4 or 5 craftable items.  Each level adds 1 more recipe, so level 6 has around 10 recipes, by that point you either have played entirely too much of the previous levels, or you got sick of them and have a ton of unmade recipes in your inventory.  

But the problem is every drop only comes from one monster.  If you don't like fighting the insect on level 6 (A decently fast and hard fight)  too bad, you have to.  And the other side of that is you don't fight him once, you will have to fight him two or three times just to progress because the key to the next level is craftable to, and even more if you want to make everything.  

So even if you somehow beat him you'll have to go and grind him again and again which is where the real tedium comes in, and that's assuming you don't get unlucky and miss a potential drop (as each drop has a percentage chance to appear).   It artificially lengths the game in the worst way.

The other side of this system is that while the player gets more powerful as he plays, he doesn't feel more powerful because the enemies on each floor are significantly more powerful too.  When I went back and fought someone from level 1 I realized how much of a god I had become, but you only get that feeling if you return to very early floors, on level 6 you feel like you're the same weakling you always were. 

However with that being said, I LIKE the core gameplay of this game.  I like the concept, I even like the story, I really like everything in it, that it hurts me that I just didn't want to finish it.  It is a really terrible feeling to say "I wanted to see it, but I can't stand the monotony. " Yet that's where I ended up. 

So I recommend it, because I did put in some good hours into it, and it is a really fun game and concept.  Just realize if you aim to beat the game, you WILL be grinding, and not in a mindless way due to the combat structure. 

Sad but overall a good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198334769585', 'num_games_owned': 480, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1417, 'last_played': 1500480287}
review:
This game was absolutely awesome! As a very experienced and advanced Dance Dance Revolution, Osu, and Stepmania player, I tend to fly through many rhythm games, especially those involving arrows. However, I was on the medium setting, and the game was challenging for me. The challenge is in the arrows, of course, but it is more so in the strategy of the game, such as navigating between the arrow screens, casting spells at the right time, making sure you have enough mana, trying to defeat the enemy before time ran out, not getting hit, and balancing experience points, as the experience points are also currency for synthesizing and crafting items. 
I loved that mechanic of the game because it was not a set value to craft an item, but instead you can decide how many experience points to use. The higher you want your probability of success to be, the more exp you sacrifice. The probability also caps at 95%, so there are no free rides. It's a good way to keep people battling and playing and makes one think carefully before deciding what to create. Quite a few times, I had to go down a level to create something I needed. I also liked how in this game, you have to accept that you will lose hp in battle in order to defeat the enemies. This is not a huge deal because all your stats reset after every battle.
The story itself was also very original, although it didn't get very deep until the end. When it did get deep, though, it went far. There are a lot of twists that are less predictable than I had anticipated, and the plot gets into the nitty-gritty of what's going on while still keeping secrets.
Playing for acheivements does actually expand gameplay, and there are quite a few little secrets in the game that lead to one large secret. 
The voice acting and audio are beautiful. The voice actors were pretty talented, and the audio was high-quality. The music during the rhythm battles was a bit underwhelming to me as a ddr player and sounded more like background music, but it was very well produced and some songs were cool. It made sense in the context of the game. The art was beautiful, too. I think the aesthetic fit the game very well, and the main characters and enemies are well-done and very pleasing.
I highly recommend this game to people who like rhythm games like DDR, Stepmania, and Osu, as well as people who just like RPG-style battles or intense games. This is a different kind of game that is very well developed and that I'd like to see more of.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049271328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 834, 'last_played': 1499629700}
review:
Before the Echo/Sequence is a fun rhythm game which actually requires strategy. One of my favourite parts was actually the credits, as they were narrated and really cute while also providing some behind the scenes information. I really think more games should do that as it made the credits both fun and informative.

Getting all the achievements took me a while due to "Erudite" and "Lies Within Lies" but this meant it was really satisfying when I finally got them. It isn't necessary to get these to enjoy the game though, if you don't want the hassle.

The story is... interesting. I go between thinking it's great and thinking it's dumb so you're just going to have to make up your own mind about it.

The music is fun, and I especially like Piano Jam as a song even if it was the main reason I found those two achievements so difficult. Of course it depends on your taste of music whether or not you'll like the soundtrack.

I would say that upon getting Lies Within Lies [spoiler]the hidden ending was a bit disappointing given how much time I spent trying to defeat the other Ky in order to see it - I'd just assumed that Shira was a part of the whole scheme anyway so this didn't really give me any new information. It's also not really made clear why she was necessary to the tower's plan other than possibly "psychological factors" or whatever. Now if we had found out the thing that is revealed in the sequel There Came An Echo (I won't spoil it if you don't already know) then it would have felt more worthwhile. But I guess this just comes back to my point about the story. If the big plot twist hadn't been a weird eugenics thing but the other thing instead then I would love the story so much more.[/spoiler]

All in all this was an enjoyable game with interesting gameplay. Check it out if you're interested in rhythm games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004355797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2215, 'last_played': 1608674774}
review: I boughtBefore the Echo a long time ago.  I keep coming back to it.  It's premise is a simple rythym game like the dance ones we used to find in the arcarde.  The story is short but really good.  The music is worth actually listening too.  Outstanding game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968801600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1499214914}
review: As much as I'd like to recommend this game just so we can get a streamlined version of this game I can't recommend it in it's current form.  I enjoyed the story (including the ending) and there are some good songs.  That said though not all the songs are that great and when you're "grinding" in this game it can be really tedious.  Speaking of "grinding" that's my biggest hiccup with this game.  You grind for items but ALL items have a percentage.  This means that sometimes you could play a near 5 minute song and end up with only EXP.  It's infurating to say the least even with items that make the % go up.  So if a sequal was ever made for this game (and I'm not talking about There Came An Echo) please make the game less grindy.  If this was a short game I'd take it for what it is and come back and play it over and over but because of the grind, I never will come back to this game sadly.  Thank you for your hard work and I look forward to your next project.  I know you have potential!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994939278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2811, 'last_played': 1498872101}
review:
Other than the unexpected name change, Before the Echo (originally Sequence) is a fun music-timed RPG game where you fight monsters a la parappa the rapper style until the end. Some of the music is really good (Ronald Jenkees bits are good synth-game music) and the features for the magic system are really interesting. 

Give this a try if you like DDR, Parappa, or any game based on music, or if you enjoy games with twitch reflexes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031399827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1498329038}
review:
For anyone looking for an entertaining blend of RPG and rhythm game, I'd recommend you skip over this title and buy The Metronomicon instead. Why? The tutorial is better, the music is better, the backgrounds and character designs are more animated and interesting overall, and the gameplay mechanics are more challenging and ultimately more satisfying to play.

I couldn't get through the horrible jokes of the extremely boring tutorial. Even the protagonist seemed like he really didn't want to be in this game. I don't mind involved tutorials when the gameplay captures my interest, but this game sure doesn't. Considering some of the other comments, I'm rather glad I didn't get to the grindy portion of the game. I don't know if the music ever gets any better, but I'm pretty sure the gameplay does not.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995749658', 'num_games_owned': 1958, 'num_reviews': 1565, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1498401807}

review:
