Metiendonos m√°s profundo Before the Echo es un juego de ritmo mezclado con elementos RPG y he de decir que lo hace perfectamente. La secuencia de botones se divide en 3 paneles diferentes que tendr√°s que tocar a la vez, y me encanta como lo ha llevado, el resultado es muy satisfactorio y muy divertido de jugar.
El doblaje de los personajes y sus di√°logos lo hacen muy divertido cuando no estas jugando
(pero CUIDADO est√° solo en ingl√©s)
Es rejugable, pues a veces tendr√°s que farmear si quieres alg√∫n objeto antes de tiempo, y tiene diferentes dificultades que te invitan a volver a jugarlo cuando le has cogido el tranquillo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128292174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1455481278}
review: Great music. Everything else is fairly secondary, but it still has a decent storyline and gameplay, albeit with too much grinding near the end (but what game doesn't have that).

author: {'steamid': '76561197973224937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1494850009}
review:
This game is a mix of rythm games and jrpg. The story is pretty interesting but the game is too much of a grind for my liking. The music is ok but there is not enough variance.

The game mechanics were fresh to me. You tap keys in the rythm of the music to cast spells. Inbetween battles you can craft new gear to make you hit harder or take less damage.

For me there was just too much grind in the game so this is why I can not recommend it. There are just a handfull of enemy types and songs. However for the price it is not really a bad game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1643693295}

author: {'steamid': '76561198055441828', 'num_games_owned': 728, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 883, 'last_played': 1613795556}
review:
Before the Echo is a rythem game that is also an RPG and that alone is pretty interesting. But it goes beyond just being an interesting idea into the realm of decent execution. 

PROS:
*Compelling Story
*Voice Acting
*Quality Voice Acting
*Excellent sense of humour
*Enjoyable music

CONS:
*A tad repetitive

The story is actually fairly compelling and the characters have a lot of charm. Heck, even the item names and descriptions provide plenty of entertainment. THe difficulty is flexible and allows you to have fun at almost any skill level. As for the music, it's fairly good, but can get a bit repetitive at times if you are trying a certain to aquire a certain item or beat a certain boss or grind for XP(which you almost must do, but not to an insane degree, and can techniclly be overcome through sheer skill in most cases.) I'd recomend this game very highly if you enjoy ryhtem games, story games, and lighthearted yet serious games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032683935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1493600158}
review: its trash

author: {'steamid': '76561198048365487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1390684790}
review: This is a review that I perhaps should've done some years ago. But to keep matters short, the gameplay got stale after a while, the farming for items got fairly tedious. The story was somewhat interesting at first hand, but towards the end of the game; it's plot twist, was what ruined it. I don't remember much of the music, so I can't really comment on it. On that end, I didn't find this game to be my cup of tea.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045934424', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1144, 'last_played': 1435519074}
review: Formerly known as Sequence, Before the Echo is a rhythm-based RPG. It features some of the music of a wonderful artist named Ronald Jenkees (check him out on the Youtubes) among others. The game genre puts a relatively innovative spin on the rhythm games of the time. Working both to progress through levels as well as manage your resources, this game is a clever mash up. The dialogue and plot of this game, while cheesy at times, is pretty hilarious and I thoroughly enjoyed watching every single cutscene. The suspense of what the situation is regarding the main characters is profoundly strong for a seemly small game. One of the few games so far that I have ever 100% in achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078051898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 672, 'last_played': 1492674989}
review:
Before the Echo is basically what happens when you mash a ddr game with a rpg.

[u]It's a standard rpg experience.[/u] There are varying levels of grindiness depending on how completionist/what difficulty you're playing at. There is also a fair amount of repetitiveness.

But, [u]your weapon of choice is music[/u]. Or more specifically, how good you are at rhythm games and multitasking. You will be hearing the same songs multiple times so if you don't like the songs, you're out of luck.

The [u]story plays out like a standard visual novel[/u] so if you really don't like cheesy lines and a generic storyline, maybe take that into account.

All in all, as someone who likes rpg and heavily enjoys music games, I highly recommend this game to people of a similar likeness. It's a decent length, has just the right amount of grind, quite smooth gameplay, a decent soundtrack, all wrapped up with a smidgen of comedy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015412685', 'num_games_owned': 1972, 'num_reviews': 1015, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1441413362}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030363460', 'num_games_owned': 922, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1483228452}
review:
Before the Echo is a perfect mash-up of the rhythm and RPG genres. You use DDR style mechanics to cast powerful spells, restore your mana, and block incoming attacks as you make your way through the increasingly dangerous dungeons. The characters are really likeable, and I found myself enjoying the story way more than I expected. The villains in particular are quite entertaining, and while I won't spoil them here, you're likely to remember them long after you stop playing this game. The mechanics here are rock solid, and the difficulty curves quite nicely at each level. I mostly played on normal, since I sadly don't have the time to practice enough to master the hardest difficulties, but there's definitely enough value for both hardcore rhythm gamers and players new to the genre who want to see what it's all about. If you are new to rhythm games, be aware that grind is an essential part of the experience. You're going to be fighting the same monsters time and time again on each level to unlock the items you need, and the drop rates ensure that there's a random element that can halt your progression and add some frustration. In another game, this would be a huge negative, but rhythm games are based on the idea that you're going to play the same levels over and over again to master them. I never found the grind to be an issue, but I also beat Knights of Cydonia on Expert in GH3. My tolerance is pretty high for this kind of thing.

If you love rhythm games already, buy this game. If you're not sure whether you like rhythm games but really like character focused RPGs, buy this game. If you hate rhythm games, I don't know how you got this far into my review, but this isn't going to be the game that changes your mind. I loved this game, and if you found this page in the first place, I'm willing to bet you will too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982033076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1362, 'last_played': 1389259068}
review: An innovative rhythm/combat game set to a glorious soundtrack of Ronald Jenkees, DJplayskool and others. Great for people looking for a well structured music driven game that don't mind repeating tracks over a few times to get the most out of it. Recommended for more casual players and people looking for a challenge (with higher difficulties)

author: {'steamid': '76561197969643946', 'num_games_owned': 927, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1487939391}
review:
DDR-like rhythm game with a repetitive and grindy RPG bottom line.

----

The gameplay of Before the Echo involves swapping between three different screens of falling arrows to hit in the right rhythm. Each screen has a different effect - one is for generating mana with which to cast spells, one is for casting spells to damage your opponent or for a variety of other effects and the last one is to defend yourself from enemy attacks which deplete your hp.

The gameplay itself is quite good. The falling arrows are tracked well with the music on all the difficulties and swapping between screens adds an interesting multi-tasking and decision making aspect.

Where the game falls down is the RPG elements. You're given a bunch of recipes to craft which require materials dropped from battles. This involves repeating the same battles with the same music over and over again to get the required materials and then actually crafting the recipe has an experience point cost. In my two hours of playing I leveled from 1 to 4 and then back down to 1 again after having crafted all the items for the first floor and eventually finished on level 3 again at the start of the second floor. You can see why this is a problem.

By the time I arrived on the second floor I was looking forward to a new set of songs at least and was unpleasantly surprised to find that the three battles for that floor were all tracks I'd heard before. Two out of three tracks were songs I'd just spent an hour on for the previous floor. Exactly the same. The prospect of grinding more battles on songs I've already heard for item upgrades and character level downgrades made me uninstall right then and there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998391090', 'num_games_owned': 2587, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 936, 'last_played': 1487886181}
review: Probably considered an older XBLA indie classic at this point, I finally got around to finishing this game six years after the fact on the Mac. Fun game with a weird silly sci-fi nonsense plot, but good tunes and a solid mechanic make the game what it is. Note: strongly suggest playing with an Xbox/PS controller over the default mouse and keyboard setup. (Game previously known as Sequence.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030123832', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 346, 'playtime_forever': 812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1545492099}
review:
I cannot overstate how awful the story of this game is.

I won't even talk about the gameplay, because the gameplay could be as good as the Second Coming of Christ and it wouldn't forgive the awfulness of the story. Skip every cutscene, do yourselves a favour.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078815095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1486447790}
review:
As someone from the DDR generation, it takes a lot for a rhythm game to receive a good review from me. Keep that in mind when reading this review.

Before the Echo is a very interesting approach to the genre. It combines RPGs and rhythm. During the game you equip your character with various equipment and spells and fight monsters.

Fighting monsters is accomplished by toggling between a magic, defense and mana field and trying to hit the arrows at the proper point. You will frequently find yourself choosing between recharging your mana, defending against enemy attacks, and using magic against the enemy.

This combat approach is very well implemented when using a controller. They obviously put a lot of thought into it, and it makes sense. 

The music is fine. It didn‚Äôt stand out as anything special to me. I didn‚Äôt really ‚Äúfeel‚Äù it though, so it was more a matter of watching the arrows than listening to the beat. This can probably be improved by ensuring your audio settings are correct. 

I have mixed feelings about the tutorial and plot. The tutorial accomplishes its purpose well, after playing through it, you know how to play the game. The plot consists of waking up in a tower, having a snarky/sarcastic woman tell you what is going on, and then fighting monsters to get a key to move to the next floor. I don‚Äôt know more than that, as the game quickly lost my interest. 

I was very glad we have the ability to skip the plot scenes. I found the character‚Äôs interactions very annoying. 

Despite being well designed, the game didn‚Äôt grab my interest. It felt like it was missing something. It is inexpensive enough that fans of the genre might as well give it a try, but casual players should look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025708389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1486424487}
review:
The mashup of RPG/rhythm is very cool, and switching between the different aspects of the battle is a great idea.  That's where my praise of this game ends.

In one of the worst openings to any game I've ever played, we are immediately subjected to terrible dialogue with worse voice acting.  Every line is delivered awkwardly and with a shoehorned-in joke.  The writer goes out of their way to try to poke fun at RPG/gaming stereotypes, and not a single joke lands.  

If that wasn't bad enough, we're subjected to approximately 20 minutes of tutorials before we can even play the game.  A character even calls the game out on having too many tutorials, which begs the question why this was not fixed prior to release.

When we finally get to play the game, we find that we're in for a repetitive, non-stop grind.  Let's go through the steps it takes to learn a new spell:  1) grind multiple battles against one or more enemies. 2) craft the spell, which may fail, requiring repeat of step 1. 3) learn the spell, requiring you to play a mini-game, which is a more boring version of a regular battle, oh and by the way the song is the same song you heard 6-7 times during step 1.  What should be an exciting aspect of an RPG (learning a new spell, oh boy!) is instead reduced to a slog.  And that, in a nutshell, is Before the Echo.

Stay away from this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014499343', 'num_games_owned': 991, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1484727678}
review:
So I really enjoyed this game but some of the mechanics and choices of the game design completely kill this game for me. First, progressing through the levels requires you to farm monster drops from the various enemies. Normally, this wouldn't be too bad but getting screwed by RNG never feels good in any game. After you finally get all of your materials to craft a key to progress, you spend experience to increase the chances that your crafting succeeds. The decision to implement F2P game design into this game is mind boggling. 

So after you spend all of your experience to craft your key, you end up losing levels and stats which makes you much less likely to be able to beat the boss. In a normal game you could just trust your skills to get you through the level. However, if you don't do enough damage to an enemy before the song ends then you end up losing the battle. I really wanted to enjoy this game. I really did. But the implementation of the rpg system and the horrible crafting system really made me hate it.

With the bad being said, I would still have to recommend this game. Even wth all of the systems that I really dislike, the game still has me enjoying the musical gameplay while frantically switching between the different styles.

TLDR

Pros:
unique gameplay
good soundtrack

Cons:
hate the story and characters (subjective)
annoying rpg/crafting system
can't turn up/down in game sound
RNG sucks
Grindy

Woud still recommend even with the cons

author: {'steamid': '76561198091822767', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1649869500}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993775996', 'num_games_owned': 3613, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1286, 'last_played': 1482435472}
review:
Pros: Great music, fun gameplay mechanics, nice artwork, interesting characters + voices and good story with some snarky humour.
Con: Can get grindy

As someone who fails at DDR games, I think this game's a good 'entry level' type. It having a story and easy mode made me play it to the end, and then made me want to check out the sequel. 
Good indie 'classic' imo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999311958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1455025625}
review:
More enjoyable than I expected. Got this on sale for a very low price and was not expecting a massive amount however this turned out to be a really fun rhythm game. Another great thing is the simple graphics mean that it'll run on a laptop and can be quite fun on the move. Downsides are that the controls take some getting used to as they're slightly sluggish and some of the writing can feel overly forced. There's also a lot of grind involved, not just to level up equipment but just to clear the game due to the RNG nature of the crafting system. Finally, if you don't like the music you'll hate the game so might be a good idea to check out the OST on youtube beforehand.

In summary: 3 bruising bass lines out of 5

author: {'steamid': '76561198003674374', 'num_games_owned': 249, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1430681590}
review:
I went into this game fully knowing it was a DDR game. Being mediocre at it, i thought that it would be a simple 2 maybe 3 hours to finish this.

Now, what i did not expect was the engaging storyline, the funny banter and the relationships that develop. If you are a storyline kind of person and can do so-so in stepmania, i would encourage you to give this a go. 

While "grinding" for levels is a thing in this game, you'll notice that you would do the same in any DDR / stepmania type of game. Watch yourself get better as you aim for that perfect all the while gaining more power (by leveling) and actual skill of both memory and reflexes.

All in all, i find this to be my hidden gem. Simple gameplay, GREAT storyline and above all memorable chracters.

The three tracks and necessity to cast spells as you play mean it's not just a straight game of DDR, and lets them 'gate' content with RPG-like elements like hit points and stats, instead of just more difficult charting and songs. Gets a little grindy in the middle especially if you want to acquire all the items, but is fun enough and not too long so as to ruin the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961658357', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1408991002}
review:
Das Spiel ist eine sehr nette Mischung aus Rhythmusspiel mit RPG Elementen und hat tats√§chliche eine gute Story, was f√ºr ein Rhythmusspiel relativ selten ist (einzige andere mir bekannte ausnahme ist Elite Beat Agents, aber das ist ein ganz anderes Kaliber...).

Das Spielprinzip ist schnell erkl√§rt: Von oben fallen rhytmisch Pfeile, die anzeigen in welche Richtung man dr√ºcken muss. Die erste Neuerung hier ist, dass es drei Spielfelder gleichzeitig gibt. Jedes Match ist ein Kampf gegen einen Gegner, es gibt demnach ein Verteidigungsfeld um Schaden auf einen selbst abzuwehren, ein Regenerationsfeld um Mana aufzulagen und ein Angriffsfeld um selbst Spells abzusetzen. Da man nur ein Feld zur Zeit ‚Äûbearbeiten‚Äú kann, kommt hier ein sehr anregender Multitasking Stress zu stande. Die zweite Neuerung sind die Spells. Man bestimmt hier selbst, wann welcher Spell verwendet werden soll, was dem Multitasking nochmal einen draufsetzt.

Spells und Ausr√ºstung m√ºssen gefunden oder gecraftet werden. Die Grundzutaten dazu muss man sich erfarmen und dann auch noch das craften mit XP bezahlen. Daher ist wird das Spiel manchmal ein bischen grindlastig, war f√ºr mich aber noch aushaltbar.

Zu Story sag ich nur, dass die leicht SciFi angehaucht ist und mir sehr gefallen hat. Sie hat gerade die richtige Mischung aus Klischee und dem Spiel ebendamit getroffen um anregend genug zu sein doch immer mal wieder reinzuschauen.

Fazit:
Empfehlung f√ºr alle, die was f√ºr Rhythmusspiele √ºbrig haben und etwas Grind aushalten k√∂nnen.

PS: Die Credits nach dem Ende des Spiels sind die Besten, die ich je gesehen habe. So sollten mehr Entwickler ihre Spiele beenden.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014445897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 1260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1550261622}
review:
9/10

An interesting blend of RPG and rhythm game that works incredibly well.

Before the Echo is a game that combines the usual mechanics from rhythm games, where you have to press keys/buttons with the precise timing according to the music played, with elements from RPG games - leveling up, acquiring new gear, crafting, etc. And it does so very well. Basically, you have 3 screens - Attack, Defense and Mana. You use the Mana screen to recover Mana spent, the Attack screen to cast spells and the Defense screen to block incoming enemy attacks. To advance through the game, the player needs to know how to administer all three screens, changing between them whenever needed and using the proper timing to cast spells so that they're not cast at the same time an enemy attack is coming. The player can then learn new spells with varied effects like damage, damage over time, healing, creating a protective barrier, etc. The stronger the spell, the harder it is to cast it. Items improve the character's stats, making the character cause more damage, take less damage, recover more Mana, etc. Bosses have special abilities of their own that makes the battle harder.

At first, the story seems to be overly simplistic, but as the game develops and the story unfolds, it's revealed that there's a lot more to it. Characters are interesting and there is character development throughout the story and the voice acting is very well done.

For those who like a challenge, the game has four difficulty levels, with the hardest difficulty being for those lovers of rhythm games. The easiest difficulty still presents some challenge at later levels. (I actually had to reduce the difficulty to Easy for the last boss)

And, of course, the soundtrack - truly amazing. I would have expected a good soundtrack for a game that is heavily based on music, but even then, it surpassed my expectations.

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026608222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 847, 'last_played': 1489774824}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004736584', 'num_games_owned': 795, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1474243613}
review: Only the worst sort of game starts by corralling the player into sitting through a mostly non-interactive, twenty-minute-long tutorial consisting predominantly of banter between two characters you've never met before and have no connection with. And what little interactivity there is isn't representative of the difficulty level you're forced to pick before starting the game. I don't think I have any opinion on the game itself because I'm not sure I ever got to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997788394', 'num_games_owned': 9625, 'num_reviews': 329, 'playtime_forever': 1064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1635284069}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026761552', 'num_games_owned': 2174, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1473621062}
review:
Overall, I liked Before the Echo. I'm quite fond of rythm games in general (hard player on Guitar Hero, but not expert) and I liked the mix of rythm and RPG elements here.

At first I wasn't much into the artstyle but I got used to it and kinda like it now. Same went for the dialogues which are a bit cheesy, especially in the beginning but then you get into the story and it's all ok. I found the story interesting and mostly went to the end of the game for that. Oh and the voiced credits is a nice little bonus ^^.

As for the game mechanics, they mostly work well. You got stats to increase with stuff and level up, and spells to unlock and select for your build. The "line" selection during combats gives you control on how to spend your time and keystrokes.

Though, the main negative point I have with this game lie in the game design. I started the game in Hard mode because I'm used to rythm games, it gives a little challenge and at first it was all ok. But, as after floor 3 you can't change difficulty, I regretted that choice much later when I needed to unlock more spells and couldn't because it was too hard for me (struggling with keys and controller, more used to frets). So I finished the game with only 7 of the 20+ (?) spells unlocked. And I unlocked 2 of them out of necessity for the floor 7 boss and final boss.

The second complain I could make about the design of the game is about the final boss. On floor 7, once beat the boss of the level, you immediatly encounter the final boss and start the battle. There is a noticeable difficulty increase from the floor 7 boss. Therefore if you barely beat the previous boss, you can't beat the final boss and you have to go back and farm to level up and increase your stats. Also, because the damages notes are random, and in the battle the rythm of the song varies a lot, you end up in a total random fight when casting your spells and it ends up being infuriating. I lost my temper there with 20-30+ tries. I guess it's mostly because I didn't have the right spells unlocked but I was also struggling to unlock them.

So, could be a bit better on some points, but overall a good and enjoyable game with a nice story to it. Liking rythm games is recommended to play this one ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198000244942', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1665110434}
review: Great Music and Gameplay would play a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053559020', 'num_games_owned': 896, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1474403116}
review:
I really don't get some of the negative reviews here. First of all, it's a rhytm game - a very specific genre, which is, well... about keeping the rhytm and there isn't usually much else to it. RPG elements, like equipment, levelling up, crafting, are a very nice twist to it - but that's it. It's still a rhytm game - and if you don't enjoy things like DDR, Osu! etc. - you probably won't enjoy Before the Echo, either.

As a huge enthusiast of both mentioned genres, I enjoy the game greatly. I admit, the grinding tends to be quite monotous and gets boring after a while - then again, you don't have to be like me and craft every item possible. As long as you keep defeating different enemies, you shouldn't get easily bored. Humor and the story, though simple and there's not that much of it, make me want to keep going, if just for the sake of satisfying my - and main character's - curiosity about the place he got trapped in.

Also, for the people complaining the game's too easy - when you choose the difficulty level at the very beginning, make sure you read the descriptions carefully. It helps. :p

author: {'steamid': '76561197991129294', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1358, 'last_played': 1471625602}
review:
Juego ritmico, incluso algo casual dir√≠a yo (aunque varia segun la dificultad en la que lo juegues), con elementos RPG con equipamiento, estadisticas y niveles y puntos de experiencia.

La historia no es algo excepcional, pero te mantiene ciertamente intrigado durante algunos momentos, el final es..., bueno, el VERDADERO final no es cerrado, lo que para mi es una faena pero bueno, es preferencia personal. 

La m√∫sica es increiblemente buena, no son canciones a lo DDR, es m√∫sica electronica sin letra pero con mucho ritmo perfecta para las mecanicas del juego, y es lo que hace que este juego tenga una buena nota para mi.


Problema principal: Esta 100% en Ingles. Para mi no lo es, pero para todo el que no se maneje en este idioma, pues el juego pierde mucho, y no te vas a enterar ni de la mitad de lo que pasa.


Recomendado para todo el que se maneje en ingles y le gusten los juegos ritmicos con un toque a lo Final Fantasy. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198042011620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 744, 'last_played': 1511396974}
review: Before the Echo is an extremely pleasant time-killer, with interesting mechanics for a rythm-based game. The game is captivating, and the story(which may not be the best) is one that naturally pushes you forward to completion. The game gives you the option of grinding for better equipment/spells, but they are not necessary; skill is all that is required. Overall, amazing game with fun gameplay and a great soundtrack.

review:
Attention, petite perle m√©connue!

Le concept:
Vous affrontez une s√©rie d'ennemies dans une tour √©trange et les affrontements s'effectue via un jeux de rythme.

Si la base semble simpliste et que le jeux n'a pas une tr√®s grande dur√©e de vie, le tout est malgr√© tout tr√®s bien ex√©cut√©. Le syst√®me de jeux m√©lant combat et rpg est vraiment tr√®s bien penser, l'id√©e des 3 √©crans diff√©rents (attaque, d√©ffense et mana) est excellente et tr√®s originale (je ne connait personnellement aucun autre jeux reprenant ce syst√®me mais je serais content d'en conna√Ætre).

M√™me si vous n'√®tes pas un adepte des jeux de rythme (ce qui est totalement mon cas) vous pouvez appr√©cier ce jeux pour son challenge son gameplay bien penser et sa bonne direction artistique.

Mension sp√©ciale √©galement pour les doubleurs (anglais) du jeux qui arrive a rendre certains personnages assez attachant.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066921036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1441755838}
review:
While both rhythm games and RPGs are not unknown land to me, a game that combines both of them in an almost seamless way made for a very unique experience. 

The overall visual design is good, especially in terms of colour and consistency, and the voice acting just adds another layer of quality. The story itself puts a bit of a twist on the caught-in-a-video-game trope and is well-worth the play, and the characters are quirky and unique enough to be interesting. What stood out in terms of writing though was the humour which was present throughout the whole of the game on many different levels, such as dialogue but also e.g. weapon descriptions. It knows its audience well. 

Of course, as a combination of two genres, the game, while scratching the surface of many gameplay features (e.g. crafting, character equipment choice), cannot reach the depth of e.g. an RPG in terms of gameplay, and, unsurprisingly, every rhythm game could do with even more songs. Still, [i] Before the Echo [/i] is a lowly priced and highly recommended hidden gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983215619', 'num_games_owned': 875, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 907, 'last_played': 1544659520}
review:
think of it like DDR with 3 mats for your hands.  WASD  UDLR  and two buttons for switching between the 3 mats, and 1,2,3,4,5,6 etc for abilities to fight

that's all the game is.

a buncha stages, with 3 battles + boss and maybe special events for that stage.

a nice repetotoire of music, that unfortunately gets reused for every stage.

depending on difficulty chosen, you can breeze through, or grind a while to level up.  i had to choose the hardest one. so i've grinding a while on each stage to get to the boss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051003049', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1109, 'last_played': 1532476987}
review:
OUTSTANDING game.

First of all, I adore indie games. I love the creativity and teamwork that comes with creating indie games, and they are my favorite genre to play and watch. I picked up this game on my queue during the Steam summer sale, but let me tell you, it's at least worth the five dollars standard price.

As an avid lover of rhythm games, I was pleasantly surprised at the complexity of each level. The difficulty increased without overwhelming the player, and the spells come in a great variety that essentially allow the player to beat the game in their own style. The art style is consistent, entirely due to the fact that every visual was created by the same artist! And it's so very sweet on the eyes.

Moving on to the characters, I have to say that while it is a rather short game (I finished all achievements in around 2-3 hours, after resetting my glitched game, a result of an error on my part) and thus we don't get to see much in terms of character depth or development, the characters' presence was enough to add quality and personality to the game without taking away the mystery and shock of the plot (I loved each of the Guardians and applaud the voice actors, as well as the artist, for providing such animated spirit). The ending leaves several questions unanswered, and if you're ambitious enough to get the hidden ending, you get a taste of even more secrets yet to be revealed.

I couldn't put this game down. It was funny, intriguing, and the artwork and music are STELLAR!

Now, to be fair, the game did have some drawbacks. I feel like the characters were a bit flat, but, if you play the game, you'll figure out why they seem to be so...scripted. It is a short game (hence the low price), but the crew that worked on it was so small! Aside from the voice actors, very few people put together a game that I will proudly call one of my all-time favorites. Iridium Studios, thank you for this masterpiece; I will cherish it for years to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980327565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1453170652}
review:
When I was a kid, I really liked DDR.  I bought this game because I thought it would be like DDR.  I am disappointed that this game is not a whole lot like DDR.

I'm having trouble separating my disappointment of this game as a scratch to my DDR itch and how I feel about the game as its own thing.

So first I have to say, if you want to buy this game because you're like me and want to scratch that itch, give it a pass.  The objective of this game is to miss a bunch of notes on purpose, which drives me absolutely insane.  Just watching arrows pass by without being pressed.

By itself?  I dunno, it's got a lot of cringey humor and some mediocre voice acting.  The RPG elements seem kind of compelling?  But also really confusing?  It just feels really unpolished, I had a lot of trouble grasping how well I was doing because the visual feedback is less than great.  I think, mechanically, this kind of step rythm game just wasn't meant to be mixed with an RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979983536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1336, 'last_played': 1465076568}
review:
Definitely an awesome game for anyone that enjoys step mania, DDR, and possibly even rhythm and music games in general.  However, if you find Step Mania or DDR challenging or frustrating, this game is likely going to be too hard for you.  It forces you to not only hit arrow keys in time with the music in the same fashion, but adds even more layers of difficulty.  There are no color codes on the arrows themselves to tell you what beat the note is on.  So you have to go purely on listening to the music, and sometimes the arrows are just on really awkward notes or tones of the song, like a series of 16th notes where only a few of them have arrows on them.  Tack on that you are watching three sets of arrows at once instead of only 1, having to swap fields of arrows to be hitting, and apply strategic thinking to when to cast spells and what to cast SIMULTANEOUSLY and you need to be so good at something like Stepmania that you don't even have to think about the arrows.  You have to be able to do them almost completely subconsciously to keep up with this game (At least at the Hard difficulty level)  If you're that good, this game will knock your socks off.  It's incredibly fun.

The only real downsides to it come from sheer lack of variety.  The game has RPG mechanics for sure, and that includes trying to collect items with a % drop rate.  Meaning if you get unlucky (And you WILL get unlucky) you may be grinding the same exact monster for half an hour.  Which means the same damn song for half an hour straight.  What is worse, each monster does not have it's own song.  Some repeat.  This can get seriously old.

For 5$, this game is awesome.  Something I've never seen before and very well put together.  And at that price, the lack of variety is understandable.  Personally, I'd love to see a sequel, and would be happy to pay four times as much if they just make sure to really crank up the variety so the game isn't such an awful feeling grind at times.  The foundations of this game are rock solid.  It just needs a few more coats of paint.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008465332', 'num_games_owned': 1252, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1132, 'last_played': 1514844678}

author: {'steamid': '76561198055479003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 931, 'last_played': 1542866611}
review: I loved every minute of playing this game. The art is beautiful, the music is great, and the gameplay is very unique. The story isn't very deep and complex, and the game gets a little grindy at the beginning of each floor, but it's definitely worth what you are paying for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964416237', 'num_games_owned': 1118, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1464188309}
review:
[b]Score ‚Äì 8/10 (Excellent)[/b]

Despite the game feeling a bit of a grind at times and the last couple of boss battles being infuriatingly difficult compared to the rest, Iridium Studios has cleverly morphed the humble rhythm game into a full-blown RPG and it surprisingly works well. Before the Echo has done for rhythm games what Puzzle Quest did for match-3 puzzle games and I like it. Before the Echo is highly recommended for lovers of rhythm games who want a bit more plot and strategy added to the mix.

http://www.choicestgames.com/2016/05/before-echo-review.html

author: {'steamid': '76561197974183287', 'num_games_owned': 929, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 1108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1108, 'last_played': 1463952867}
review:
I strongly recommend this game. This is an excellent and original blend of RPG and rhythm game. The gameplay is not just relatively unique but also very well crafted. It's interesting, engaging, and well balanced. The acting and story are also very good, not amazing but clearly above average. The art and interface are also good.

I usually don't like music games, but since I'm a big fan of RPGs and got this in a bundle, I decided to give it a try. And am I glad I did! It hooked me in so well I ended up finishing it 100% and watched all the ending credits in detail to learn more about the people who worked on this amazing game.

review:
Before the Echo ist so ziemlich genau das, was ich unter einem Indie Game verstehe. Es ist kurz, leicht zu verstehen, hat eine simple Story und das Gameplay macht Spa√ü! Es ist sogar gut genug, um mich nach einiger Zeit zu einem zweiten Durchspielen zu bewegen.
Die Archievements sind z.T. leicht und z.T. mit ein klein wenig mehr Aufwand zu erreichen. Keine Schweren, was bei einem kurzen Game auch √ºberhaupt nicht verh√§ltnism√§√üig w√§re.

Kurz und knapp: Gutes Spiel. Klare Empfehlung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013104271', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 436, 'last_played': 1578722073}
review:
Haven't finished yet, but I truly love the style, gameplay, concept, and mechanics of the game!

Imagine an RPG style "guitar hero like" rhythm game. Got you hooked yet? 

Simply put, the player switches between 3 "fields" or screens (Defence, Spell, and Mana) while in game as arrows move down in each field. 

There's a great deal of multitasking involved because of casting spells, defending yourself, and gaining mana.

You win by draining the opponent's HP to 0 by casting damaging spells, but you can lose by losing all of your health or by not winning by the end of the song. It's a great game that keeps you on your toes and equipping the right spells. 

That being said, don't feel as though there are "wrong" or "right" spells to use. Some are better for certain levels or battles, but I've been able to use the spells that fit my playstyle. 

Before the Echo is a great game for people who love RPGs but may not have all the time in the world to spend 60+ hours in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068648180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1628855383}
review:
[h1]Before the Echo[/h1] (zufor unter dem Namen: "sequence" bekannt)
Ist ein Musik RPG mit einigen neuen, und einer Menge gut verwendeten
alten Ideen. Ich empfehle es mit einem Controller zu spielen, aber es
geht auch ohne Probleme mit der Tastatur.
[b]-Musik: 9/10[/b] sehr gute St√ºcke, ein/zwei mehr w√§hren aber sch√∂n gewesen
[b]-Gameplay: 10/10[/b] die K√§mpfe sind sehr geschicklichkeits und Strategie fordernd
die Men√ºs sind klar strukturiert und verst√§ndlich
[b]-√Ñsthetik: 9/10[/b] sehr sch√∂ne Farbwahl und stimmungsvolle Hintergr√ºnde sowie
individuelle Charaktere, nur die umgef√§rbten Gegner k√∂nnten jemanden (mich nicht)
st√∂ren.
[b]Story8/10 [/b] Anfangs recht simpel(Aufwachen ohne Erinnerungen), im Ende aber sehr gelungen.
[b]Humor: 11/10[/b] Viele Gute Dialoge vorallem mit den Bossen, und wunderbare Iteam Beschreibungen.
[b]Fazit: 9/10[/b]
Einziges Problem des Spiels ist das man wenn man alle Iteams haben will oft ein wenig grinden muss,
was aber aufgrund des guten Gameplays nicht wirklich st√∂rt.
Ansonsten ein komplet empfehlenswertes Spiel, das mir sehr gef√§llt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025247656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1457789949}
review:
I played Before the Echo on Linux using a Steam Controller, and had a great time. The concept is simple, but well executed, and playing with the Steam Controller's two touchpads was perfect for such a precision game; I enjoyed not having to press buttons all the time but having the possibility to just touch the right area; so I'd recommend the config I shared to any player using a Steam Controller ;)

The music is nice and the dialogs are witty, and all that with relatively good voice acting. There are some good 12+ hours of gameplay on the normal difficulty, plus some cool bonuses and optional hidden ending for the hardcore looters.

For this price, it's definitely a good buy, even if you're not particularly interested in rhythm games in the first place (that's my case, and I still really enjoyed Before the Echo).

author: {'steamid': '76561197960313663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1115, 'last_played': 1544932182}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043891670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1245, 'last_played': 1324454400}

This game realizes incredibly well the concept of and RPG + Rhythm game. It's safe to say that if you love both genres, you're gonna enjoy this game a lot; otherwise, this might not be your thing.

It is, regardless, a great indie game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974085922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 313, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1461554580}
review: A rhythm game and an RPG had a baby.  The three screens are really complex and I could never find a control scheme that satisfied me.  The voice acting was really awful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044741891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1456680799}
review:
I can recommend this game to anyone who likes rhythm games. They did a good job at implementing RPG elements into the genre and wrapped everything up in a surprisingly decent story. You can play this with a keyboard, but I found it a bit easier to play with a controller.

So basically you "fight" yourself through a tower with seven floors and their guardians, and by fighting I mean you press directional arrows in three different windows to either defend yourself, regenerate mana or cast spells. If you're bad with coordination you might have trouble on the higher floors as switching quickly between the windows will become mandatory.

My two major gripes with the game are a lack of different soundtracks early on (luckily there will be more variety later on, and some of the soundtracks are amazing) and incredibly frustrating RNG at times. Both item drops and crafting items are based on a percentage, the latter costing experience which makes failing a little more frustrating. If you want to get everything, you WILL have to grind a bit. Other than that, I found it overall enjoyable and enticing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015071034', 'num_games_owned': 337, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 771, 'last_played': 1691720139}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998967954', 'num_games_owned': 1416, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1455689325}
review:
This game's Very Positive rating at the time of this review really boggles my mind. It's not that the game is bad, rather that its an idea who's implementation seems inherently flawed.

The base mechanic of the game is the traditional "press one or more of the 4 directions on the beat as instructed". However, the twist is that you have three panels of arrows to rotate between and timing your presses correctly on them has different effects. There's your mana regen panel where each correct press earns you a little mana to cast spells. There's another that represents spellcasting where successfully landing a series of presses will cast a spell (more on this later). The last one represents defense where a sequence of arrows represents the enemy's attack; if you miss any here you take damage.

The problem is that the defense panel's arrows (i.e. the enemy's attacks) occur at random, but you have to manually trigger your spellcast sequences. You may already see the issue here: you build mana, cast an attack spell, and arrows start to fall in the spell cast panel and defense panel simultaneously. The game's prescribed cure for this is to constantly keep up a "barrier" spell which effectively mutes the enemy. So the game requires you to continually recast this barrier spell so that you can actually cast the spells you want in between each barrier cast. In my opinion this is a kludge of a game mechanic. You get involved with a whole lot of busy work just to occasionally do something meaningful. Perhaps it all gets a bit smoother with some practice, but whats to engage you enough to want to get that good?

I found a majority of the music to be ignorable at best. I've enjoyed some of Ronald Jenkees' music, but what's offered here I'd be reluctant to classify as even B-side music. The dialog is atrocious, the story is insignificant, and the graphics are the kind of crappy animatics that have now become standard fair in a sea of indie game dev mediocrity. The game would be perfectly suited for two hands on the keyboard, but I was forced into using a controller. (Oh I hope this wasn't just because I had a controller plugged into my PC; I'm not going back!)

Perhaps worst yet is that the game devolves into a grind as each enemy you face has the chance to drop (at most?) one of three items of increasingly rarer chances to drop. You can face an enemy multiple times (enjoying the same music each time!) to get all items from an enemy. Why? Did the game need a time sink like this? Again, its more poor game design that not only contributes nothing fun, but actually contributes frustration.

I really wanted to like this game. I had it on my wishlist as soon as it was released and bought it while it was still named Sequence. Despite the game's somewhat novel concept, it seems like the developer tried to throw a hodge-podge of ideas and twists at the rhythm genre, but just ended up with an overly-complicated and unfun mess.

Unless you're some kind of rhythm game fanatic, skip this one. 6/10

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198011595325', 'num_games_owned': 2468, 'num_reviews': 928, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1454032415}
review:
"Jogo r√≠tmico com elementos de rpg e sistema de craft" Isso √© tudo? Bem, isso √© a parte interessante, mas dai vem os defeitos: o jogo √© muito repetitivo, os elementos de rpg s√£o muito simples e o sistema de craft possuem uma chance de erro que parece servir para segurar o jogador mais tempo. As atua√ß√µes vocais s√£o boas tamb√©m, mas o jogo que muitas poucas musicas que se repetem infinitamente. Before the Echo √© um jogo solido, mas abusa ou usa mal seus elementos, acabando por se tornar um jogo repetitivo e sem brilho.
-------------------------
"Rhythmic game with RPG elements and craft system" That's all? Well, that's the interesting part, but now comes defects: the game is very repetitive, the RPG elements are very simple and the craft system have a chance of error that seems to serve to hold the player for longer. The voice performances are good too, but the game was very few songs that are repeated endlessly. Before the Echo is a solid game, but abuses or misuses its elements, eventually becoming a repetitive and dull game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077170206', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1057, 'last_played': 1477614814}
review:
Okay, first thing, this game NEEDS a controller. If you try to play with keyboard controls you will die. You will despise the game and probably end up putting a magazine or two through your monitor.

If you have a controller: HOLY BALLS THIS IS AMAZING. It's literally DDR with RPG aspects and an amazing story. Plus the soundtrack ALONE (Ronald Jenkees, I freaking love you) is worth at least $20. I would actually not even be mad if my save got deleted. Don't care, I'll beat it again. And again.

10/10 will play forever.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972584572', 'num_games_owned': 1628, 'num_reviews': 384, 'playtime_forever': 882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 882, 'last_played': 1456125778}
review:
Beaten - 15 hours

Before the Echo (or Sequence as it was formally called) is essentially a dance dance revolution/stepmania RPG.   

Mechanics:
- In battle, you can switch between three "dance" screens (where you match the sequences given like in DDR). Each screen is useful for one of three things: Mana, Attack, or Defense. So in order to prevent damage to you, you match the sequence on the defense screen.  You also collect items and abilities that you can use during battle.

Another interestign mechanic is the game provides you "recipies" on each floor. In order to get the items needed to make something, you have to defeat an enemy. Then, to actually craft it, you get a 50% chance of success. To make it greater, you can sacrific XP 9and potentially level).  

Pros:
- Mechanics are fun
- Music is catchy (although can get redundant)
- Cool crafting system (although not terribly deep)
- You can level up above the necessary requirments if you feel like it to make it easier.

Cons
- Can get grindy

author: {'steamid': '76561198061402089', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 722, 'last_played': 1453606812}
review: Before the Echo is a unique, one-of-a-kind sort of game that has both the elements of a rhythm game and RPG. Maybe unique isn't always a good thing, but this game definitely nailed it with its unique concept and amazing gameplay. If you like rhythm games like me, then you will most likely enjoy Before the Echo just as I did. It has a set of amazing soundtracks,  great gameplay, very interesting characters and a clever story premise. If I have any complaint, it'd probably be the grinding you have to do to craft the recipe items, but even so it wasn't that bad and hey, what's an RPG without a little a grinding am I right? I'm definitely recommending this amazing game, 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198045044409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1451464160}
review:
Had this game recommended to me as a good music game hybrid, and was pleasantly surprised.  I'm not usually an RPG fan, but this game is enjoyable so far and there's no question that I'll see it through to the end.

As a long-time DDR/stepmania player, I stepped quite easily into hard mode.  The charts themselves are still pretty easy for me, and I can easily get 100% while unlocking spells.  However, during regular gameplay, coordinating switching between panes with hitting notes is a new and interesting challenge.

The biggest downside so far is the lack of content.  The soundtrack, while well-made, is extremely limited, and you'll end up hearing the same handful of songs over and over (so far maybe a half dozen songs in the first 4/7 floors of the tower, compared to dozens/hundreds in your average true rhythm game).  That coupled with the fact that I'm better than halfway through the game in under 4 hours suggests that this game won't have replay value.

Other thoughts:
- The art is somewhat low-res (720p?) and you can't change resolutions.  You can choose full screen or windowed though.  Not something I notice during gameplay, but nowadays I'd expect full HD (or preferably vector) art.
- So far I've only gotten one defensive spell and it's not that powerful.  There's a huge emphasis on attack-heavily-and-occasionally-heal with not much in the way of actually defending.  Some battles you can coast through without using the defense pane much at all, so it's not equally balanced throughout.
- A lot of the items/spells seem ignorable in general, unless you're a compulsive completionist like I am.
- Each floor of the tower has 3 different enemy battles (each with 3 different item drops), plus a boss battle.
- It's interesting that the item drop probabilities are shown, that way you can quantify how bad your luck is when grinding.  Sure, I got the 35% item in 3 of my last 4 battles, but I only got one of the 85% item that I need three of.  Haha.
- The boss battles don't seem to be replayable, but they do unlock new songs when you complete them that will be used in the higher levels of battle.
- Most people complaining about the name change (from "Sequence") have no idea how trademark law works, or why companies are obligated to protect their trademarks.

Overall, this game is well worth that 99c sale price, but it seems like something I'll play through once and then forget about.  I absolutely love the concept, but it needs more content for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014197773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1451450487}

The game itself is great, with a great mechanic and rather unique. I like the art style and also the RPG essence. I do like this game, and I bought it at such a discounted price. Love it.

I was wrong.

I got addicted the moment I started playing, literally. I started with hard difficulty, and I enjoy it so much.

I r8 this game a perfect 5/7.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040721865', 'num_games_owned': 946, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1455927290}
review: Great sound track, beautiful artwork, interesting story and a really clever gameplay concept. Can't recommend this enough. My only issue is that the artwork seems to have been designed for a lower resolution (1366x720?) than what I usually see these days, still the overall quality makes it easy enough to see past that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126241299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 2814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1143, 'last_played': 1657978296}
review:
This is a great great great game. If you're into rythm games, go and grab it. The battle interface is great, the controls are flawless, and there are difficulty levels to keep you busy for a reasonable amount of time.

If you're into RPGs, however, be wary that this game is not really an RPG. It's much more of a visual novel, with no control of what your character does or where it goes, no side quests, no character customization either at the start or during the gameplay. Also, the synthesis system is a bit grindy, but you eventually acquire items that drastically improve drop rates.

Finally, most of the supporting characters are well written and the plot is interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961889769', 'num_games_owned': 504, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1441, 'last_played': 1403874027}
review: Fun story with a rhythm game twist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073454499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1453358976}
review:
[h1]The RPG where grinding is fun![/h1]
[b]If you are a fan of RPGs and rhythm games I highly recommend Before the Echo.[/b]

I've completed the first of seven levels and my impressions so far are positive.  The first thing the player is treated to is the banter between the protaganist and his unseen guide.  The voice acting is good and the dialogue is consistently amusing with the occasional chuckle-worthy highlight.

At each level the player is encouraged to create objects from recipes but the raw materials for each recipe are only acquired by defeating enemies.  The basic enemies drop one, two, or three different materials based on individual percentages so a specific drop is never guaranteed.  This requires the grind for which RPGs are famous.  The objects created from these recipes aren't required to progress in the game but because battles are resolved in fun rhythm challenges ala Dance Dance Revolution, why not obtain the materials to create the objects and try them out?

I was pleasantly surprised that the first boss I encountered was an Internet meme and my interest is only piqued to see what subsequent levels will bring.

You know you.  If resolving RPG combat by playing a rhythm game doesn't sound like fun to you, then take a pass on Before the Echo.  Otherwise, take a chance on it and you will likely be glad you did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019159937', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2440, 'last_played': 1434067338}
review: Take DDR, RPG elements, Great storyline and a sweet techno/electronic soundtrack and you have Before the Echo. Originally titled 'Sequence' (changed due to C&D I think?) this game is amazing. The art? Breathtaking. The music? Absolutely unique and charming. The play style? One of a kind. If you enjoy any derivitive of DDR or FFR, please try this game out!

review:
Nice little music game.  Simple yet entertaining narative, and the game play can get intense at times.  There is also little easter eggs hidden in this game that give it that bit of a jump ahead from games that kind of just keep you on a linear path.

For such a low budget they did a great job with the game, and the music is really nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125830895', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 588, 'last_played': 1466044341}
review:
This game's a hard one for me to explain- part RPG, part stepmania, all rolled up in an aesthetically pleasing pun fest (I LOVE PUNS) with a great (albeit kinda limited) soundtrack. I can't get enough!

It's got nice voice acting, it's a bit of a grind fest if you want to craft and unlock spells (Both grinding and crafting are my kind of thing so these are positives for me), and it's got a neat mechanic of paying XP for items instead of currency! And the pi√®ce de r√©sistance of this game for me is the 3 arena style, where you have three fields of events going at once. One controls your spellsets, one is for defence, and the last one is for your mana pool. Missing an arrow in all but the mana field might cost you dearly! Switching between them is crazy fun, and timing is crucial if you want to chain events up.

All in all, beautiful game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017706666', 'num_games_owned': 1226, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1448780602}
review:
[h1]A Paladin‚Äôs Review: Before The Echo. Rhythm and RPG Genre Mixing Goodness.[/h1]
[list]
[*]Genre: Rhythm RPG Indie Title
[*]Developed & Published by: Iridium Studios
[*]Platform: Windows, Mac and Linux.
[*]Business Model: Cheap Base Game.
[*][i]Copy Purchased by Myself[/i] 
[/list]
[i][url=http://kingisaaclinksr.com/2015/11/29/a-paladins-review-before-the-echo-rhythm-and-rpg-genre-mixing-goodness/]Read the full & unabridged review A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/i]

[b]Preamble[/b]
Originally titled [i]Sequence[/i], [i]Before the Echo[/i] is the first game released by the indie devs Iridium Studios. It was later followed by [i]There Came An Echo[/i], a real time tactics voice controlled game released on Steam in early 2015. According to Before the Echo‚Äôs Steam Forums, they had a copyright claim thrown against them by another developer over their name. So, Iridium Studios had to rename Sequence to something else in order to avoid legal trouble. A rather unfortunate turn of events. However, I will say that Before the Echo might have been a better choice anyway, as Sequence isn‚Äôt particularly memorable for a name. I myself only discovered Before the Echo when There Came An Echo was released and got a lot of press attention for its unique voice control mechanics. BtE has some interesting ideas of its own though and I don‚Äôt think it should be ignored.

[b]Overall Gameplay Thoughts[/b]
A rhythm-based-combat RPG with a story driven narrative has a decent amount of content, especially if you decide to go for as many recipes as possible. The rhythm mechanics are a refreshing change of pace from the normal choose-spells, counter as best you can and win over and over again. It forces you to pay attention to what you‚Äôre doing and continually improve as the game goes along. This is even after my initial skepticism that this game had few legs to stand on. After all, we‚Äôve had plenty of rhythm games before. What could possibly make BtE stand out? Well, a good story with an amusing banter between the two protagonists and a decently diverse set of characters to fight out against with their own particular personality doesn‚Äôt hurt. Neither does a refined rhythm system that requires you to pay attention and react quickly to three different fields of falling arrows.

[b]Story Thoughts[/b]
The player is following the story of Ky, a hacker who finds himself waking up in a mysterious tower called, well, the Tower. This seven leveled tower isn‚Äôt something to scoff as he‚Äôll soon learn that he can die in this tower. Upon awaking and talking to himself about what‚Äôs going on, he‚Äôs greeted by Naia, a ‚Äúshepherd‚Äù that has few answers for Kai but seems to be on his side or at the very least trapped by her own circumstances. She‚Äôll help him out by guiding him through the tutorial and each level. Ky must do this, defeating monsters to grow in strength to eventually defeat the seven guardians that stop forward progress. The plot has lies and half truths a plenty. Not everyone is telling the truth and there‚Äôs something sinister going on in the background. It seems to be set in the modern era though no country or actual year is dropped. The characters do seem to imply this is all happening in the 2010s.

[b]Combat Thoughts[/b]
In Before the Echo‚Äôs battles, you defeat monsters and bosses by following the beat of the music and destroying the enemy‚Äôs health before they do yours in. This is accomplished in a dance-dance-revolution type battle where you‚Äôre trying to cast spells, block their attacks and regenerate your mana when possible. To do this, you‚Äôll need to press the right direction on the d-pad and letter keys of your controller when arrows are at the right time. You‚Äôll often need to use both set of controls in order to handle all the arrows falling. Keyboard and mouse can also be used but I find the controller to be a little bit more enjoyable and easier to use for this game. To further complicate things, you‚Äôll need to select and cast spells using the controller‚Äôs joystick while keeping an eye on arrows. This can be a little tricky to figure out at first but I eventually got used to it.

[b]PC Settings[/b]
Settings are a little bizarre here. Fullscreen on/off is the only traditional video setting to be found. Particle effects can be turned off, there‚Äôs a lag calibration for your controller, gem and text speed can be changed and a lot of other different functions important to the rhythm mechanics. Resolution options, AA, V-sync and other settings are missing as well. The one game I actually desire individual sound volume options doesn‚Äôt have them at all. I found the SFX was just a bit too loud over the music and people speaking but not unbearably high. For such an audio-intensive game, being able to adjust the different volumes seems like an obvious thing to include in your game. Voice acting can be turned off but I don‚Äôt know why you‚Äôd want to do that. It‚Äôs pretty good voice acting. I was surprised to hear the voice actor for Dust from Dust: An Elysian Tail in this title too. He plays one of the guardians.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
Before the Echo is a good and different experience that‚Äôs both decently approachable but difficult to master. The combination of RPG and Rhythm mechanics just works here, the mechanics blending well together and never allowing things to get dull for long. Though there are fights that can be overly frustrating. It‚Äôs also not too hard to lose concentration and find yourself in an unwinnable situation. So, you‚Äôll need to stay on your toes or take a break if it‚Äôs happening too often. The story itself is pretty good, I found myself chuckling at the banter between the two protagonists from time to time. It does lean a bit too much on tropes but I think it does them well enough that I‚Äôm not bothered by it. It‚Äôs a good time ‚Äúdancing‚Äù to the beats while playing a more traditional RPG game. I definitely liked this mix of genres and I recommend checking out when you have the chance.

[h1][url=http://kingisaaclinksr.com/2016/02/26/a-paladins-review-there-came-an-echo-an-imperfect-but-enjoyable-attempt-at-pushing-barriers/]A Paladin's Review: There Came An Echo.[/url][/h1]
[h1][url=http://kingisaaclinksr.com/2015/11/29/a-paladins-review-before-the-echo-rhythm-and-rpg-genre-mixing-goodness/]Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198041041379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1448888747}
review:
SHORT VERSION | The game is pretty great.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

LONG   VERSION | 

Pros:

+ Characters are quirky, almost too much so, but I love each and every one of them.
+ Game is challenging enough on preferred dificulty; with good balance between complexity and simplicity.
+ The Humour is sometimes cringey, but for the most part its good for a giggle or two.
+ The art style is consistent, it may not be for you but it does maintain aesthetic consistency.

Cons:

- Quite grindy at later stages.
- Hearing the same song for the same enemy can get repetive very quickly when doing said grinding.
- UI is console driven, and can be clunky at times for PC and keyboard.
- Limited options if you're not ok with that sort of thing.

The experience has been overall positive with this game, if you're not terribly into rythmn games or RPGs then one of the two genres might drag you through this game with some minor gripes, but for the most part even if you're not terribly into either it is worth it for the characters and the story.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198032120166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1393208647}
review:
Repetitive, boring, reptetitive. Wants to be a fun rhythm game, fails horrifically. What should be fun, just becomes a grind. Maybe you'll enjoy it if you're a hard core rhythm gamer, but for the everyone else it's not even worth the effort. 

Thankfully I didn't pay full price and got it with a steep discount so it wasn't too much of a waste.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047002594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1482530042}
review:
So I heard you like music, rpg, good humor and have fast fingers? This game is for you then. I'm not sure how I got to this game at first - btw it was called Sequence, but they had to rename it. I think I got to this game trought some sale ticked from crafting badges on steam and I'm very happy that I bought it.

I have never seen a game like this - it combines a lot of elements that I love. 

It's fun, but it can make you rage ofcourse too, cause some music fights are real hard - atleast for me. Game has it's real own real nice athmosphere.

[h1]Pros and cons:[/h1]

+ mix of game features
+ graphics
+ story
+ humor
+ music
+ bis emoticons on Steam

- missing volume settings(or at least I can't seem to find one anywhere and the in-game music/sound is higher than my normal and I don't like editting my volume everytime I play it)
- most of the time u are pressing arrows in the fight - even tho u need additional keys for switching between attack/defense/mana and for spells, it would be cool if you could use dancepad for playing this game

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

If you are a person who loves good games you should give Before the Echo a try for sure. It's worth it even without any sale <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198021500857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2457, 'last_played': 1465201708}
review: Before the Echo (previously SEQUENCE) is an RPG with rhythm game elements. It has all the features you look for in an RPG - decent music, story, gameplay mechanics, etc. It's also reasonably priced, and is definitely worth the buy. It /is/ a short game, however - speedruns can be done in just under 2 hours. Still worth it, and is fun to replay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037520882', 'num_games_owned': 695, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1444970150}
review:
It's and interesting game with a blend of genres. I used to play a lot of DDR and Stepmania on PC when I was younger and I was really hoping this would scratch that itch for me. Alas, although I really liked the humor, this falls really flat for me. I expect better responses and controls from a rhythm game and this did not have either. I hated having to switch between different windows to cast spells and regain mana. It completely took me away from the song. There is way to much grind on the stages for my taste, too. Give me more monsters to fight, not the same few to fight over and over on each floor. I think I had too high expectations for this game but for me it is a no go. I can't recommend this coming from a DDR snob like me. 

4/10 Fun for some, but not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018302427', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1444945677}
review:
It's DDR the grinding RPG.
I did stage one (of seven), and I was pushing myself to do that.
I gave up, it's not going to get much better than that.
Fight using DDR style interface, get experiance and  rare drops, use these to craft a key for the next stage.
Rince repeat (with more difficulty).

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198062018383', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1506478012}
review:
I'm conflcted in reviewing this game, because I both enjoy it and resent some of its features.

First, the good points:
+ Nice music
+ Fun gameplay, has a nice flow to it
+ Love the variety of spells and possibilities for spell combos
+ The narrative is neat and has entertaining humor and characters
+ Pretty artwork, and solid-looking characters


Now the not-so-good:
- Not much song variety. New levels and challenges for unlocking spells tend to recycle songs from previous levels.
- Item crafting is done by sacrificing some exp. This in itself isnt horrible, but when paired with the tiny song selection, repeating the same fights over and over again to craft your armor and weapons and keys to unlock the next level all while trying to maintain a level that allows you to continue playing comfortably becomes tedious.
- In short, grinding becomes pretty much mandatory.
- Not much selection in craftable weapons and armor. Each level supplies you with crafting recipes for one armor and weapon item at its beginning. Additional items can sometimes be dropped by enemies, but I have rarely found these helpful. When I saw the crafting screens in the trailer, I was hoping there would be more variety in items for the player; a build with a ton of attack and no defense, or a ton of mana but not much health would be interesting challenges to make repeating songs less tedious.

Additionally, controllers are supported by the game, but only 360 controllers as of right now. I used the program ds4windows to make my ps4 controller compatible with it (running on Win8.1), and I have seen others find supporting programs for different controllers. Using a controller makes for comfortable gameplay.


Overall, I'm not sure I whether I would recommend this game. The core concept is interesting and the spells are fun. Playing the faster-paced songs is a blast. However, the game suffers from a tiny playlist which turns some floors into drudgery and "this track again?" rather than keeping it a fun, fresh experience. On sale or in a bundle, I suppose it is worth it, though, as this game definitely has its strong points.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129034138', 'num_games_owned': 1119, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1443529852}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002958420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1385, 'last_played': 1633919438}
review:

The only problem I have with it is that the songs get repititious after a while. I would have like to see more songs applied to this playstyle. Ultimately that's only asking for more of what this game offers though, so I really can't complain.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088855855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1441258511}
review:
I absolutely loved this! I loved the music which never got boring and tiresome when I was grinding for those rare items. I never had an issue with the crafting, I thought it was pretty inventive becasue it gets the player to make decisions on the items they absolutely need and then to be prepared for the crafting. I thought that the battle system was INSANE! The amount of thought and timing that goes into each battle is awesome. 
Now, my few issues were that A. It was too short and B. Some of the drop rates were a little too out there to benefit from. I mean sure there is THAT item, but it wasn't worth it and it was too much of a spike at the point when I got it (just before the final boss fight for the 6th time because SO ANNOYING)
All in all 9/10, you guys did AMAZING
