author: {'steamid': '76561198018580644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1444046589}
review:
Extremely well crafted game. Love the beat/music dance-pad like game mechanic mixed with RPG elements led by a young college-kid protagonist and female narrator who don't take the game to seriously. The voice acting sounds great (the aforementioned two are supposed to be 24 years olds in the game), and I like the way they portray the characters' idiosyncrasies. The humor is amusing. 

Works great with a 360 controller. 60 fps and decent 1080p screen scaling to boot!

I'm 1/7th through the game and I would definitely recommend this to people who don't mind feeling a little pressure as they swich frantically between Mana, Spell casting, and defensive panels, each of which the player must deal with in DDR 4-way-arrow dance-style gameplay. 

Recommended. I give it a 4/5.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980506581', 'num_games_owned': 463, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 888, 'last_played': 1441653650}
review:
The Rhythm Action RPG I've Always Needed

I expected to find exemplary RPG gameplay on top of a familiar Bemani style of gaming.  What I didn't expect was that I'd be thrown into an awesome story with amazing voice acting, scripting, and art.  This far exceeds the bottom-line definition of "DDR RPG."

author: {'steamid': '76561198009334801', 'num_games_owned': 988, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1441476211}
review:
Before the Echo (fu Sequence) √® un gioco molto particolare che mescola rhythm game a rpg. L'esperienza mi insegna che mischiare rhythm game a qualsiasi altro genere pu√≤ potenzialmente portare a un disastro (tipo quel gioco che lo faceva con gli shootemup), ma fortunatamente non √® questo il caso, e anzi il risultato √® molto interessante.

Noi siamo Ky, un ragazzo che si risveglia misteriosamente all'interno di una strana torre di 7 piani, ricolma di mostri. Guidato tramite interfono da Naia, Ky deve superare ogni piano della torre, presieduti da immancabili ed eccentrici "guardiani", per scoprire dove diavolo √® finito esattamente e perch√©. 

E per fare questo, dovr√† affrontare le sue battaglie.. a colpi di ritmo. Proprio cos√¨, ogni scontro con i mostri si svolge durante un intero brano, su tre tabelle alternabili a piacimento: una rossa che rappresenta i danni nemici, una verde per i nostri attacchi/incantesimi e una blu per il mana. Azzeccando le frecce che scendono a tempo con la canzone si pu√≤ quindi parare i danni nemici, attaccare con potenti magie o ripristinare il mana, chiaramente in base alla tabella in cui siamo. Per cui, durante le battaglie √® necessaria un'alta concentrazione e la capacit√† di cambiare al volo tra una tabella e l'altra, azzeccando note su note per sconfiggere il nemico prima che la canzone finisca (o prima di morire). 

√à un sistema molto particolare ma che funziona egregiamente, e per venire incontro a tutti ci sono 4 livelli di difficolt√† (non pi√π modificabili dopo il 3¬∞ piano), dal pi√π basso con meno note a quello pi√π alto per fanatici di rhythm game e praticamente impossibile per le persone normali. E, cosa che ho apprezzato, non c'√® nessuno sbloccabile basato sulla difficolt√†, neppure achievement, perci√≤ chiunque pu√≤ ottenere tutto giocando alla difficolt√† che preferisce. 

Il punto forse pi√π debole di questo gioco per√≤ sta proprio nel gameplay. A ogni nuovo piano raggiunto, Ky ottiene da Naia una serie di ricette di equip, magie, altri oggetti e ovviamente la chiave per il piano successivo. Per ottenere gli oggetti necessari a fabbricare il tutto, sar√† quindi necessario sconfiggere i 3 mostri di ogni piano, ognuno con le sue percentuali di drop. E di fatto il gioco... √® tutto qui, farmare ancora e ancora gli stessi mostri reskinnati finch√© non si hanno gli oggetti per craftare tutto (a proposito, ogni craft e acquisizione di magie costa exp, e se si fallisce √® andata sprecata per niente), e chiaramente per salire pure di livello e avere una chance contro i guardiani e i mostri successivi. Non √® troppo diverso dal normale farming sfrenato in ogni rpg, ma qui essendoci da fare praticamente solo quello potrebbe risultare un po' noioso sul lungo periodo. 

Di livello molto pi√π alto invece il resto della produzione, dalle ottime canzoni techno delle battaglie all'eccelso script e doppiaggio (solo inglese, come i sottotitoli), senza dimenticare la buona caratterizzazione di ogni personaggio, specialmente i guardiani di ogni piano. La grafica invece √® bidimensionale a schermate fisse, ma comunque ben disegnata, specialmente i personaggi. 
Anche la trama, che rimanda un po' a qualche anime giapponese, si dipana bene e incuriosisce fino alla fine (e c'√® anche un finale segreto con qualche informazione in pi√π), che sopraggiunge dopo una dozzina di ore. E i credits sono tra i migliori che abbia mai visto. 

Perci√≤ nel complesso promosso ma non a pieni voti, pi√π che altro per il fatto che qualcuno potrebbe trovare un po' monotono il farming forzato e costante, e che le canzoni su cui si combatte siano in fondo sempre le stesse. Ma essendo una produzione indipendente fatta da una manciata di persone (il doppiatore di Ky √® lo stesso che ha fatto il 90% del resto) e con un gameplay originale che in fondo funziona, non si poteva obiettivamente chiedere troppo di pi√π.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030691885', 'num_games_owned': 2037, 'num_reviews': 651, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1439158840}
review:
Before the Echo is like this weird Rhythm game and rpg rolled into one. You play the game by matching Arrows in three different fields. Defense blocks attacks, There's an attack field where you need to hit all the arrows to cast spells. Then there is the mana pool where you replenish your mana for more spells. The thing is you queue your spells up on your own. So you have to either take a few hits while you get a spell off on the enemy or maybe you'll find that gap in the enemy's attack pattern. Besides that the game has a ton of other rpg elements like monster drops, item synthesis, equipment, learning new spells and more. 

I also enjoy the voice acting and all the snarky sarasm that goes on between the guy you play and Naia the girl over the intercom. I was really laughing at the first boss encounter poor old percival was offended by my words. Then again he was asking for it.

I say pick this up if you like rhythm games and want a splash of rpg stuff to go with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969331425', 'num_games_owned': 1305, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1438547236}
review: Fun and interesting concept. The story is kind of weak... I mean if I woke up in a tower and some girl told me that I had to fight my way to the top and could die at any moment I'd probably be a little bit more questioning but it serves its purpose. The music is absolutely terrible but what can you expect from an indie game... I guess the only real complaint I'd have about it is that all of the songs are so similar that it kind of sounds like you're listening to the same song over and over again. It gets annoying. I can play about 1 floor a week.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976740032', 'num_games_owned': 1631, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1437864820}
review:
Before the Echo, once called Sequence, is a fun and short rhythm fighting/dancing role-playing game. My game time represents how long it took for me to beat the game and it ended just at the right time. The pacing of the game and story go well together. There was a short grind near the end of the game, but it was good practice and leveling for the last few bosses which are quite a challenge.

I bought the game on sale so add this to your wishlist if you think the price is too much currently. Regardless, make sure you don't miss out playing this title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098069106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1421, 'last_played': 1614873497}
review:
[h1]Triple screen DDR RPG[/h1]
DDR = Dance Dance Revolution game where you press arrow sequences in time to the music
This game adds 3 different screens of arrows to make it more brain-meltingly hard. Initially it seems impossible but becomes a lot easier with practice. 
You earn XP with each victory which you can use to craft items and new spells but the probability of crafting success is never 100% guaranteed.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
+ Multiple difficulty levels, Normal difficulty is actually challenging and gradually pushed my (limited) DDR skills to the limit. Improving your DDR skills requires practice and is rewarding.
+ Rocking battle music by Ronald Jenkees
+ Floor 3 boss made me lol
+ Full voice acting 
+ Just plain fun, more fun than a whole bunch of AAA games that I have played and gotten bored of.

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- Limited variety of battle songs. They get reused multiple times.
- Ending was unpredictable but I personally found the explanation unsatisfying. Hidden ending unlock was very challenging and equally unsatisfying, explaining nothing. 
- Hardly ever needed to use defensive spells on Normal difficulty
- Impatient players may find this game too grindy and/or challenging

If you have any interest in DDR games, this one comes highly recommended.
8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198030201030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1548277752}
review: This game has all the elements of Flash Flash Revolution but is 100 times more fun. While FFR was fun for a while unlocking new songs, this game has several RPG elements and a great storyline. For starters, you dont play on just one field, you play on 3, thats right 3 at once. I'm only good enough to comeplete the game on hard, but there is one difficulty past that but its insane. All in all, this game is amazing if you love FFR and DDR style games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066768915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1437612382}
review:
This is a bit of a mixed review. The battle system is pretty interesting with the switching between screens and thinking up the best strategies to beat the enemies. I also have fun with the crafting system (but it does make the game grind-y; I find grinding rewarding so I enjoy it, but if you have little patience for that sort of thing, trying to gather all the materials and experience points to craft stuff might get on your nerves). Overall I've spent a lot of hours entertained by the game and am invested enough to want to get all achievements, craft all items, etc. So for the price I think the experience is really worth it (and I even got it on sale).

That said - I expected an RPG with a rhythm game gimmick, and got a rhythm game with an RPG gimmick instead... the rhythm game battling is like 90% of the game. But it's not quite strong on its own to be what I'd call an "amazing" rhythm game... the music is a bit bland and sounds more like a nice BGM than something to actively enjoy. I also appreciate sleek visuals/designs in rhythm/music games but the battle screen looks pretty basic. This would've all been 100% fine if there was just more besides the battles to the game... like if you could actually move through a map and  meet the monsters in random encounters or something, in a more RPG-y way. Or if the story and characters were more unique and there were more and better written narration and dialogue, in a visual novel-y way. The characters are pretty basic and the dialogue is cringey at times (trying a bit too hard to be witty/funny to be taken seriously, kinda generic, uncomfortable moments like one point where the r-slur is used). Basically I feel like the game is fun but falls short of being Great. Better visuals/music, more varied gameplay, better story/writing - if it had any one of those 3 things, I think it might've been enough. I wouldn't even demand to have all three at once. But as it is, it feels like it falls short of its potential. I think the core idea of integrating rhythm games with RPG in a battle system is really great and that the game could've been better.

But like I said, since it's cheap, I do think it's worth its price. So if you enjoy rhythm games you might as well get it because it'll probably provide quite a few hours of fun. If you don't like rhythm games, I'd just say you won't be missing out on much if you pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037155046', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1117, 'last_played': 1597020437}
review:
After I listened to Ronald Jenkees' last single "Try the Bass" (Hello Youtubes!) I found out that his popular songs where in the game "Before the Echo" (ex Sequence), so I decided to try a rhythmic game for once. No regrets.
Totally recommended for music fans even though it has its flaws: a few songs and repetitive gameplay. If you can pass that, you will be immersed in an interesting story, nice voice acting, a small RPG-esque game and challenging steam achievements.

Note: there was a time when I closed my eyes and I kept seeing arrows flowing down... Yeah, that kind of effect it had on me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985549518', 'num_games_owned': 267, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1436552495}
review: Great game! Really difficult, quite a lot bang for your buck. If you enjoy rhythm games, this one will keep you up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042822312', 'num_games_owned': 494, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1436886091}
{'steamid': '76561197993588835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1436412462}
review:
If you like rhythmically tapping buttons and can tolerate cringe-worthy voice acting and writing, you'll enjoy this game. The story is more elaborate than you would expect for a $5 rhythm-based RPG. But being elaborate doesn't make it good. The gameplay is the highlight of this game and it certainly impresses. This game transforms Stepmania the way that Puzzle Quest transformed Bejeweled. 

I definitely recommend buying it, even at full price. Unless you're completely terrible at rhythm games, in which case you might find it frustrating, although it isn't particularly hard on the standard difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030660219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1434915904}
review:
I loved rhythm games and RPGs while growing up. I tried twice, a couple years apart, but this game just couldn't hold my interest.

It's not fun to grind. It's especially not fun when it means playing the same song over and over, with nothing new happening. Most of the non-gameplay actions you can take require wagering experience points -- academically, the mechanic is really interesting...but gameplay-wise, it's just frustrating to spend massive amounts of experience points on this.

The characters, at least through as much of the game as I saw, were just cringey. It's like Twilight for boys -- a totally non-special guy randomly ends up in a magical world where a woman with a sexy voice flirts with him. I'm looking for something a little more interesting than sarcasm. I don't need an elitist lesson in how everyone but the dev pronounces "mana" wrong -- I'm sure there's an audience that resonates with, but it isn't me.

The actual gameplay is not terrible, and involves rotating through 3 DDR-style tracks -- one to defend, one to regenerate mana, and one to cast spells. Again, it's academically interesting, but gameplay-wise, it's just kind of infuriating to constantly be shown the opportunity cost of the choosing the track you're currently on.

So maybe that's my gripe -- the game always made me feel like I wasn't doing what I should be doing. The game wants me to take risks with my EXP wagering and to not care about the other tracks during gameplay, but my personality doesn't let me switch into that mode. My personality isn't changing, the game isn't changing, and we're just not a match. If you're not like me, this might be the game for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048750012', 'num_games_owned': 3160, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1436133627}
review:
[b]Good rhythm strategy music game.
7.5 / 10[/b]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[olist]
[*]Good music tracks.
[*]Good writing.
[*]Good voice acting.
[*]Spell setups and strategies are interesting.
[*]Highest difficulty is a decent challenge. [i](I recommend you play on Hard if you're even remotely familiar with the genre, as Medium is too easy.)[/i]
[*]21 Achievements.
[*]Steam card drops.
[*]Supports WASD + Arrows in combination.
[*]Key remapping.
[*]Decent art, though some enemies are simple recolors. [i](It's okay when it matches their [b]spectrum[/b] stat)[/i]
[*]Smooth performance at all times.
[*]Fair game length. It took me ~10 hours to get all achievements.
[*]Option to play the tracks outside of battles, once unlocked.
[*]Crafting / Equipment / XP system is good and balanced.
[*]Hit detection is really good, even immediately after rotating fields.
[*]I got it for 99 cents.
[/olist]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[olist]
[*]Some item drop rates will have you fighting the same enemies 10-25 times.
[*]Some music tracks are reused for other enemies.
[*]The game could use more tracks.
[*]I [b]really[/b] wish there were more achievements to bring in more replayability. Such as getting 100% on each track while playing in "Bonus" on the highest difficulty and beating the game on the highest difficulty. Currently you can get all achievements on any difficulty.
[*]No option to change difficulty on the main menu or in "Bonus" mode. You must enter the main game, then back out.
[/olist]

review:

If you don't have and do not want to install Windows Media Player [b]do not buy this game[/b], however good it might be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984591011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1435913291}
review: The Puzzle Quest of DDR/Stepmania. A combination that surprisingly works. All with great voice acting and a decent story tying it all together. The soundtrack is also great, but it would greatly benefit from more tracks. The concept of dealing with three sets at once seems daunting, but once you play it, everything just clicks and every battle is a series of rhythmic keystrokes. I grabbed it on sale for $1 and I can't argue with the value. As a fan of DDR and RPG's it was certainly worth a shot and I'm not disappointed. Played it to completion in 2 days. It does get a little grindy if you're trying to 100% the game and it does get pretty difficult (especially if you're not accustomed to the genre), but it's certainly worth a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077175107', 'num_games_owned': 876, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1527194009}

author: {'steamid': '76561198055814197', 'num_games_owned': 754, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 782, 'last_played': 1435789024}
review:
[b]TL;DR[/b] --> It costs less than an euro during sales, and it doesn't mean it's a bad game. It's a sign to purchase it as a duty.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------


If you're reading this, congratulations! You have a good taste in videogames.

As a hardcore rhythm game player, Before the Echo caught my attention soon enough but honestly I didn't know what to expect. The conclusion after beating everything is a fully recommendation of the game.

Before the Echo (also known as Sequence) is a rhythm game with RPG elements. The basic stuff  in summary (HP, Mana, EXP, weapons, accesories...). The main character, Ky, has somehow placed himself into a tower where he needs to fight mobs and bosses in order to escape.

The battle system consists in getting control of 3 labels of notes. They have different purposes and you need to know when to focus into one or another. I won't explain their features here since the game has tutorials for that.

PROS:

+ The artwork is cool. Backgrounds are good-looking, and so are characters and foes. 
+ The soundtrack, as you might expect from a rhythm game, is pretty awesome. It also combines many music styles so if you're open minded with that stuff you'll probably enjoy it a lot.
+ 4 difficulties, from lame to more challenging. 
+ The RPG system is pretty well included. Just as simple as it needs to be.
+ The storymode is surprisingly interesting. The characters' charisma helpsa lot here.
+ The dialogues. This is actually one of the most remarkable features. Dialogues in this game are VERY hilarious. Together with a pretty cool voice acting, dialogues will keep you super entertaining and will provide many, many laughs.

CONS:

- Despite having a cool artwork, there's not too much variety, specially from foes.
- At some points grinding/farming is mandatory.
- All achievements can be obtained no matter the difficulty you set, which makes them WAY less satisfying.
- No leaderboards. 
- Steam version works like a Flash game (for instance, I couldn't make screenshots, nor broadcasts). 

All in all, I've had a GREAT experience with this game. It has some minor flaws I could perfectly ignore, and every rhythm player should try this out. You'll surely find some good fun and discover a very consistent title despite its price (less than an euro during sales... WHAT?).

[b]Final Mark[/b]: 7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198023246857', 'num_games_owned': 1266, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1435791249}
review:
One of the best rhythmic games out there. Other then that, it's a mix between that and RPG style progression. I'll give ya a list of pros and cons so you can better decide on whether you should buy Beyond the Echo. I personally recommend the game. By the way, don't mind shitty Metascore for the low rating, and I mean that for this game and for all the other games out there. Enough rambling though.

Pros:
- Very, very low price.
- Amazing soundtrack!
- Original gameplay.
- Beautiful hand painted scenarios.
- Mix between rhythmic and RPG genres.
- Awesome setting!
- Prequel to "There Came an Echo".
- Really funny parts!
- Over 12 hours of gameplay for such a low price!
- Quality voice acting.
- Cuddos for the ending sequence.
- Credits scene! 

Cons:
- Can get grindy after a while, due to repetition of certain songs.
- Rather simplistic, yet enjoyable gameplay.
- The final boss fight is simply to easy! Learning the final scroll should be the ending sequence. (it's so god damn hard!)
- No more cons, so just buy the damn game already!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=460700330

author: {'steamid': '76561197966077684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1912, 'last_played': 1390190955}
review: Quite awesome, to be completely honest. Some longtime stepmania players may find it hard to adapt to lane switching, and the arrows which are now coded for game mechanics reasons (like skills, incoming damage amounts), rather than based on beat type. This in particular can make some things (like skill unlock challenges) much harder than you may be used to, for interface reasons. Still, the gameplay is quite solid, the dialog and characters, while campy, is very enjoyable, and the game overall was more than worth a summer sale purchase price.

review: Been some time since I played it and just now (after game rename) felt the need to express how wonderful this game is. Smooth gameplay, awesome music. 100%-able! And a lil of story to go with it. Grab it to relax while exercising your brain cells! Double profit!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992614533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1434898171}
review:
I started playing and could not stop until I finished the story.

Everything about this game is great. The story is mysterious, the characters have personality and are well-voiced, there is a simple crafting element, and the sense of incremental progress that you want in an RPG. The rhythm mechanic works very well! It keeps battles interesting and fun.

My only complaint is that there is not enough music. The system in this game deserves a wide array of music. There were only ~12 battle songs throughout the game. I found myself a little disappointed when I'd face a new monster or boss and think, "Oh, it's this song again." I do like the quality of the music, and would prefer quality over quantity, but the ideal case would be both. :)

If you are a fan of rhythm games and RPGs, this is the game for you!
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198017714999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1434823242}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995242011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1172, 'last_played': 1433744566}
review:
The boring prequel to the much more interesting "There Came an Echo".  The game plays much like StepMania (DDR without the dancing) although there is an intersting field switch mechanic which you need to exploit to clear the stages.  Alot of odd design decisions went into this game; spend your experince to maybe get an item, craft required items in order to progress the stage, challenge the same stage over and over in hopes of getting key components.  It all adds up to repetitively grinding the same monsters on the same handful of songs over and over in order to progress.  I can only imagine these were added to help artifically increase the length of the game, which would otherwise be extremely short, which leads me into my major issue with the game; the writing.
Writing is an issue which it's much better successor shares, everyone is so contrived in following along with the plotline, In this iteration, the protaginist and the supporting heroine are set up as antagonists, but engage in half hearted bickering until events contrive to have the hero off rescuing her a couple in game hours after their intitial meeting; what changed to reconcile these two advesaries?  A couple of passing comments wich imply the possibly the heroine is not 100% commited to organization which is forcing the hero to risk his life.  If only it was that easy for me to reconcile with my enemies.  The story climax involves a forced moral objection to something which, when you think about it, isn't all that bad, which has the hero vowing to commit his life to destroying those responsible and taking on substatial personal risk in the interium.  This isn't a crusader of justice, it's suposedly a VERY bright college kid caught up in a risky mis-adventure.  In real life, 10 of 10 of such kids would not tell the head of a powerful multinational organization which managed to abduct them and spirt them away to tower of death, that not only will you not forgive them, you'll make it your life's work to destroy them for the crime of [spoiler] setting you up on a blind date [/spoiler]

review:

M√™me l'histoire est accrochante (ca nous change du groupe de musique qui part en tourn√©e n'est ce pas Actipognon?!)
Graphiquement les plans sont vraiment beaux rien √† redire

Les dialogues sont assez marrants j'ai ador√© les voix des personnages et en particulier celles de Ky et Naia. Une version francaise aurait ete super mais bon on va pas chipot√© non plus.

Bref un systeme d'item et de level tres bien travaill√©, et si on est d'abord surpris par la musique, on se rend compte qu'elle est vraiment cool. Le fait de mettre en sc√®ne des combats √† travers un jeu de rythme parait casse gueule mais c'est pas du tout le cas ici au contraire et on retrouve cette espece de fi√®vre des bornes d'arcade √†  appuyer fr√©n√©tiquement partout sur sa manette...

author: {'steamid': '76561198076368082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1417, 'last_played': 1433447900}

author: {'steamid': '76561198091666121', 'num_games_owned': 711, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1448588242}
review:
Before the Echo (used to be Sequence) is a game that combines the rhythm game genre and the RPG genre. It combines the element of grinding from RPG games and rhythm game EXTREME TAPPING EXTRAVAGANZA!!! very well, and if you are a fan of both, definitely get this game. This game is only $4.99 and is totally worth it, even at full price. I've never seen a game that has successfully combined two different genres together so well.

Before the Echo also has a story included inside of it. I really love all of the character voice acting especially the sassiness of the main characters, Ky and Naia (it's pretty funny because of the amount of sass).There are also automatic saves that appear very often, which is great. Music is also very fun and upbeat as well. 



Also, this game has taught me one lesson. 

Multitasking is hard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004388901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1434356385}
review:
As a huge fan of Rhythm games and RPGs I thought that this game would be amazing, but I am extremely disappointed.

While I ultimately ended up playing on Spasmodic difficulty, and am capable of getting 100% on several songs when I 'practice' in the bonus mode, the RPG elements, coupled with the field switching mechanic makes many foes extremely challenging.

Speaking of RPG elements, there is absolutely no explanation of the actual mechanical effects of the offense and defense stats. It's logical to assume that defense decreases the damage you take from missed gems, which is in turn multiplied by the gem color, but no indication is given about how much defense reduces how much damage.
Coupled with the fact that you can't see actual concrete stats from enemies (only vague bars), and the RPG mechanics seem to be a gimick that was tacked on to a rhythm game to make it 'harder' without requiring them to add more songs or harder difficulties for the songs.

Ultimately, I'd rather play something like Stepmania on the harder difficulties for my Rhythm game fix, and then play an RPG like Dragon Age or one of the various Elder Scrolls.

I give this game a 2/5. I might have given it a 3/5 purely for the snarky dialogue during the cutscenes, but the audio quality is hit and miss. (You can tell that certain lines were recorded on different days when the ambient sound changes)

author: {'steamid': '76561198048808158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1433119464}
review:
Before the Echo is an RPG where you have to play DDR every time you want to cast a spell, defend against an attack or restore your mana (so you can cast more spells). Combat can be quite frantic as you have to swap between the three aforementioned modes, and it becomes important to find gaps in an enemy's attack pattern to effectively go on the offense. Additionally all combat has a time limit: each monster has a track associated with it and you need to kill it before the song ends to gain any experience or drops.

It's a neat idea and can be quite fun, at least on normal since the DDR inputs for Hard are extremely challenging to anyone without a good sense of rhythm and coordination. A controller with a reliable D-pad is essential, and thankfully you can use a combination of the D-pad and ABXY for simultaneous direction inputs.

Unfortunately it is a grind-fest; you need to craft keys to progress from floor to floor, and to craft them requires items and experience which requires you to fight monsters over and over again. Sometimes you can fail crafting an item, but if you put more experience into the synthesis you will have a greater success rate. Most of your equipment requires crafting, and learning new spells means crafting the scroll then to learn it you have to use more experience and complete a challenge which if you fail doesn't reimburse the experience used.

Grinding often becomes something of a necessity in RPGs but with a game like this you can't just do it mindlessly because of the battle system in place. It probably doesn't help either if you're not fond of the music in the game because you're going to be hearing the same tracks over and over while you meticulously enter directional inputs and pray for the right drop this time.

For the majority of people Before the Echo will not be an enjoyable experience, but if you really love DDR (but are perhaps too corpulent or uncoordinated to deal with floor pads) and grindy RPGs this will kill two birds with one stone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993676134', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1408320063}
review:
Before the Echo (formally sequence) is a game with many good ideas.  This is a shame, because it buries them in terrible design and writing.

Let's start with the good.  The basic gameplay of the game revolves around a rhythm based combat system. This is similar to DDR or Stepmania, but with three step charts (one for your attacks, one to defend, and one to recharge your mana).  This system is intuitive and rewards both musical ability as well as strategy (primarily for when you attack).  If this game was just a series of songs which had to be defeated using this system it would have been great.

Unfortunately the game has been lengthened with the most obnoxious forms of grind.  To get to the next boss fight and to proceed to the next area, you must craft a key.  To get the items for crafting the key you must fight the three monsters on your level.  They have a random chance of dropping various items, with some of the required items having a very low chance to drop.  And on top of this, crafting isn't guaranteed.  You can sacrifice your XP (and possibly lose levels) to increase the chance of success, but the success rate caps out at 95% so you can still fail.  If you do fail you lose everything and have to repeat your hunt for those items from scratch.

This means that the game very quickly forces you to repeat the same fight over and over and over again, long after it has ceased to be challenge anymore.  This completely killed any enjoyment I had for the game.  I have a feeling the developers added these grind elements to lengthen the amount of time that people would play the game, but it had the opposite effect for me.

While the grinding aspects are what kill this game, I should note that the writing is also horrible.  Absolutely everything in the game, from the dialogue of every single character and every single item description, is written in this ironic hipster tone.  This might have been amusing if it had been done in moderation, but as it is every bit of text in the game is trying to show you how funny it is, when very little is even amusing (unless you find lines like "I feel like my brain got stabbed by a hobo" to be hilarious).  It also kills your sense of immersion when absolutely every character is aware (and comments on the fact) that the game mechanics don't make sense and seem to be completely artificial.

The music is boring, and the gameplay is kind of terrible in that its basically DDR, but DDR on those annoying songs that you can never get the rhythm for. Maybe its just me, but it doesn't feel like it matches up properly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991482092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 843, 'last_played': 1407253890}
review:
I've been playing Before the Echo for years, and still wholeheartedly recommend it.  Several years back it was released as an Xbox Indie game called Sequence.  Controller, dancepad, and guitar support.  Not too much later it was ported to PC in all its glory.  I bought it again because, why not?  Although the voice acting and story get a lot of criticism, I love them both.  Maybe its just my kind of humor, but I find all of it both clever and charming.

My only complaint about the game is depending on your dificulty of choice, you can get some harsh difficulty spikes right after you pass the point you are no longer allowed to chance your difficulty.  Be warned, but otherwise this game is loads of fun.  RPG plus Rhythm game with loads of style and witty dialogue thrown in.  Also, the creator voices the main character and honstly, I think he does a terrific job.  Well done, all around.  The game is well worth the price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035931277', 'num_games_owned': 1569, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 1213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1083, 'last_played': 1449888177}
review: I am not musically inclined, I do not play an instrument, I cannot detect a beat or follow rhythm to save my life - BUT I LOVE THIS GAME. The storyline is sarcastic, whitty, and beautiful backgrounds with just enough graphics to not detract from the overall ambiance of the game.  Of all the games I completed 100% in the past decade, this one I did because it was addictingly fun and I love showing it off to friends.  Beat the entire thing at least 3 times, and still play it randomly to relisten to the songs. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198040068728', 'num_games_owned': 2159, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 923, 'last_played': 1419986421}
review:
Now I have to admit when I first started playing this game I had quite low expectations of it. I absolutely love rhythm games but I couldnt see how they could successfully combine this into a RPG style. Although I was proved wrong as this game is AMAZING!!

The mechanics of the game are very unique and there is nothing quite like it. You use the rhythm of the music to fight a battle. To this you use the arrow keys and click them as soon as the arrow reaches the bottom of the screen. And this is when it gets unique. You have 3 fields to control via this rhythm ability. Mana, Attack and Defense. Mana is collected and can be used to cast spells in the attack field. You can switch through these fields at your free will. You need to make sure that you use each field correctly and at the right time to survive and win the battle. 

The story of this game is what most suprised me. It had me hooked throughout the entire thing. There are many twists in the story that keep you guessing throughout the game. The voice is acting is very well done and the characters are very likable. You really do get to know the characters. In a rhythm game a gripping story is the last thing I would have expected. I am not going to go into detail about the story but just experience it for yourself and you will see how great it is. 

The whole look of the game is completely incredible. The art style gives a real great look to the game that compliments the awesome gameplay. 

Throughout the floors you get different items. You have collect these items through playing the levels. I felt the items abilitys were very well balanced and contributed well to the gameplay. These items are obtained through a random drop rate on levels. Some items have a very low drop rate on levels later on the game. Unfortunetely this is where my only bad point comes from this game. To get these items it can become very grindy with you having to repeat these levels multiple times in a row just to get it. This can get very boring after a while.

I'll end this review with the best part of the game, the soundtrack. It is made of music by Ronald Jenkees and Michael Wade Hamilton. I always feel that a game has a great soundtrack when I like it so much that I even listen to it outside of the game itself, and with this one I did. It is incredible and goes great with a rhythm game. 

Overall this game is a true masterpiece and a bit of a hidden gem. This game is possibly one of the best I have ever played and I really highly recommend it.

[h1]TheIronicGamers rating system[/h1]
[list][*] Don't ever buy this game. 
[*]Maybe consider it on a sale. 
[*]An average game.
[*]A good game that should definitely be considered.
[*][b][u]A must play![/u][/b]
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197998568769', 'num_games_owned': 669, 'num_reviews': 818, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1453257924}
review: I found that inputs become very complicated very fast, and the gameplay wasn't engaging enough to make getting better worth my time.  Great soundtrack though - go Ronald Jenkees!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025201418', 'num_games_owned': 979, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1366, 'last_played': 1427561196}
review:
Though it's easy to go "oh it's just DDR/Stepmania/etc" there really aren't any games that play like Sequence does, forcing you to manage multiple stepcharts, resources, and commands on top of the basic 'hit the notes when they hit the bottom of the screen' gameplay we're all familiar with.  Which probably sounds daunting but the game's tailored to all varieties of skill levels.  And then you add in a pretty solid soundtrack and genuinely enjoyable writing and art and you've got a very solid package.

That said, be ready to (ugh) grind.  There's a heavy RNG factor that can force you to repeat content or spontaneously penalize you, and that really does drag down the game.  I mean the core game is fun, but, y'know, somewhere around the tenth fight against a monster for the material you only needed 3 of you start getting kinda worn out.

But that's basically the one strike against an otherwise brilliant game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092535958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1459970589}
review: At first I was skeptical of the quality of this game. I initially bought it because i got a 50% discount coupon from completing the Transistor card set bvut it turned outto be quite enjoyable. It's one of those DDR style music games where you have to hit the incoming directional arrows that time with the music. Yes, this is a rpg-ish game and you're probably wondering what music would have to do with that. Well, guess what? That's right, you dance battle the monsters and bosses. You play as some guy with no real fashion sense who gets to dance battle monsters or die trying. This game also features a storyline with quality voice acting and funny dialogue, A sassy companion in the form of a disembodied female voice, and one very sexy man-boss. Definitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997255017', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 899, 'last_played': 1386112840}
review:
Pros:

¬∑ Great music-based battle mechanics, fast paced and everything I wanted for an RPG in this aspect
¬∑ Music during battle is not bad, some themes are pretty good.
¬∑ Interesting history, but someway predictable.

Cons:

¬∑ Lack of an open world to explore: it's just a sequence (ha!) of background images where you do your standard RPG stuff
¬∑ Lack of proper character animation: sometimes the game just feels plain. If only the artwork guys had made some basic animations for at least the characters, the game would look amazing and dynamic, specially in battles.

Nevertheless, it's a must play

author: {'steamid': '76561198025511957', 'num_games_owned': 1206, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1429361986}
review:
This game is excellent. Normally, RPGs and music games both face issues, but I can't readily see them in this title. It took the gameplay of Rockband: Unplugged for the PSP and made it actually functional, and into an intuitive battle system. The RPG elements, with the ability to gain and lose levels as you spend time bettering your character, made character building interesting and every upgrade felt impactful. The voice acting was well done too, though similarly with There Came an Echo the character development was not endearing, focused too much on antagonistic dialouge rather than meaningful trait building. Still, however, you can skip these scenes so you can get away from that as much as possible. 

The game itself, I'll warn, has little replay value. There's no software to add custom tracks like in Audiosurf, the music gets used on multiple levels and, given you are grinding, you get to hear the songs over and over again. If the music was bad, this would have been worse of an issue but I can't honestly say that the songs were terrible and didn't go so far as to play abrasive music from Dubstep, etc. Other things I'd change would be additions of things like local PvP, clearer labeling on the spell circle to tell which spell was which and what numbers corresponded to which slice of the circle, and more than seven levels/three battle senarios per level.  

All in all it is a fun game. For 5$, it has about as much content as you'd expect and with as polished as it looks, sounds, and feels I can't recommend it enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097644523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1932, 'last_played': 1449090679}
review: I can't recommend this game enough- It has beautiful visuals, an awesome soundtrack, great characters and a pretty neat story too. It's so fun to play! I just love this game and wish that there was more of it. (You can't grumble at the price either).

author: {'steamid': '76561198119168885', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1421119227}
review: A self-aware, DDR, RPG game.  Absolutely awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993204463', 'num_games_owned': 2317, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 852, 'last_played': 1425292606}
review:
Games like Sequence are the reason Kickstarter and the Indie Game movement exist. It's not a perfect game, not everyone is going to enjoy it and it will never receive a lot of fame and recognition. However, for the niche audience that can appreciate it, Sequence is a game like no other.

The closest thing I can relate Sequence to is Puzzle Quest. The game doesn't play like Puzzle Quest but what that game did for Match-3 games, Sequence does for the rhythm genre. The base game has you traveling up a tower by fighting enemies, collecting their dropped items, and synthesising items such as keys, weapons and armor. Battles give you experience which will level up your stats while armor and weapons are equipable and can also improve your abilities. 

Where Sequence differs from the average dungeon crawler is that combat is played out by putting you in a rhythm system similar to StepMania, if you're using a keyboard, but with three separate boards. One board is defensive, one board is for building mana and one is for casting spells. On the first board, any notes that you miss will count as damage against you so catching them defends your HP. The second board will have a constant stream of notes. Missing them doesn't hurt you but catching them restores your mana which you need to cast spells. The last board stays dormant until you cast spells, the only way to damage your opponents. When you cast a spell, it takes mana and makes you complete a short rhythm sequence. Failing it causes the spell to fail but completing it will cast that spell. While it can be a lot to juggle at once, the game does a great job of teaching you and ramping up the difficulty slowly in order to build your skills both in game and out.

The gameplay by itself is fun for a while but as the entire game is built around grinding items and EXP, it would get boring very quickly if it weren't for the well written story pushing players forward. The tone reminded me of The World Ends With You in the best possible way, but felt wholy unique. Your main character finds himself waking up in a tower with no idea how he got there. The voice of a girl named Naia tells you that you are stuck in this tower/game and you will need to make your way up 7 floors to escape so off you go. While there are some predictable moments, the story as a whole never becomes too transparent and despite a few moments when I swore I was done after one more battle, curiosity kept me pushing ever forward. The characters are all voiced as well and while none are particularly mind-blowing, it's a nice touch and the quality stayed consistent throughout. If you do find your bar set particularly high in regards to VO quality, they do have an option to turn it off as well although I doubt this will be necessary for most people.

That's not to say the game isn't without it's rough spots. For a music-based game, Sequence has a surprisingly limited soundtrack of only about 10 songs that show up in battle. This means several monsters will have you playing the same songs repeatedly. Thankfully, they aren't bad and some of them I didn't mind repeating but considering each monster all but requires multiple playthroughs anyway, don't be surprised if you wind up hearing the same song 10+ times. As that suggests too, the gameplay is simply too grindy and while item drops are pretty common, it can be irritating when you need one specific item and have to fight the same monster over and over just to move forward. Finally, the song balance is a bit odd as by the end of the game, the length of the song decided more battles for me than my HP did. It felt like very artificial difficulty (you lose if the song ends before killing the enemy) and it would have been nicer to have some of the songs be just a bit longer, especially in Floor 7. Depending on your strategy, you may not have a problem with this but it showed up several times in my game.

Overall, if you're looking for something different and enjoy music gameplay, Sequence is worth a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110057344', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1703050384}
review: I was skeptical about this game at first, but after two near-sleepless nights I can honestly say I'm super addicted.  I got this game with the sequel "There Came an Echo," and didn't expect much out of it, but there's just something addicting about playing DDR with your fingers on a keyboard.  Also, considering these only two games from iridium studios, I think the guy that runs the place just wants to make funny sounds while he plays his games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980054291', 'num_games_owned': 2267, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1425247548}
review:
Taking a simple DDR based rthym game and turning into an RPG combat system was a suprisingly good idea. Unfortunately the way progression in the game is very grindy, but the core combat mechanics are more than fun enough to keep you playing. 
And while a simple arcade concept such as this could have easily gone with a cheesy and overly simplistic story, they went all out here, the game's got a very good story and is well voice acted.

Simply put, for the cheap price it's currently available at (or even better, free with There came an echoe) it'll provide hours of fun and a great story. Can't recommend it enough, Iridium studios are quickly becoming a studio to watch out for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970534866', 'num_games_owned': 964, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1425083183}
review: I don't like rhythm based games and there's no real way around this. The story seems neat, and I like Iridium, but I can't get around the fact that I don't enjoy it as a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992503198', 'num_games_owned': 813, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1426630068}
review: Tr√®s bon jeu. A tester absolument !

author: {'steamid': '76561198023732687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1042, 'last_played': 1424733512}
review:
This game is amazing. If a game that combines rhythm game and RPG appeals to you then this game would be something to look at even if that combination of genre wasn't so rare. 

First off to all the people who aren't scared off from thinking of potential problems or weirdness already, it's not just "let's smash these genres together". It's very functional as a rhythm game and they made that part of gameplay the "battle" portion of the RPG. You switch between "fields" to either defend against attacks, cast spells or regain mana. The balance of strength of attacks and difficulty pulling them off feels nice and natural and the game overall feels just wonderfully made. Like any RPG you might need to grind a little but just remember to pay attention to getting good equipment and good spell usage and it shouldn't get too bad. I think the only negative I can really think about gameplay is there isn't any "turn based" alternative for anyone that isn't physically capable of playing a timing based game, but for the rest of it it's good to go. 

Music and visual aesthetics might depend a bit on individual taste to say for sure but I personally loved both in this game.  The story is awesome too, unlike a lot of other RPG's it doesn't give you a ton of story which works since plenty of the interest comes in the mystery and uncertainty. You get just a few cutscenes every floor, long enough to enjoy the strange characters but not so long you forget you're playing a video game. Trust me there's not really any throw away characters.

Saddly as much as I'd like to go on I don't know how much deeper I can dig without risking any spoilers or rambling on too much, but trust me when I say this is a unique gem of a game worth playing through to the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099414892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1219, 'last_played': 1569136137}
review: Awesome game! Reminds me of DDR except with fingers. This game has some RPG elements along with mulitiple different songs to play to. I enjoyed every part of it. The plot is well constructed and is weaved together with each successive level in the game. Strongly recommend. Best game I've played in a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086061585', 'num_games_owned': 2345, 'num_reviews': 384, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1424282431}
review:
Great than Thapster app. It contains a lot of wonderful musics especially the last one with the boss scene, hard like hell but challenging to achieve 100%. The story is basic for me but I have a little surprise of it a bit though.

If you like music-tap game so this is the best game I can recommend.

And the other thing that I love is the publisher releases their soundtracks for free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064859671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1424188810}
review:
Wow, I feel so annoyed by this game that I actually needed to post a review of it in order to assuage my hatred.

I absolutely love rhythm games and RPGs but what I get here is a game narration that is trying far too hard to be cutesy snarky and a tutorial system that crashes out. If you can actually make it past that, the game play itself is boring and the controls are weak. By "weak" I mean largely frustrating with a lack of baked-in customization. I'm glad I did not pay full price for this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068926428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1423802357}
review:
A rhythm-based turn-based RPG with a lot of interesting ideas. Paying XP to craft... three different "arrow screens" to rotate between in battles.

There are some negatives:
- You will play the same songs at varying difficulties through the game... I was shocked to enter the second "floor" and see that my battles were some of the same songs (some different, but some the same).
- The writing and voice acting is annoying. If you go to negative reviews you will see this overwhelmingly stated... you can just skip the dialogue... or just not get SO bothered by it... it's not like there is a ton of dialogue in the game. There is a decent amount, but all save the tutorial is skippable.

But, as a positive, the general premise of the game is fun and it has some great ideas. It's a fun game if you don't mind "grinding" some DDR to get loot to craft items, etc.

If you can look past the negatives above and are even remotely interested in rhythm games and RPGs I suggest this game. If you are only an RPG fan and not much for rhythm games... even then I suggest it (just play at the easiest difficulty). At 5$ you cannot go wrong with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971476410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1382844114}
review: It's a rather fun, challenging, rhthym game. The game plays like DDR for those unfamiliar, and the music is pretty good. It's the same music featured in Bill Simmon's B.S. report. The game is really polished. I had no glitches of any sort and it never crashed on me.  I can get back to playing this game after a year or so because there's no "grinding" aspect. Listen to the music and it will flow through.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991428111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1133, 'last_played': 1423840289}
review: Hands down the best rythm game I have ever had the joy of experiencing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039863685', 'num_games_owned': 1423, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 1054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1054, 'last_played': 1423424832}
review:
Idea is fun and refreshing, visuals are fine, music is ok, but it gets too grindy for me by the end... It's not too long, so I suggest to give it a shot... Especially if you find it cheap...

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994130090', 'num_games_owned': 498, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1423270077}
review:
As a long-time rhythm game (in this case Stepmania) player, I was really excited for Sequence. The game looked to be just the right mix between rhythm and RPG elements, with a fun soundtrack to back it up. Unfortunately the game gets a little too grindy for my taste - you can beat pretty much any encounter in the game provided that you're a high enough level. 

Leveling up is a chore though, and the bonus for beating an enemy skillfully isn't enough to outweigh the immense grind. A lot of the depth of the game involved simple grinding to get better levels, as later bosses had too much health and an item or a couple of levels was enough to make it easy. The grinding is really boring though as the regular creatures usually don't pose much threat. 

If you're a fan of rhythm games I'd recommend picking it up, but if you're new maybe give it a pass or play it on a lower difficulty. I played it on Hard because it said "for the not musically challenged," but most of the difficulty came from luck not going in my favor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009490987', 'num_games_owned': 1210, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1948, 'last_played': 1597488289}
review: Highly recommended. Played this game all the way through and enjoyed every minute of it. Wish more games were like this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005501566', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1403888428}
review:
I‚Äôm horrible at rhythm games, I‚Äôve never had the speed and skills to get through the harder difficulties and at the easier levels it feels like it‚Äôs to simple and child‚Äôs play. So I was kinda meh about the whole idea behind Sequence. But as soon as I got in there I must say that I really REALLY enjoyed rhythm gaming mixed with RPG elements, fighting, spells, mana and so on. Giving my successes and failures a deeper meaning.

It surprisingly fun to pull of a combo in Sequence and you‚Äôre rewarded with fun characters, good dialogue (not the best voice acting maybe but still fun dialogue). And for the first time I want to get further and deeper through the game‚Ä¶ and it‚Äôs a rhythm game! The hardcore rhythm gamers will probably enjoy this, and the casual ones will like this, and the non rhythm gamers will still enjoy it for feeling more like a puzzle game.

Give this game a chance!

Recommended.

[b]/ Nurgleprobe[/b]

review: Rhythm game with RPG elements that brings nice music, story, and challenge. Worth a look if you're interested in rhythm games, and even if you're bad (but enjoy them) you can lower the difficulty or grind a bit to make it easier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040488448', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1421458085}
review: Sequence is easily one of the best rhythm games I've ever played. The unique blend of rhythm and RPG is simply fantastic. Not to mention an amazing soundtrack primarily featuring Ronald Jenkees, this game will definitely be one of the best investments you make.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037334748', 'num_games_owned': 577, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1421031463}
review:
Sequence √© um jogo deveras impressionante. O seu objetivo √© pressionar as teclas direcionais no momento exato para produzir m√∫ltiplas a√ß√µes. Existem 3 quadros interativos nas batalhas: o de defesa (contra ataques inimigos), o de magias (sua √∫nica forma de atacar seus advers√°rios) e o de Mana ‚Äì cuja pron√∫ncia correta √© ‚Äúmah-nah" ‚Äì onde √© poss√≠vel recuperar seus pontos de magia para utilizar cada vez mais suas magias.

O jogo gira em torno de lutas, batalhas estas muitas vezes cansativas devido ao fato de que ser√° necess√°rio enfrentar um mesmo personagem v√°rias vezes at√© obter todos os seus itens drop√°veis. Alguns desses itens ser√£o necess√°rios para fabrica√ß√£o de chaves, obrigat√≥rias para que se d√™ continuidade ao jogo.

Quanto √† trilha sonora, √© relativamente boa, o que nesse caso torna-se obrigat√≥rio visto que o jogo em quest√£o gira em torno de sua musicalidade e as "sequ√™ncias" devem ser realizadas de acordo com o ritmo musical. Um fator negativo √© que as mesmas repetem-se v√°rias vezes em virtude de existirem poucas, o que tornar√° suas batalhas, em alguns casos, entediantes.

A hist√≥ria √© razo√°vel, sem um enredo complexo nem nada, mas at√© certo ponto atraente. √â uma parte que deveria ter sido mais bem trabalhada. Ap√≥s vencer o jogo e cumprir alguns requisitos especiais (vide achievements) um novo final pode ser destravado, mas t√£o non-sense quanto o anterior.

Por fim, quero deixar registrado minha frusta√ß√£o com rela√ß√£o ao m√©todo de c√°lculo de percentagem desse jogo. A percentagem ou porcentagem (do latim per centum, significando "por cento", "a cada centena") √© uma medida de raz√£o com base 100 (cem). √â um modo de expressar uma propor√ß√£o ou uma rela√ß√£o entre 2 (dois) valores (um √© a parte e o outro √© o inteiro) a partir de uma fra√ß√£o cujo denominador √© 100 (cem), ou seja, √© dividir um n√∫mero por 100 (cem). O c√°lculo percentual nada mais √© que a multiplica√ß√£o de um valor qualquer pelo percentual desejado. Durante o jogo inteiro, voc√™ precisar√° de reagentes e receitas para sintetiza√ß√£o de produtos. A chance de sucesso aumenta (ou diminui) conforme voc√™ aumenta (ou diminui!) a quantidade de XP doada! Isso mesmo, XP! Voc√™ perder√° muita experi√™ncia atrav√©s deste m√©todo, infelizmente.

A frusta√ß√£o ocorre porque os desenvolvedores animais desse jogo n√£o sabem como este c√°lculo ocorre e o que significa, gerando situa√ß√µes em que uma chance de 90%+ n√£o significar√° absolutamente nada na fabrica√ß√£o de itens... Lament√°vel...

Por√©m, quero deixar registrado que o jogo possui uma caracter√≠stica peculiar que me agradou bastante, diga-se de passagem. E √© por este motivo que eu o recomendo!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011548235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 909, 'last_played': 1540750738}
review:
Love this game! The music, the backgrounds, the characters! I'm a long time fan of DDR but this was something else entirely. I loved having to switch through the three different panels to gain mana, defend, and attack. Towards the end, it started to get a little too easy for me once I figured out a sure way to win each battle (certain combinations of attacks in certain 'sequences' ...haha). Next time I'll have to play through on a harder difficulty - first time through it I think I did it on a step up from easy.

And a nice little story to keep me engaged and curious. I only wish there was more! 15 hours of game time is pretty good, though. But it's very relaxing to play so I think I'll be coming back to it often.

If you have yet to acquire a sense of rhthym or musicality, this game might be a bit hard to get used to... but I still recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032458865', 'num_games_owned': 1345, 'num_reviews': 393, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1684256033}
review: Worst writing[It's like I'm on meth, that flashy thing...], and voice acting[skype chat] ever. Borring/slow gameplay, very simple UI and gameplay, the only thing that looks like it took minimal effort was the art assets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055239225', 'num_games_owned': 640, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1399539480}
review: A rhythm rpg game with a level up system and a crafting element is a brief summary, however the story and characters are flat and unengaging, I keep meaning to go back and try to finish the game but never quite get there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018488154', 'num_games_owned': 2807, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 94, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1420318257}
review:
Wow. Where to start?

The controls are bad. First time I played it detected my pad and therefore forgot to mention the keyboard keys which I had to find on my own (and you have to rebind them cause they are stupid. Try using the up and low arrows quickly at the same time for example).
Second they are not responsive. I've played rythm games before and never had any problems (especially at lower difficulties).
Third. The story is non existent, the dialogs are terrible and probably made for 13 year old kids.
The voices are so bad it hurts.
Fourth the music is bad. It's not electro it's not techno, it's closer to elevator music.
Fifth I'll be having nightmares about this game.
Sixth first time I'm writing a review but I felt I had to. (Can't believe there are so few negative reviews about that game).

author: {'steamid': '76561198002227575', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1420068182}
review:
Here we have a very unique RPG game known as Sequence. This game is a RPG game with Dancing Stage elements added. The way it is used is very cool, and I do think that more people should try it out.

The story is quite good, the characters are memorable, and the music is great. I will easily give this a dice throw score of 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006077632', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 838, 'last_played': 1419325859}
review:
Personally used a DS4 gamepad for Sequence. Having played through it using only the gamepad, I have no idea how it handles with a keyboard, but I can say that the gamepad felt completely natural to use. Switching through the fields using the triggers was outright cathartic.

Sequence is a gameplay-focused game, and the gameplay is as fantastic as it is interesting. The field-based rhythm combat isn't just a novelty, it has handfuls of legitimate merit. I'd even go so far as to call it innovative. The inherent multi-tasking and battle system means that the game is less execution-heavy than you might like, but playing on Hard did mean that Piano Jam left my fingers aching nonetheless. 

Battle system itself revolves around the use of skills and micromanaging several fields. Things start to fall apart here - the usefulness of skills is determined by your stats (automatically allocated after each level-up) entirely and utterly. Pulling off a skill doesn't nearly matter as much as the stats behind it, and at several points in the game I had to go to a previous area to grind up a few levels because I was simply unable to deal enough damage to defeat an enemy in the time allocated (you only have until the song ends). Taking into account that the insurmountable enemies in question were rather easy otherwise, it was a total chore. 

Stats don't belong in this game - instead of skillfully outmaneuvering the enemy through sick beats, you're either painfully chipping away at their health pool or utterly annihilating them, and all in the space of about 2-3 levels. 

The reason this game has so many stats is because it also bills itself as an RPG, and stats are a required part of that I guess. It fails as one. There's no sense of playing a role whatsoever, and the worldbuilding is so thin it completely collapses under itself at several points. All the item descriptions are all completely irrelevant puns (funny ones, but quick wit doesn't flesh out a world), and the entire premise is waved off by the characters as intentionally arbitrary, which tries as hard to engage as a prince betrothed to a simian. This game is about as much an RPG as your average dating sim.

You progress through the game through the game's shallow crafting system. Choose an enemy to fight, and they have a chance to drop an item. Use these items to craft an item that will allow you to progress to the next area. How quickly you are able to craft this item depends on whether or not an enemy decides to drop the item. While it should be noted that there are some late-game items that increase item drop rate, the progression remains steadfastly a nightmare. Farming for items isn't fun. Whoever thought it was fun is a monster.

Combine this with that crafting recipes requires EXP. On it's own, this is a fantastic idea. However, combined with the stat-dependent gameplay and already tedious farm-based progression, it does nothing but serve to remind yourself how much of a chore it should have been to get through the game, had it not had the lucky break of being legitimately enjoyable to play. I don't see myself replaying it anytime soon, though.

The character banter is alright, though the story is so horrendous that I was left shocked by the sheer contrived garage leaking out of that final 10 minute exposition dump that sold itself as an ending. Shocked at a point I'd long since become apathetic. It's almost impressive how bad the plot is. The weak sense of intrigue initially spiked is just dragged out and finally shot like a dying dog. The super secret Sequel hook is hilariously nothing as well.

Art direction, I found, was fine, outside of rather cheap-looking UI. There's not enough of it though - there's a total of about 8 area images, and a single sprite per character or monster. No CGs for major events, and even those scarce few images are reused to hell and back. There's budget, and then there's ridiculous.

In spite of these problems, I completely and totally recommend that you play Sequence. The choice of music is stellar, the mechanics responsive, and as a whole the game is plain fun. The gameplay doesn't just carry it, it vaults it to the finish line. I'd love to see a sequel.

Regardless of its other issues (they're important to know, and I've spent the majority of the review ragging on them as a result), they're superficial to the very meaty game itself. And that's the bottom line.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995215940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1424998714}
review:
Expectation should be left at the door when playing "Before the Echo". Catchy tracks align themselves neatly with "gems" or arrows on the tracks, bringing a truely rhythmic experience. 

"Before the Echo" occasionally feels like a grind and my experience has only been through PC controls through normal difficulty.
I still rate this game highly on rhythmic value, the combat system is a nice tweek to the typical guitar hero style approach; with switch lanes that reminds me of Frequency and/or Amplitude.

!!! Do not measure this game by store value, it's an experience not to be missed !!!
