author: {'steamid': '76561198001494272', 'num_games_owned': 1309, 'num_reviews': 332, 'playtime_forever': 983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 983, 'last_played': 1384570760}
review:
June 4, 2015

Before the Echo (or Sequence, before the legal stuff) is a solid rhythm combat game, with emphasis on multitasking. The graphics are nice, but lacking full character animation. Music in the game is good, but the limited setlist means several songs will be repeated. That repetition [i]will[/i] get on your nerves, as the progression system in the game pushes for RPG-style grinding to craft all the equipment. With 3 monsters to choose per floor, you will have to repeat fights to get all the random crafting parts.

The game is solid and charming, but stretches some content thin with grinding. I can recognize the music even a year after beating it. It doesn't need much of a sale to be a great deal, and I can recommend it at full $5 USD if you are looking for something unique. If you don't mind the combat grind, you'll love every minute.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999769158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1153, 'last_played': 1418147362}
review:
When I heard about this indie title, being addicted to rhythm games like Stepmania and the possibility to play with a dancepad already got me interested. 
Ready to press arrows blindly according to the patterns, what I really found is that [b]Sequence is a simple rpg game, in which are injected rhythmic mechanics with average difficulty[/b]. 
Mixed genres dude!

Iridium Studios managed to produce [i]something difficult to classify[/i], yet the gameplay alone will entertain you for a decent amount of time. Yes, because while I enjoyed the game in its essence - the crafting system, the bosses and the good ol' leveling up - the story and the characters can't really get you hooked.

[spoiler]Plus, I don't get why sentences by the main character are constantly being interrupted: you feel like a spoiled brat who needs a lesson for no particular reason, and the moment after we're oh so important like the future of the world depends on us. XD
Plot twists, kinda forced, kinda rushed. Someone likes that, others don't.
[/spoiler]

Despite the full controller support, I fully played it on keyboard - more fit in handling the controls in my opinion - and it was a good experience overall: my playtime reached ~20 hours, not bad for an indie game so I cannot say I didn't enjoy the run! The achievements offer a medium challenge to accomplish, so if you're an [i]achievement hunter[/i] this is a nice game to 100% .

Finally, would you look at the price! Looks like an [i]on-sale[/i] game already, so definitely give this title a chance if you're searching for something outside the box.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977082865', 'num_games_owned': 931, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1279, 'last_played': 1588006224}
review:
Very unique spin on an otherwise commonly used rhythm game mechanic.

Anyone who has played rhythm games is all too familiar with the standard mechanic of having 4 columns of arrows falling in tune with the music. Sequence manages to make a very strong tactical/multi-tasking game out of it by having 3 seperate grids. One grid is the mana grid, which you use to get mana to cast spells - it's very common to miss lots of beats here in preference to landing beats on the other 2 grids. This is also where the beats primarily follow the song. Another grid is the defensive grid - beats that fall here and you don't hit will reduce your HP until you hit 0 and lose. The other grid is the spell grid. At any time you have the mana for it, you can choose to cast a spell - the effects vary from dealing damage to the enemy, healing, lifestealing, hitting the enemy with damage over time, giving yourself a mana boost, boosting the strength of the next spell you cast. Each individual spell has its own beat combination that doesn't change with the exception of inverting a few presses, left instead of right, etc, and also significant changes between difficulties. All these different spells are balanced by difficulty of input, how much blank space is there in between beats (to allow for swapping to other grids), as well as cooldown before you can cast that same spell again. Anything less than 100% on a spell input results in it failing, going on cooldown, and using up mana.

All those different factors result in a very frantic level of multi-tasking that I have never seen in this genre, and continuously leaves me mentally engaged, instead of just sitting back and hitting buttons corresponding to a beatmap all day. Incredibly satisfied with Sequence for gameplay originality and engagement.

Music: I'm not that big of an electronica fan, however, Ronald Jenkees has made a good effort to change my mind on that. The music for the beatmaps are all catchy. DJplaeskool did a good job with the rest of the soundtrack.

Writing/dialogue: There is a large community wide disagreement between enjoyment and annoyance of the dialogue between the 2 main characters, so your mileage will vary heavily in that regard. What I can say from an objective point of view is that it is very mechanically solid, all the characters in the game have lots of personality, and the voice acting also performs just as well as the writing.

Story: The story is neat and fairly original, and with an excellent great reveal at the end.

RPG Elements: Probably my least favorite aspect of the game, but they work solidly enough. In order to progress to a higher level in the tower, you need to do the same 3 beatmaps on the existing level enough times to collect enough drops to craft a key to be able to start the boss fight to go to the next level. This part is just fine, since it encourages a not-excessive amount of replaying the same content to a good amount of replayability. By collecting those drops, you can also craft items that make it so your spells are stronger, you have more survivability, and/or a larger mana pool. There's also experience that gets used to improve those stats via level ups, and gets used in crafting. The big reason why I'm iffy on this, is that especially on the higher difficulties, I put myself in a dilemma of whether I just need to get less bad at the game, or if I just need to grind out some better stats to give me a better fighting chance.

Overall: All the parts come to work together without any major flaws to spoil the image, and where the game truly excels is its innovative take with the 3-grid system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041812237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1461301044}
review: Bit of a mixed bag, Sequence is a rhythm game about using three different playing to fight monsters.  There's the defense field in which you defend against incoming attacks by aggressors by blocking their attacks pressing the corresponding keys.  The spell field in which you cast spells with different effects such as DoT, healing, or fast recharge low damage spells.  And the mana field in which you replenish mana, which is used to cast spells, you can only have one of these fields open at a time and there is a time limit for defeating the monster, which is an interesting concept.  The monsters have a chance of dropping various items, the lower the more rare and they all give a different amount of experience. You use your experience to craft items, spell scrolls, or keys which you use to use to progress, herein lies some of the problems of the game.  It feels like a grind, just a huge grind.  You end up wasting so much time either killing the same monster over and over again to find that ONE item you need to make better gear or spells, and you can end up wasting all of that precious expereince you earned making you down on experience, although you do lose out on some items.  It just gets very very repetitive around floor four you notice none of the spells bring anything new to the table.  It doesn't help the writing isn't super compelling.  Not to mention the music is reused and the only time you feel like you're actually playing a rhythm game is when you're in the mana field, which is when the keys actually feel like they correspond to the music.  It's got cute ideas but it's riddled with flaws, it's worth checking out if you feel confident sinking money into just to get a feel for it, hey if you're into the grind and slamming on keys for 10 seconds at a time (roughly how long it takes to get your mana replensihed) then be my guest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031789432', 'num_games_owned': 1153, 'num_reviews': 208, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 813, 'last_played': 1454145099}
review:
It's an RPG with a DDR-esque battle system. Having three simultaneous DDR-esque streams going -- one for offense, one for defense, and one for healing -- at all times during battle keeps things from going stale and allows the player freedom to strategize. If you like rhythm games, this is definitely a good one to get. It doesn't hurt that the writing and characters are also excellent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025528412', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1415963090}
review:
Art: 9/10 (I am being a little too much critical here, it is above great!)
Code: 10/10 (can not see flaws, very agile and stable! +there is calibration feature to fix A/V off-sync!)
Enjoyability: 9/10 +consists great humour! (especially check item descriptions!)
Beatmaps: 7/10 (sometimes weaker beats result in two keypress, when the strong one is one key press)
Toughtness if necessary: 10/10 (there are four difficulty settings: easy, medium, hard, spasmodic)


9/10

PROTIPS: #1: Use ASDF instead of arrows and numeric keypad 4,6 to rotate and 1,2,3,7,8,9 for spells. Really comfortable! #2: Medium is too easy. #3: Spasmodic difficulty most likely will require playing against easier enemies repetitively in order to level up and beat stronger enemies or to use recipes, because that will help a lot; makes game a little more like RPG because of the repetitions, but that is enjoyable, really. If that is not for you, take hard or normal. When I started with normal and went to 4th floor, I felt it was too easy for me and I went for spasmodic difficulty. I found it really challenging and that is what I really hoped for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049183091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1439977685}
review: Oh dear God I love this game. This is a really addictive and difficult (On hard difficulty at least) rhythm RPG. You have to switch between three panels, each of which you can see in the background even if you're not using them. The defence panel is to stop attacks that enemies throw at you, any missed will cause you to take damage. The spell panel comes up with the rhythm of any spell you cast, and missing even one will cause the spell to fail. Finally, the mana panel has rhythm which fits the song and replenishes the ability to use spells. Very difficult to keep track of the three, yet whenever you mess up you KNOW it's your fault. It also lasts a fair amount of time, however the necessary random drops can be quite frustrating. ALWAYS make all items you can on a floor, they will be needed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053568113', 'num_games_owned': 4846, 'num_reviews': 337, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1413180852}
review:
I have to admit, this game surprised me. I got this game from a bundle and decided to install it to try it out. I end up really liking it and played it until the very end. It's a rhythm based game, you have to change between 3 panels with Q and E, you use the arrows to hit the notes.

When I saw the tutorial I thought the game would be insanely confusing and hard to play, but it's quite nicely done, as you see all 3 panels at once at any time, so you see what is coming.

The art is really cool, the music is awesome and the story is even more awesome! I wanted to play until the end to know what happens... It's full of surprises, it's hiralious and you get hooked right into the story.

The spells aren't limited to only damage, you have shielding, direct damage, DOT, healing, boosts... Alot of different spells to use. You have to kill the monsters and ascend floors until you reach the top. All monsters have specific drops which you have a certain percentage of getting everytime you kill them (with music of course). You also have to craft/find your gear and you can learn new spells by using scrolls and completing the songs with high accuracy or note combos.

Theres not many bad things to say about the game... My only real issue with the game is the hitboxes... Sometimes it looks like you miss but it actually works and sometimes you think you succesfully hit the note but you didin't. Luckily this rarely happens so it didin't affect me too much. Maybe i'm just bad at the game though, I don't know!

This game is definately worth looking into, especially since it is only 4.99$. I'd say anybody that likes good stories or rhythm/music-based games should really try it out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198015850375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1412653899}
review:
Fun game, neat concept. 

Wish there were 4 or 5 monsters per floor to get the crafting items from, but that would mean more songs to get the rhythm of I suppose. I did like seeing how I could change my spell order and still kill them, and one hit killing the lower level monsters when mopping up the last few items.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000415707', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1678134234}
review:
A really awesome game that knows what it is trying to be and maximizes its potential.

What I like:
-Awesome soundtrack. I expected to tire of the music after playing a mission a few times, but it does a good job of remaining likeable throughout.
-Great visual and audible feedback when hitting and missing notes.
-I love the storyline and the voicework. Just amateur enough to seem like a project done by your friends, just professional enough to not be too distracting.
-The three way split really adds to the DDR formula and makes it a strategic challenge instead of a reflex workout.
-Scope of the game is just right. Not too big, not too small.

What I didn't like:
-Sometimes it becomes a grind when you need just one item to advance and you can't quite get it.

Not really about the game, but I love the trailers. If you don't know about hitpoints... this probably isn't the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996397743', 'num_games_owned': 1635, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1406006161}
review:
Sequence is a cool RPG/Keyboard & Controller DDR hybrid where you switch between 3 panels of moves in order to defeat your enemies. You can craft weapons, armor and a bunch of other items to make your character stronger as well. While the game has some really cool concepts, it failed to keep me interested for long. Despite all of the different spells and abilities you can use, the game started to feel tedious to me.

This is by no means a bad game; the gameplay mechanics are pretty decent, and while the voice acting and writing are semi-cringeworthy, Sequence is definitely worth a try if you see it on sale.

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198017026402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 936, 'last_played': 1629474249}
review:
El joven Ky es encerrado en una misteriosa torre, monitorizada por unos desconocidos, para hacerle pasar ciertas pruebas en las que deber√° enfrentarse a diversos guardianes en cada uno de los siete pisos. 

√âste es guiado por una misteriosa chica llamada Naia, a trav√©s de altavoces, situados en cada piso, la cual ir√°s conociendo poco a poco con unos di√°logos muy divertidos.

En el sistema de batalla deber√°s ir alternando tres pantallas: Defensa, Ataque y Recuperaci√≥n de Man√°. Deber√°s seguir el ritmo para ir recuperando man√° e ir atacando con tus diversas habilidades y derrotar a los enemigos mientras te defiendes de sus golpes.

Tambi√©n contamos con un sistema de forja de objetos en el que usaremos nuestra propia experiencia para crear nuevas magias, armas, accesorios... 

Lo que m√°s me ha llegado a atraer de este juego, ha sido la gran banda sonora (¬°¬°Ronald Jenkees es un genio!!). Todas las canciones se te acaban quedando en la cabeza, ¬°ya que debes repetir 'esas' canciones para conseguir ese dichoso objeto que no ha ca√≠do a la primera para continuar avanzando!

Como bien he mencionado anteriormente con Naia, las conversaciones son muy divertidas. Los guardianes de cada uno de los siete pisos son muy peculiares, con maneras distintas de expresarse contigo. La verdad es que me han hecho sacar m√°s de una carcajada al aire, son tan... 'especiales'. 

Si te apetece bailar tus dedos al son de la m√∫sica para acabar con esta dichosa torre, Before the Echo es una muy buena elecci√≥n.

Edit: Ahora el juego se llama Before the Echo, no Sequence. Sigh.

review: This game is worth every cent if you're into a rythem/RPG type of game. The voice-over's are great, the character design and enviroments looks very good. And i love the music in this game, although after some grinding for materials and defeating the same mob the song starts to get annoying a bit. The humor in the game is awesome, if you're into that internet/meme kinda humor. I've really had a great time playing this game. Took me just over 11 hours to beat the game and get all the achievements for it. Truly is a one of a kind game, amazing!

author: {'steamid': '76561197990725997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 357, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1408296754}
review:
At first glance, this game is a unique rhythm and battle game. I would enjoy this IMMENSELY more if there were multiplayer. Fighting against stale AI is pretty dull, but I like it for what it is. 

The dialog is full of excruciatingly bad deliveries of unwitty jokes and poor "insightful" satirical sarcasm that belittles people's intelligence in an almost superfluously verbose manner (as if they are talking to a child). I don't need the explanations of these poor attempts at "correcting" whoever they are trying to correct and I am sure most people didn't eg., when they say the word "Mana" and say it is pronounced "Mah-na", It came off so pretentious and belittling. It would just be so much better if they didn't have this unnecessary dialog for the tutorial, people want to get straight to the gameplay and see if they like it before wasting an hour of dialog! I know how "Mana" is pronounced, I am sure most avid gamers are familiar with it and even MTG players. BUT the MAIN character, I guess because of the personality he was given? He speaks FOR me. He called Naia annoying, dear god is she annoying! The voice actor who did her, I don't know if it was a girlfriend of one of the developers or something, but she has that valley girl voice that makes me want to rip my hair out every time I hear her vocal fry. She stutters here and there and fails to convey her credibility as a "guardian" in the game. Despite her lines and voice acting being terrible, the main character proves a redeeming glimmer of hope of tolerance. 

Being there were some sound issues already, I expect way more and some of the sfx are not mixed into the overall game volume very well. 

The music, thus far, is pretty bland. It would be better if they were all original tracks catered to the players and developers. 

I recommend the game if you can catch it on sale or in a bundle or if you have a 10-16 year old sis/bro, otherwise I'd say to go find a different rhythm game. If multiplayer comes to be in this concept, then it's on!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041543513', 'num_games_owned': 761, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1470513083}
review:
I've been buying a lot of bundles recently, I picked up ~20 in July, and Sequence has been one of my favorite pulls thus far. 

*NOTE: This review will be fairly biased, as I enjoy dj-ing/mixing electronic dance music.

If you like rhythm games like Tap Tap Revolution, music - in particular the electronic dance music genre, grinding, and crafting, then you will really enjoy this game. [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lg8LfoyDFUM]Ronald Jenkees[/url] does a lot of the music for the game, and if you like his style then you will love the music found here.

The aesthetics of the game are nice - the artstyle for the characters and backgrounds are well-detailed. The music is very, very good, however, if you do not like the electronic genre, then you may get tired of hearing the music, and this is critical because it is the core of the gameplay and (so far) the variety is not too expansive. You will also grind quite a bit, so you will be hearing the same tracks repeatedly. 

The story is decent, nothing too fancy. The voice acting is not bad, and the comedic banter between the main characters is funny at times. There is also some teasing of common RPG elements, which I always find very nice when not overdone.

The controls are easy to familiarize yourself with - you use the WASD keyes and/or the arrow keys in combination with the numbers (spell hotkeys) and Q and E. The tutorial is skip-able but extremely important for understanding the mechanics of the game. The learning curve is moderate to difficult - especially if you are not used to playing rhythm games. I am pretty good at beatmatching by ear, so I tried the 2nd hardest difficulty and had to tone it down a level - my finger dexterity on the keys are still rusty; however, I plan to do a playthrough on the hardest difficulty once I beat the game.

Gameplay is very, very fun if you are interested in the rhythm genre. You have three windows, Defence, Spells, and Mana. Arrow kills will fall in the Defence and Mana windows, and you can swap your active window with the Q and E skills (left and right respectively). If you fail to press an arrow key in the Defence window, you lose health depending on the type of arrow (basic white color = -1 HP, and so forth). If you fail to press an arrow key in the Mana window, there is no effect.

Arrows will only fall in the Spells window when you activate one of your spells with the number hotkeys, however, you must also have enough mana to cast the spell. Failing to press even a single arrow key in the Spells window will cause you to fail in casting it and you will not be refunded your mana. Spells are the way you damage your opponent, and you can also heal yourself. I believe you can only have 4 active spells at a time (you start with 2 slots and unlock more as you progress through the tower).

Between battles, you can craft and equip different items. There are 7 floors in the tower you wake up in, and you are given new crafting recipes as you reach new floors. One item will always give a permanent bonus (ex: +1 to offence), and others can be new spells, armor, or weapons. You can also scrap your items for experience points. When you craft, you have to pay exp. to increase the chance of success (you can even pay lose levels if you want to pay that much exp); if you fail, you are not refunded the exp. 

Levelling up is done automatically, you do not have to allocate skill points. 

As you progress through the game, monsters will have a unique "guardian ability" for each floor - for example, on the 2nd floor enemies (once per battle) can activate an ability that makes the falling arrow keys fade to invisibility as they reach the lower quarter of your window. Listening to the beat of the music really, really helps because the keystrokes tend to match the beat very well. With enough practice, you can even swap windows freely and continue pressing arrow keys to the beat. There is a craftable item for each floor that allows you to ignore guardian effects (except when you fight the bosses).

Boss battles are fun and the character's are pretty funny. Each boss will use their guardian effect more frequently, and you cannot negate it with the inhibition item. 

If you are interested in rhythm games, definitely pick up this fantastic game.

Highly recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025451288', 'num_games_owned': 833, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1077, 'last_played': 1407002528}
review:
A lot of love was put into this title, and I feel like it deserves due notice. My experience was on medium difficulty of someone who is not musically inclined, though I am a fan of rhythm games.

The RPG aspect of the title is somewhat limited. There's three equipment slots, but overall there's a clear progression of "this item is pretty much completely better than this other one," blandly increasing stats, though they -- like all the other items in the game -- may have punny item descriptions or names. The accessories slot, the third item slot, is interesting though -- if you ever find yourself needing certain items to progress, two later-game items let you increase your item drop rate at the cost of decreasing your stats, essentially. Or you can have a more unique attribute like doubling critical hit chance or decreasing spell cooldown. Leveling up is an across-the-board boost to your stats, but one interesting mechanic is in crafting -- you have to trade exp for chance to craft, exp is a currency. The level cap is 34, but you can beat the game in your mid-20s. I beat it at level 28 with relative ease compared to the grinding (more on that later).

Spells are acquired to directly combat enemies. They are all balanced differently (mana cost, damage, length of time to cast the spell, spell cooldown, difficulty of the arrow sequence) so there's plenty of choices in gameplay style. You can have a maximum of 6 spell slots to unload direct damage, damage over time, healing, and life-draining spells. There are also two buffing spells that boost the damage of the next spell, and a barrier spell to decrease the number of arrows thrown your way on the defence field. You can ALSO play the game significantly more aggresively by using the Convert spells to trade a bit of health for a load of mana, allowing you to ignore the defence and mana fields if you want to try your skill at hammering out life drain and heal spells in between Converts.

The rhythm aspect is definitely its strenth. The higher BPM, the more chaotic. Managing all three fields is ideal for defeating enemies within the time limit of the song and for the most fun in general, as you bounce seemlessly between defending, attacking, and recharging. On medium difficulty, it seems like the game is SIGNIFICANTLY more merciful: players do NOT have to have perfect coordination -- just have an arrow in the space of the outlines and you'll hit it. There's not "perfect" or "ok" score like in DDR to tell you how precise you were(n't). Perhaps this is changed in the higher difficulties, especially since the game mentions that players who are more musically inclined should play them.

One of the weaknesses of the game is definitely fatigue and pacing. For a rhythm game, there are NOT a lot of songs -- about 25 in total, including background music that isn't used in combat, when there are 7 floors of 3-4 enemies each with a boss on each floor. Before getting items to increase drop rate, you may spend 5+ fights on each enemy to acquire their drops. Even with decreasing the number of encounters, you will hear the same songs over and over again on different floors, though spaced out decently well so it's not completely repetitive. If you don't like the two artists who contribute 99% of the music or the combat system itself, then you will not enjoy this game for very long (I highly recommend checking out bits of the soundtrack; not every song is like Piano Jam or On Cue, they tend to be more like Super Fun or Derty).

The story starts off fairly cliche and parodying, but it develops over the course of the game. Voice acting is good regardless of content; as an indie game, it's interesting that the programmer/writer also voices the main character fairly well. I highly recommend sticking to it (assuming, of course, a seemingly weak story is the main sticking point to enjoying the game). The final boss throws a curveball into the setting if you didn't pick up the foreshadowing before, and there is a hidden ending. And, of course, perhaps you will enjoy the story throughout because of its humor; others have praised it, but I was ambivalent.

Overall, there's at least ten hours of gameplay, likely more for a 100% completion. It has a nice amount of replayability since the game allows you to change difficulty up to the third floor (wherein you should be able to decide the right difficulty for you), an incredibly low price, decent RPG mechanics, fairly unique rhythm mechanics, and servicable art (it's a rhythm game with THREE FIELDS, you have neither room nor need to show much more). A niche title as a rhythm game alone, but one of the best for those who want a rhythm game with progression. Buy it, especially if it's on sale for $2 like it was the Christmas I bought it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198062319230', 'num_games_owned': 834, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1409269109}
review: So far I've only played a few rounds, but I must say that I can already tell I will be playing this game to completion. I started off on medium and switched it to hard, at first I was a little bit surprised with the dramatic increase in dificulty, but it didn't take too long to catch on. I've played a ton of music rhythm games and generally play on expert. It should only take me a little time to get to that level on this game. As it does say in the tutorial you probably want to actually pay attention to the music since the timing is not very forgiving. Overall it seems fun and adds another level of urgency to a music rhythm game since you can switch from defensive/mana regen/spell casting with three seperate rhythm streams. Yeah, I'm glad as heck I picked this up from indiegala.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025128159', 'num_games_owned': 1163, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1432603030}
review:
Without a doubt one of the most rewarding rythm-based games I've ever played. The gameplay, the music, the script, the feel, all of it fits together wonderfully and even several years down the line I still credit this as one of my top 10 games. 

10/10 would DDR again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980699761', 'num_games_owned': 550, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1218, 'last_played': 1576166677}
review:
simply wonderful!

good story full with mystery. even though it is a ehythm game that required timing and flow it has smart RPG elements and unique game play. smart way to use leveling system. good gameplay. wonderful graphics and music (they just fit togather). 

what else do you want?

author: {'steamid': '76561198086043085', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1168, 'last_played': 1404835951}
review:
Sequence is one of the best music/rythim type games I ever played, pretty challenging with awesome music and a great great story, great level, background, character and monster design. I loved this game.

The actors were awesome, I enjoyed ''Ky'' voice but I just loved ''Naya'' voice.

I would suggest this game to anyone cause its a super well made game that everyone should play.

Also good to say that its a good game to get 100% achievements, does not require 2nd playthrough and its a very good experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969918459', 'num_games_owned': 1143, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1371086707}
review: This game is good but REAAAAAAALLY needs more songs. If the idea of grinding the same song way too much isn't a game breaker this is a fun game with some neat ideas that don't quite work.  Super weak recommendation but its cheap so whatever, if it sounds fun to you, get it. This would be really good if they made another game of similar length but without the padding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058278806', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1119, 'last_played': 1677778036}
review: RPG game design is blended incredibly well with rhythm gameplay to make a game unlike any other on the market. Would definitely recommend to anyone interested in RPGs who wants something a little different.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054731280', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1591044148}
review: A different sort of rhythm game, Sequence manages to incorporate some RPG elements into the gameplay. Sequence is a pretty fun game with solid soundtracks. The player has to battle enemies to get drops to build more equipment that provides bonuses, build new spells, or build a key to the next level. When battling enemies, there are three columns that the player must pay attention to; defense, attack, and mana. You take damage every time you let a stroke through defense, you attack by using a spell and hitting everything in the sequence in the attack column, and you get mana to cast more spells by hitting strokes in the mana column. A combination of solid music, unique gameplay, and a fun experience at a low price makes this game a recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061253036', 'num_games_owned': 684, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1404418246}
review:
Worst tutorial ever. Speech bubble; Click! Speech bubble; Click! Speech bubble; Click! After you done have this 40-100 times you are bored and have not played much and missed probably the important information of the tutorial. 
The actual gameplay is a like guitar hero only you have to change between 3  windows . For my taste it is realy difficult with a keyboard & mouse.
The presentaion is realy bad and consist mostly bad anime picture. The sound and songs are ok.

Den Soundtrack f√ºr dieses rhytmusbasierte Spiel (a'la "super crazy guitar maniac") w√ºrde ich nicht als gro√üartug, aber definitiv als gelungen / gut bezeichnen. Geschm√§cker sind halt verschieden.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979372295', 'num_games_owned': 2318, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1326268800}
review: This is an amazing game. RPG meets rhythm game meets pure awesome.  The voice acting is great, especially when you consider this is made by a very small team.  The soundtrack is excellent!  The story is good, with touches of humor and it gives you a reason to want to move forward (as if the great gameplay wasn't enough).  I'm not someone who typically plays rhythm games very much, and the thought of having 3 different screens where things were going on seemed to be way too much, but I'm glad I took a chance.  I got it for super cheap during a Holiday sale, but its easily worth 3 times the normal asking price.  I very highly recommend this game!  It'll always hold a fond place in my collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037418732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 4263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1870, 'last_played': 1667088896}
review:
This game is amazing.

It's not the best art. It's not that long. In fact, there's lots of things that it isn't.

But you know what it is?

Exactly what it's supposed to be.

It's rare to find a game nowadays that is precisely, utterly, and completely what it's trying to be. This is what indie gaming is capable of. This is what it's about. This game is a delightful romp of skill and story. I can only hope that you enjoyed it even half as much as I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049980773', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1404408125}
review: Honestly, this game has a lot of potential. The dialogue is funny and fast. The game style is very interesting and unique. However, the controls are clunky at best. Half the time I would hit an arrow, it misses. I've played this on both controller and keyboard with the same result. It badly needs some polishing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080382417', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1463421780}
review: alt+f4

author: {'steamid': '76561197977303636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1684198785}
review: The best rhythm game you'll ever play in your life.  Combines the falling notes element of rhythm games with some great RPG elements, which create a real, unique experience.  My only complaint is the grinding you need to do the unlock everything, though it's not really required.  Also, although I really enjoy the music in the game, by the end of the game I had pretty much heard enough, as the number of tracks are somewhat limited.  Still, a great game that's worth a pick-up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045529073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1404122418}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049665399', 'num_games_owned': 752, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1115, 'last_played': 1327305600}
review:
If you like rhythm games, this game is for you. You may satisfied playing Stepmania or Guitar Hero or what have you, but this is the real deal. It'll fill the void in your heart you didn't know you had.

Someone took a very good RPG, ripped out the battles and replaced with a dancing game and novel mechanics. This is a game within a game, and the developers nailed both of them. The visual novel style is not my type, and the game could have better replay value, but those flaws are compensated by the great story and solid gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998216057', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1404137753}
review: A very interesting blend of RPG and Rhythm game mechanics. The comedy, quirkiness and overall flow of the game really has its own unique charm. I recommend it for lovers of either genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987809189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1404047799}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023786857', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1504, 'last_played': 1383798175}
review: Sequence is a fun game for any rhythm gaming fans. It is not very complex graphics or story-wise but has some fun mechanics. If you are looking for a great music RPG this is probably not going to be your kind of game but if you enjoy basic rhythm games then go for it. The music is fantastic and the voice acting is pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037430125', 'num_games_owned': 979, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1403949652}
review:
Sequence es un RPG musical. Que combina combates con una mec√°nica estilo Stepmania o Guitar Hero, con un sistema de crafteo y de estad√≠sticas t√≠pico de los RPG.

Pros:
+La mec√°nica de combates me parece muy bien hecha y original, se divide en 3 paneles distintos para lanzar ataques, acumular man√° o defender, dando lugar a varias estrategias.
+Variedad de hechizos y estrategias para el combate.
+La historia empieza un poco t√≠pica, pero mejora un poco, sin ser una maravilla.
+El a√±adir el sistema de estad√≠sticas t√≠pico de los RPG, te permite ajustar el nivel de una fase si est√°s atascado.

Contras:
-Escasez de canciones, creo que apenas hay unas 6 o 8, que adem√°s no son mi estilo musical.
-No se puede cambiar la dificultad desde el piso 3 hasta acabar el juego, as√≠ que juega en un nivel que te resulte realmente f√°cil de primeras, porque el juego se complica.
-Si bien el sistema de crafteo y drops est√° bien pensado, le falta profundidad, y termina en una mec√°nica de grindear el objeto de ese piso que es mejor que el que ten√≠as, muy lineal y predecible.

Duraci√≥n: unas 8-12 horas, no le veo rejugabilidad.

review:
8.75/10

I love DDR. I absolutely love DDR... and I am good at it. Imagine my surprise when I heard that there was a game like DDR on Steam? Instant buy. Sequence has surpassed DDR in pushing and developing my skills. You think you are good at DDR? Try it while having to switch between 3 screens and planning out tactics. That is the beauty of Sequence. Only reason I did not rate this game higher is the short story (but good replayability) and the fact that there isn't a Sequence Sequel. <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198051077030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1403828732}
review:
Un m√©lange entre un RPG et du DDR; tuer des monstres en faisant du stepmania, que demander de plus ?

On ne peut malheureusement pas jouer seulement avec des tapis de DDR, il faut remaper soit m√™me les touches, et on est oblig√© d'avoir un clavier dans la main pour lancer les sorts. √áa rend quand m√™me le jeu assez fun, mais bien plus compliqu√© (en difficile il ne faut m√™me pas y penser). Mais au clavier il se fait aussi tr√®s bien !

Le seul probl√®me √©tant qu'il faut parfois farmer les montres pour avoir tous les drops, et les musiques bien qu'excellentes deviennent assez lassante au bout de la 10e fois.

Sinon une dizaine d'heures de jeu pour seulement 4 euros. Si vous avez un peu squatt√© stepmania ou DDR, il ne faut vraiment pas h√©siter !

author: {'steamid': '76561198112057736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1395892910}
review:
Goodness... where do I start? Bought Sequence as part of a Humble Bundle. It's a little confusing and very repetitive. Switching between the different "boards" to deploy attacks and defend gets really dull after a while. It just doesn't seem to have any substance. 

Also, the voice over that explains gameplay has the most irritating and contrived dialogue I've ever heard.

review: Mt legal os dialogos e a mecanica nerd d jogabilidade musical. Pra kem jogava uns game asiatico tipo o2jam e pump nao vai achar mt dificil, mas no modo hard eh osso. Vc tem 3 telas q vai descendo os comandos, e uma delas eh kuando vc vai dar o atake q vc nao pode errar nenhuma nota da sequencia. Vc vai alternando entre as 3 telas na hora q kiseh (uma enche a mana, outra eh defesa e outra eh o atake). Esse eh o skema d combate. As musicas nao sao tao tops, mas o game eh bem original e cheio d humor. Recomendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082187634', 'num_games_owned': 616, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 542, 'last_played': 1419800725}
review:
I remember buying this for the Xbox, it was a load of funfetti, and it still is on the PC. Going for a Stepmania(DDR) RPG sort of feel, it features a variety of techie songs to listen to (Ronald Jenkees is a beast) and beautiful artwork, for you know, still images.

Definitely worth Five bucks (or less).

author: {'steamid': '76561198041768497', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1403627496}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994463223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 905, 'last_played': 1640194217}
review: Do you like RPGs with a healthy dose of tongue-in-cheek comedy, and a sarcastic sense of self-awareness?  Do you enjoy Flash Flash Revolution?  Do you have fun with action based strategy?  If you answered one of these questions "yes", Sequence is probably worth the $5 it costs.  If you answered "yes" to all three of these questions, Sequence will devour your free time for the fairly brief (compared to other RPGs) duration of the game.  I would go so far as to say that this is the greatest Strategy Music RPG in the history of gaming (though to be fair, that may be due to a lack of representation of the genre).

author: {'steamid': '76561198005182411', 'num_games_owned': 806, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1471478379}
review:
Picked this game up in a humble bundle, and have just finished it recently. I was an enjoyable experience, with a new twist on the standard Rthymn game formula. The music is fun to listen and battle two, with appealing artwork covering the entire game. It also helps that the entire game is fully voice acted.

If you like Rthymn games, be sure to give this gem a play. And good luck in the Tower.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999043347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1409289231}
review:
DDR/Frequency/Amplitude with an RPG twist. 

If you have ever been a fan of rhythm games, particularly those by Harmonix, you (hopefully) have come across the Frequency/Amplitude series. With its rapid track-switching gameplay, it was a unique and underappreciated entry in gaming history. Now, Sequence takes the track switching mechanic, applies simple DDR-style controls, and turns it into a monster-fighting RPG. It might sound crazy, but this is probably one of the best genre hybrids since Puzzle Fighter or Bust-a Move.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045647819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1574955080}
review: I reallly enjoy rhythm games and this is an interesting take on the classic genre. I find the rpg elements flesh it out to make it an enjoyable experinece for a variety of gamers. I find the the controls are weird on keyboard, but that can be fixed if you use a controller. This means the game is more optimized for XBOX 360 controllers, so buyers beware if you only use keyboard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048154425', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1995, 'last_played': 1434009385}
review:
If I had to describe Sequence in one word it would be this: Fun. But I'm not going describing it in one word. I'm going to describe it in as many words as I can--and--hopefully in the clearest way possible. As the trailers will tell you Sequence is a lot like a DDR game. It has a great mix of rhythm and rpg elements laced within 4.99 (and as I write this review, 1.99) dollars of pure fun. The games mechanics sound difficult at first but once you get a grasp of them it really is just like a dance stepping game (dance stepping...yeah). You have three different fields, Magic, Defense, and Mana that you must use to defend yourself against a selection of creative monsters and even more creative (or perhaps creative-er...if that were a word) bosses in order to solve four things: Where are you? Who took you to said where? Who is this chick talking to you over an intercom system? Why the heck is there an intercom system in what looks to be a tower straight from a fantasy game? 
The games plot: You are a young man named Ky, a university student who was brought to some unknown world where each wrong move could essentially be your last. But not to worry though! A very slick talking female voice is there to help you through your adventure through conveluted tower. With her aid you'll hopefully beat all fo the bosses and get to the 7th floor of the tower and...well...that's all the game tells you.
One thing I will tell you though is if you are looking for closure this isn't the game for that. The ending to this game isn't bad--no I found it highly satisfying. But it felt very cliff hanger...y for a game that as of right now is just a one shot. I assume this is so it can have some kind of sequel. Something I personally have my fingers crossed for. The music is wonderful, I'd never heard of Ronald Jenkins before this game and let me tell you I'm glad I did. Go ahead and look up his music to get a taste of what you'll hear in-game. 
As with any grinding rpg you may find yourself feeling a bit bored from the repetitive fights, forging of materials through recipies and other little minute chores you have to do in the game. But I personally believe the music is what helps bring it together. Nothing ever really FEELS like a chore in this game. The monsters are relatively balanced, after you defeat and gather what you need for a boss you will feel like top dog for a few brief moments before getting brought back down a peg or two from the next monster one floor up. The only complaint I have is that the particle effect is too much for my computer and has a tendency to lag and affect your rhythm. This could just be my computer though. The dialogue is very well versed and thought out. Smooth gameplay mechanics and you rarely feel any mistakes made is anything but your own. 
And the item descriptions. Oh the item descriptions. 
Needless to say, I have a bit of a bias for this game and I want anyone reading this to take that in terms with this review. This is a very niche kind of game. If you love DDR games you'll love this to death I'm sure. But I do recommend checking it out for its low price alone.

Update: This game still holds up. Though its 2010 culture references can seem a bit forced at times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031725194', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 1607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 943, 'last_played': 1465073996}
review:
Sequence is a Hybrid of a Rhythm game and an RPG. 
Every combat is done in the way of a rhythm game like, say, Guitar Hero. With each battle you gain experience, materials and equipment, which you can all use to become more powerful, and face harder enemies, progressing through the story.
That may or may not seem like it works for you, but trust me, they've done a damn fine job with it!

You're Ky, and you wake up in a Tower, with amnesia. Everything inside feels like a weird game in which you're but a pawn. You life is in danger, or so you're told, and so you fight for survival, learning about the place and its purposes on the way.

While the story did feel a bit cheesy for the most part, it did have a few cool ideas, and a few twists to keep it interesting. It's not the main focus on the game, but I think it added quite a lot of character to it. 



There's not much in way of graphic style in this one. 
The graphics consist mainly of hand drawn backgrounds and characters, with a bit of animation when they talk. It's not bad, by any means, just not something that you'll play this game for.
Even during the battles, each spell you cast (more on that later) only produces a few sparkles as visual effects, but it's just enough not to feel empty. All in all, it's very simple, and let's you focus on the gameplay, while maintaining an appealing look. 
The only criticism I have of it is that certain spells will overload the screen with particles, obstructing necessary information.

Another thing, regarding the interface. Outside of battle it's nothing special, but it's certainly easy to navigate. But when in-battle, it gives you every bit of information necessary without having to look for it too hard. And this is a great since, since this game WILL challenge your multi-tasking abilities (in a good way!).
Good job on that! Keeping it simple, yet complete.


I would now talk about the music, but music and gameplay are directly tied in Sequence. So I'll try to summarize gameplay and then talk about its strengths and weaknesses.

As I said before, you're in a Tower. You're guided by Naia, who gives you recipes as you go along.
You go from floor to floor, with a Boss Fight in the end of each.
When you enter a floor, you'll be given recipes for Equipment, Spells, and a Key and Inhibitor for that floor. There are 3 enemies in each, which drop 3 different materials, for you to craft later. When you craft the key, you're able to unlock the door to the next floor, and fight the Guardian.

Your characters has Mana (to cast spells), Health, Defense (to lower the damage you take), and Offense (to increase the damage you deal through spells).
You can improve these either by leveling up, or by wearing different pieces of equipment. Equipment is mainly linear in its progression, without many sidegrades. 
Trinkets, on the other hand, are a bit different. These can improve your spells' cost, their cooldown, make battles harder to improve item drops, etc. These are actually more tailored for different types of gameplay, and some have pretty cool effects.
Some you get by crafting, others you can get by enemy drops.

The Inhibitor is used to lower the Guardians' effects (more on that later).

Then, there are spells. You can craft them, and then have to learn them. How do you learn them? You play a certain track on the game, with an added challenge (which can be a note streak, or a given accuracy). These are carefuly designed, as they would be in Guitar Hero, with different button presses following the notes' pattern (to an extent, of course).
They weren't too hard, mostly. But the final one was way more challenging, but also very fun to play, so I won't complain.

This pretty much it for when you're outside the battles.

How are the battles, then?
Well, there will be arrows falling, to the beat, and you'll have to press them. Pretty simple. But that's not all, of course.
(There are single notes, or doubles. For these, you have 2 sets of "arrows" on the controller/keyboard, to make it easier, specially on a controller. It works really well, and you'll find yourself a master of it by the end, and it feels great! The game does a very good way to constantly challenge you, making you better, without being frustrating.)

In every battle, you have 3 screens you need to pay attention to. 
One, is your Defense screen. Each arrow you miss here will damage you, so you need to keep an eye on it.
Another one is your Mana screen. This one has the same spell learning pattern, making it the closest to the song, with a lot more notes. Each failed note doesn't penalize you, but you gain one Mana for each note you strike, which is needed to cast spells.
Finally, you have your Spell screen. You have a spell wheel, with your different spells (you have a limited number that you choose outside the battles). Each has a different effect and costs more/less mana, with a bigger/lesser cooldown.
Each time you activate a spell, its notes will start dropping. The spell is cast if you strike them all. If you fail a single on, bye bye mana.

That's it, mostly. Your objective is to lower your opponent's life before he does yours. Every piece of information (damage dealt, received, mana, etc.) is easily visible to you, which is great.
You will be constantly switching between these 3 screens during the battles, which sometimes gets a bit chaotic at later stages, but never too bad. The whole game is a constant balance between when you can afford to take damage, when you need mana, and so on, rarely feeling stale!
With each enemy is a song associated, so you'll repeat some on them quite a lot for their items/experience, but it's not too grindy.

One more important aspect is the Guardians! Each one has a special ability, that'll mess you up, during their fight, and the fights in their floor. 
These can go from obstructing your different screens (so that you need to be there to see what's happening) to accelerating the tempo of the songs, or the last one, that switches the arrows. This one was diabolical. Everything you had learned goes to hell, and you need to play everything in reverse. But it doesn't last long, so it's all good. 
It's these differences that keep some of the battles very interesting, and you never know when it might throw you off of your comfort zone! 


The music was done by DJPlaeskool and Ronald Jenkees. It's a mix of electronic/synth music, with a bit of rock. It's wasn't something I was into at the start of the game, but it started growing on me. I ended up enjoying the music quite a bit, although I won't listen to most of it outside the game. 
Although, the last song, and so freaking epic... Man, I wasn't expecting that. That song had changes in tempo that worked great musically and from a gameplay standpoint! (It's called Piano Jam, search it on youtube). That one I'll be listening to for a while. Great job!

So, I enjoyed the music, but I do believe it lacks a bit in replayability comparatively with other rhythm games. But it's also a very unique and very well designed game. I ended up enjoying it way more than I expected, and it had many brilliant design choices. 
There isn't much negative to say about it, really, aside from having to grind a bit, and perhaps looking a bit too simple. But even that didn't really lower the experience much for me.

I really enjoyed Sequence, and I think it does a great job of mixing the rhythmic combat and RPG elements.
One thing though, is that during the battles, while the notes do fall on the beat, there isn't as big of a connection to the notes and there is on the Mana screen (or the spell learning). Each spell has a pattern (with some random elements) that is independent of the song, and the enemies as well. So, it might not feel like like you're playing the music.
But I don't think it detracts from it too much, and those modes are still present.

Sequence is surprisingly great!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009490585', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1478817265}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014937507', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2859, 'last_played': 1462543612}
review:
A fun RPG/Rhythm game hybrid (with several difficulty levels if, like me, you suck at reflex-based gameplay). 

Nice art and music, intriguing plot and great dialogues. The writing is clever and meta, and while the game is short it still finds the time to whip up some fun characters and even has room for character development.
Some replayability since the gameplay is just super fun, but more (and different....) music tracks would have been nice.
The plot ends with a bigger mystery highlighted and the promise of something more, without giving answering all your questions. Note that as the title suggests, there is a sequel (There Came An Echo) which... does a pretty underwhelming job of tying this game's loose ends. 

But hey, the writing really is fun and this game got me into rhythm games, so i still recommend it. It's also really cheap for all that content :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198047678253', 'num_games_owned': 1115, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1482588008}
review: Sequence blends a ton of ideas together, and does a wonderful job of it. It has an engrossing story with believable characters, great gameplay mechanics, the ability to alter your approach to the challenges they give you, and has great music to boot. As a guy who's not too into music and rhythm games, the RPG elements really made me stick with the game, because even if the challenge seemed too great, I knew I could go back to previous floors to get enough XP to give me the small boost I needed, or else just to hone my skills. Though I didn't sit down and play the entire game in one sitting, I found myself coming back to the game once I had started it, which in itself speaks greatly of its quality. In short, I want to thank Iridium for making such a good game, as well as releasing it as part of a Humble Bundle. I'll be keeping an eye out for future releases!

review: Fairly shallow gameplay that would be fine for a small amount of amusement if progression wasn't tied to a completely random drop system. Fought one enemy five times in a row with a 54% drop rate and got nothing all five times. Would maybe have forced my way through if there was a way to increase chances of drops but even then the game is essentially nine hours of grinding. Life's too short for this shit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986902042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1398974457}
review:
Sequence is a rhythm game/RPG hybrid. Now, before you scroll past this review, hold up a sec. I never liked rhythm games either, and I'm having a blast with Sequence.

Why, you ask? Well, the whole rhythm part of the game blends seamlessly with the RPG aspect. Your character has an inventory, stats and all that RPG jazz (though no choice and consequence so it's not a REAL RPG!), and from his equipment and statistics come his fighting abilities. Ky (the hero) fights with spells, casting them at his enemy if you input the correct rhythm sequence. He also has to defend and regain mana, also done by inputting the correct rhythm. Now, while he's casting spells, he can't defend or regain mana, unless you quickly switch screens during your rhythm input, a tactic which is unnecessary in the beginning but becomes more and more vital as the game goes on, and spells start to have pauses between their prompts.

This whole combination of RPG and rhythm game is brought with wonderful humour. Don't expect silly puns, lazy groaners or pretentious in-jokes, the game just approaches everything with a healthy and snarky brand of humour, from the dialogues to the item descriptions. Of course, since it's a rhythm game, the music is a very important element, and it doesn't disappoint. You'll hear a lot of it, but it never bores. The composers enlisted by Iridium to score the game have done a great job, and all the music is extremely engaging to listen to.

Again, don't be surprised if you find yourself gnashing your teeth at the screen in the beginning. Once you learn to correctly input the prompts by listening to the music, instead of visually, you'll find it becomes a lot more manageable and you'll improve in leaps. And once that happens, you'll have awesome fun with it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198057341071', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1395654069}
review: I got this from Humble Bundle and it's sad to say that I didn't like it at all. It started off as a good game, doing training and all, but then come the RPG elements. Then the game became boring. Incredibly boring. The idea of combining Rhythm and RPG was not a good idea at all. The monsters have little variety, becomes very repetitive and the synth system is messed up. Though, I will admit that the music is actually very good and catchy. Aside from that though, it's not really a good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004610653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 952, 'last_played': 1397538929}
review:
I received this game as part of one of the Humble Bundles, and I'm glad I did!  I really enjoyed this game, and I would highly recommend it.  :)  I also think it is worth the $5 on Steam.  

To give you a general idea of this game, it is similar to Step Mania only with an actual storyline.  If you don't know what Step Mania is, it's basically DDR (dance dance revolution) for the PC.  However, Sequence is kind of refreshing because it isn't just arrows flying up the screen to music.  In this game, you have three different sets of arrows that travel down the screen, and you have to switch between the sets.  One is your defense, one is your attack/magic, and the other is your mana.  This keeps things interesting and sometimes challenging (depending on the difficulty).  Yes, you are battling enemies instead of "dancing" to music like you would in Step Mania.

The storyline is excellent!  There are a few plot twists that you will not see coming, and the characters are very likeable.  The dialogue is probably one of my favorite parts of the storyline, and it had me laughing a few times.  The script is usually spot-on for some things that members of our generation would say.

As for the music, I like most of the music, but it gets very repetitive very fast.  You'll play through the same songs over and over.  Be prepared for that!  

The achievements are very reasonable, and there is no reason why you shouldn't be able to get all but one or two during your first play-through (unless you are doing the bare-minimum to get by).  There is one achievement, however, that you will not be able to get on your own unless you know a little computer programming.  That is slightly unfair in my opinion, but it is what it is.  If you do have knowledge of programming, you'll probably pick-up on it rather easily if you happen to see the right part.

As for the difficulties, I played through medium.  Throughout most of it, that was way too easy for me.  There were a few battles later on where I did have a challenge.  The good news is that you are allowed to change the difficult through the first three "floors" of the game.  However, things don't get super difficult until you get to the final floor.  If you happen to lose a battle, you still gain experience in most small battles.  You are also given a chance to repeat with no penalties.  This is actually really nice, especially in those bigger challenges.  However, it may make the game a little too easy for some of you hardcore gamers.  

Overall, this is a nice, short game that I would recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003132759', 'num_games_owned': 1573, 'num_reviews': 186, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1397254061}
review:
Although flawed, Sequence remains enjoyable enough to play through to the end. 

Its concept is a neat one, combining rhythm and RPG elements. The interface looks a little confusing at first, but it is easy to get to grips with and offers interesting tactical challenges - it's a constant choice between spells, defence and mana gathering, and a split-second choice to sacrifice one for another can prove costly.

The best aspect is the writing and voice acting which are highly entertaining and make it compelling to play to the end. The third floor boss made me laugh more than any game character has in a long time.

The main weakness is that it can be very grindy - you have to use drops and pay XP to craft items, meaning you have to fight the same monster over and over again to get the items (each with a different percentage chance of dropping) and XP you need. The music is also nothing particularly special for a game built around music.

Still, the positives outweigh the negatives. Definitely worth a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054971917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1586384813}
review:
This game is surprisingly addictive. While other indie games like Limbo, Braid, etc., may make a better first impression with their stark visual style and challenging gameplay, Sequence is the game I find myself coming back to the most. It's just plain fun. The game has amazing replay value, too. The different difficulty settings mean you can always give yourself a new challenge, and if you happen to be lucky enough to own a PC compatible dance pad or guitar, then there are even more ways to play it, too.

I'm not a huge fan of rhythm, but I was pulled in by the game's deep strategy. There is a lot more to this game than just pressing buttons to the beat! In fact, there is so much more to it that it might be off-putting or confusing to some people. In order to be successful, you have to be good at multi-tasking, and there is no such thing as a perfect run on the songs (due to the three-screen system, missing some notes is inevitable).

The music is good, with all the tracks distinctive and crisp. The art style is so-so. Another interesting feature of this already interesting game is the story. With a game like this, I really would have expected a tacked-on story or even none at all. However, the developer put in a decent effort to make an engaging tale with a few twists and turns. It didn't blow me away, but it is by no means terrible. It's a little above standard visual novel quality, and while I wouldn't reccomend playing the game for the story alone, I think quite a few players will be pleasantly surprised by just how good it is.

All-in-all, one of my favorite indie games. I'm a little sad that more people haven't played this game, as it is a fresh take on both RPG and rhythm games. Definitely needs more love!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999304281', 'num_games_owned': 1369, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1457897717}
review:
Sequence: 8.5/10

The first thing I‚Äôd like to touch upon is the engaging gameplay. Think Guitar Hero, but more complex; directional arrows will fall from the screen and you must match them at the bottom, to the beat of the song. But where it becomes more complicated is that there‚Äôs ‚Äúthree screens‚Äù ‚Äì one for offense (casting spells, which lowers your opponents health, heals you, etc.), one for mana (which is the resources for spells), and defense (in which you counter your opponent‚Äôs attacks; if you match the arrows, you don‚Äôt take damage, but if you don‚Äôt, you take damage equal to what the arrow is worth). This leads to a very fun experience, because you must decide on the fly if you want to cast X spell at that time, while managing mana and seeing if you want to finish that spell, or negate the damage incoming to you, etc. The spell must be finished completely, without mistake, to be cast; if you mess up one note, it doesn‚Äôt do anything, so the more rewarding the spell, the more difficult to pull off. I am not ashamed to admit that I had to shelf my ‚Äúbest‚Äù healing spell for a moderate heal because I could never pull it off. The game is at its best when you‚Äôre on equal terms with your opponent, having to juggle mana, spells, and defense. Unfortunately, the difficulty isn‚Äôt always there, and I‚Äôve been able to literally completely ignore defense and just go for mana and spells. This is okay when the enemy is essentially a ‚Äúgear check‚Äù, so to speak, but it happened more than I‚Äôd like. The game has seven floors (perhaps more, I‚Äôm currently on floor six of a stated seven), and each floor has a ‚Äúspecial power‚Äù (that is designed to hinder you) for each fight: for the sixth floor, for example, you can‚Äôt see the screens you‚Äôre not currently selecting. Another power is that you‚Äôre unable to switch screens until the timer is expired, so you better make sure you‚Äôre on the defensive screen, or you‚Äôre going to be taking a lot of damage. 

 I would like to note that I was very surprised at how well the (controller, never tested the keyboard) controls worked; I was swapping screens and hitting notes effortlessly, and I can count the amount of times I was disoriented / confused on my hand. 

Being a rhythm game, the music is important, and Sequence delivers. I‚Äôd like to note that I enjoy it so much I‚Äôll be throwing the tracks on my iPod for repeated listening. Said tracks are varied so it‚Äôs not just the same type of music, although I do wish there was more variety when you‚Äôre grinding; hearing the same song all the time on the same enemy did kind of get on my nerves. But, still, they‚Äôre good songs, so I don‚Äôt mind much. For each song, the tempo dictates how the notes are going to hit you: if it‚Äôs a slow song, there‚Äôll be fewer notes, but they‚Äôll count for more, while the opposite is true for frantic music.  

While the story does exist, it‚Äôs not very engaging. I am ‚Äì as I‚Äôm sure a lot of others are ‚Äì tired of the main character waking up and not knowing what‚Äôs going on / amnesia / what-have-you. The dialog between the main character and your ally is often amusing (they‚Äôve had discussions which includes 4chan, ‚Äú‚Ä¶like a Disney without hidden sexual innuendo, they were missing something‚Äù, etc.) that I‚Äôve forgiven the absence of the story. And, without spoilers, the dialog made me care for the plot development about two-thirds of the way through the game, so the plot is a lot better than most games in this genre.

My largest complaint is the grinding required to advance in the story. I am at heart an RPG-enthusiast, so I really don‚Äôt mind grinding ‚Äì usually I enjoy it. Sequence, however, doesn‚Äôt pull grinding off very well, though. The game employs a crafting element to the game, which is required to use to advance. You can craft items such as permanent health increases, items that disable the hindering ‚Äúspecial powers‚Äù that each floor uses against you, and, most importantly, key items that allow you to challenge the boss for that specific floor. To get these specific items, you must defeat certain enemies, and upon defeating them, you have a percentage chance to get one of three items that they carry. This wouldn‚Äôt be so bad, except you must often get a 25% drop from multiple enemies, and this quickly becomes annoying when they pose no threat to you. Without said grinding, however, the game would be at least half as long, so I don‚Äôt mind it too much‚Ä¶but enough to complain about it. ;)

Another small complaint is the difficulty curve. In the beginning, it was about perfect for me and my difficulty setting (I chose the default ‚Äúnormal‚Äù difficulty), since I wasn‚Äôt fully aware of how to time the notes and how the game worked, etc. Then floors two through five didn‚Äôt give me many problems‚Ä¶and then the sixth floor is kicking my ass. I feel like they‚Äôre trying to prolong the game with unnecessarily high ‚Äúgear checks‚Äù at this point. This would be more forgivable if said difficulty curve was more spread out and not super noticeable after having a very easy time previously.

Overall, I am very impressed with this gem of a game that I paid $1 for (among two other solid games). In fact, I like it so much that I played five straight hours of it one day, and am planning on putting all of the songs on my iPod to listen to later. 

While there are some small flaws in my eyes, the positives far outweigh the negatives. 

TL:DR = 8.5/10; 
Pro = Gameplay is very fun, music is great, fun dialog.
Con = Unnecessarily long, RNG-reliant grinding, spiked difficulty curve.

[I played this game offline; I have eight hours logged as of posting.]

author: {'steamid': '76561198004663985', 'num_games_owned': 2730, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1395839464}
review: Sequence is an rhythm game with rpg elements. The problem is that it has boring music for a rhythm game and the rpg elements make the game repetitive. The game start out with an annoyingly dragged out tutorial which could be way shorter. What's great is that you can play with different controllers that include usb guitars.

review:
A good mix of rhythm and RPG games. A little bit challenging and story-rich.
However, there are just a few tracks in this game (like only 20 or so), so it may be a little bit repetitive.

Tips: You should play with a keyboard, and change the control settings to place the arrow keys next to each other
(I used A as left, S as down, D as up and F as right) and the game will surely be much easier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024805655', 'num_games_owned': 607, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1395598333}
review:
Wow. Sequence, we've got a lot to talk about.

Sequence is basically a DDR/ITG + RPG mashup, which may sound odd, but it works pretty fluently. Even as someone who's been an avid fan of the four-arrow dance games for over a decade, it took me a while to get fully accommodated with Sequence's unique gameplay.

However, one thing I certainly did not expect from a game like this was a compelling plot with brilliantly well-written and fully voiced characters. Sequence's story gives the game a [i]lot[/i] of depth and was probably the driving factor for me. Definitely a huge highlight of this game.

I could nit pick for quite a while, though. The music isn't anything extraordinary, it can be a bit grindy at times (as both item crafting and item drops are chance based), and the battle interface could use a little bit of work to make it easier to see what spells are ready, what the mana cost is, how much you have at the time, etc. Since I played with the keyboard, having all the tutorials and controls based around a 360 controller was also a tad confusing.

Sequence is pretty fun and I would recommend it to rhythm game/RPG fans or people who enjoy a really good story.

review: This is basically everything it should be. The soundtrack is great, the gameplay is challenging without being ridiculous, it's certainly unique as well. The plot is a bit forgettable and there's a bit of "grinding" but to be fair "grinding" in a rhythm game is far more enjoyable than in any standard RPG. I dove right in on the highest difficulty being a DDR/stepmania veteran and found it to be indeed quite challenging, though occasionally there was an enemy type much above what I'd actually be able to defeat mixed in with two easier ones, for whatever reason. Very enjoyable game overall, my thoughts are kind of jumbled since it's been quite a long time since I finished it though.
