author: {'steamid': '76561198077716958', 'num_games_owned': 1182, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3323, 'last_played': 1429416236}
review:
This game is amazing. I loved the music, the range of beats, and the story itself engaged me in a way I would have never expected from this kind of game. I found myself playing more to advance the story than for the challenge of actually performing well in the battles although, with practice, that comes easily too.

After playing Sequence, I'd be willing to try any game by Iridium Studios.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008230359', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1394017318}
review: I gave this game a second chance. This game is much easier played with a controller than a keyboard since the game has some fairly complex controls. The rhythm is pretty nice and it has a decent yet small selection of songs. The game is a bit of a grindfest. The object of the game is to grind songs by defeating the same monsters over and over to make keys to progress from level to level. It's kinda like RPG meets Stepmania. The music is not bad though it gets recycled a lot. The best part about this game is the humor. The voice acting and cutscenes are funny and the flavor text on items will make you chuckle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992536847', 'num_games_owned': 1969, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1384328539}
review:
Sequence is an entirely unique game which combines rhythm gaming with RPG mechanics. Three boards drop arrows simultaneously in a DDR fashion - one for attack, one for defense, and one for regeneration of mana with which to attack further. The player rotates between the boards while pressing the arrows in time with music in order to win the battle, gain experience and items, craft weapons, and learn new spells.

It's quite fun, if a bit short. The voice acting is quite solid for a budget title, the music is fairly good, and the graphics are perfectly serviceable if quite static - however, for the type of game it is, that doesn't get in the way.

The story gets a little odd (if predictably so) towards the end, but all in all, I had a lot of fun throughout. It's more for rhythm game fans than RPG fans, as those mechanics are the dominant ones, but it's definitely worth a look if you want to try something different.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990299177', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1393394839}
review:
I had to stop after beating the first guardian, laughing too much.

But seriously, it's a pretty good game, so far. It's easy enough to get into, difficult to master, but fun regardless, with the witty banter between Ky and Shepard (Wrex).

Not sure how much it'll have in terms of replay value, other than maybe enjoing the music and spell specific runs, but for four dollars and ninenty-nine cents? It's got a lot to offer.

I will admit, however, it is somewhat difficult to play on the pc. But it can be done and I intend to enjoy every time I beat Derpfish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052109022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1679697971}
review: Think DDR with a keyboard. Sounds fun yeah? It is. I played through this game using the Easy mode, and it sometimes was a bit too easy, even though I've never played DDR-on-a-keyboard-game. It was interesting with a sort of lackluster story, witty dialogue, fun gameplay, and mediocre art. The characters and dialogue were pretty funny and entertaining, which helped staple this game together a bit better. It had me laughing at some of the item descriptions, names, and thoughts of characters. The only thing that literally had me banging my head against the desk and wishing it to stop was the fact that the music was so limited. There were 3-4 songs per level, and you sometimes had to play them over and over to harvest materials. And also a limited number of artists. I get it, it sucks to pay for licensing, but when the majority of your game requires that you listen to music while pecking at a keyboard, you might want to make sure you get a few more songs. I found myself taking breaks because I was literally sick of the same songs over and over again. I wish this game had more songs, because it was pretty fun to play. I'd give it a higher review if I didn‚Äôt physically flinch every time I heard a note that was similar to "Stay Crunchy". 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198021204633', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1639, 'last_played': 1400079239}
review:
Similar to Stepmania and Dance Dance Revolution but entirely unique in its own way. Sequence offers an entirely new idea to the practice of pressing arrow keys by utilizing three different windows for different game mechanics. These include The Attack window where you can ready your attack against your foe, The Defense window allowing you to nullify your opponents' attacks, and the all important Mana window with the ability to regenerate mana, which is used to cast spells.

The game includes an emotive storyline which will lead the player through he many mysteries that await the protagonist and his 'Shephard'. While keeping the modern-day theme, Sequence maintains a healthy dosage of humour whilst keeping al seriousness intact.

When I played this game the music amazed me, it's hard to believe that a game can have so many good soundtracks, and with the game costing so little it's a wonder why more people don't buy it simply for the music. I give this game a 10/10 for originality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072355732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1666518065}

author: {'steamid': '76561198085424314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1322, 'last_played': 1392364136}
review: So like you're this guy named Ky and you wake up in a tower [strike]of power[/strike] wondering where the hell you are. Suddenly, a voice rings out and it's from a girl named Naia, who is pretty chill but willing to sass Ky whenever he acts like a nerd (which is often). She teaches him how to harness the power of DDR-like magic in order to defend himself because if he doesn't, then he ends up dead. Being dead is pretty bad, so try to avoid that. As Ky climbs up the tower, he runs into weirdoes who possess the power to screw with his playing field in increasingly annoying ways. There's a lot of puns, references, and wordplay in the game, which can be a dealbreaker if you're some scrub who can't deal with it/ignore it. You, the player, must guide Ky in his journey to find out who put him in the tower, why he's there, and who Naia is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972854156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1616643587}
review:
There are a couple of very good reasons to play Sequence. Firstly, the gameplay is spot on. Like most rhythm games you are simply required to hit buttons in time to the music, but Sequence has some interesting mechanics. You have three lanes of incoming notes that you can switch between at any time. One of them is defensive; any notes you miss here deplete your health. In another lane you must time your button presses to increase your mana, which is used for spellcasting. The third lane is for the spells themselves. Once you cast a spell you need to hit a short sequence of notes in this lane for the spell to actually take effect.

This leads to quite a frenetic experience where you're constantly shifting between offense and defense. It can be frustrating and it takes some getting used to, but once you get the hang of it, it's pure gaming bliss that rivals the old classic Amplitude, not to mention Guitar Hero.

The other, and possibly more significant, reason to play this game is the music. Much of the music is provided by Ronald Jenkees, a man of prodigious melodic talent. I've played Sequence for a good few hours, but I've spent much, much more time listening to the music of Jenkees. It's truly phenomenal, and even if you have no interest in this game I'd recommend checking it out.

Sequence is not perfect. There are RPG elements, and while they work well enough I can't help thinking that so, so much more could have been done with them. I'm put in mind of Puzzle Quest, another game which combined RPG elements with a totally different style of game, but did it in a much more dynamic way. Perhaps the makers of Sequence didn't have the time or resources to go that far, but I do believe they could have come up with something a little more compelling that repetitive grind they've got in this game. Maybe for the sequel?

author: {'steamid': '76561197967360372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1407006284}
review: Surprisingly addictive.  Extremely easy game to get lost in the zone, and really easy to find yourself going '... just one more battle before bed.'  If you enjoy rhythm and music games AT ALL, this is one you should definitely try out.  Keeping track of three different rows of falling arrows seems overwhelming at first, but once you get into it, you'll be switching screens without thinking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050370657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 893, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1391784980}
review: One of the best rhythm games out there. Combines an awesome soundtrack by Ronald Jenkees with very unique and fun gameplay. You have 3 DDR-like "boards" playing at the same time, one where enemies deal damage to you if you miss the notes, one that you can miss that lets you build mana, and one that only starts playing when you have a spell to cast. The game includes RPG elements in the form of item drops and crafting (which gets you more spells and more ways to get an advantage over enemies). Also has some nice art, decent story and entertaining characters. Would definitely recommend for its current price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983725374', 'num_games_owned': 4710, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1262, 'last_played': 1680770965}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003213131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 591, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1391187273}
review:
Bon sequence √ßa va √™tre rapide, voici quelques petits trucs que le trailer ne montre pas et mon ressenti.

Tout d'abord en voyant le trailer je me suis dit :
oh on dirai du guitar heroes !
oh y a des √©l√©ments de rpg !
oh y a une histoire ! (non √ßa c'√©tait pour pas m'arr√™t√© √† 2 oh ... !)

me suis dit quand j'ai commenc√© le jeu, bon allez hop difficult√© la plus dure, histoire de voir ce que √ßa donne.
je fais le tutorial et commence mon premier combat.

D√©ja dans le tuto, il nous est indiqu√© comment lanc√© un sort, le premier sort il m'a fallut 5 essai pour r√©ussir √† presser les 3 pauvres touches au bon moment ... la faute √† un syst√®me qui dit que si tu clic une demi seconde avant ou apr√®s que le symbole passe sur la fleche bah c'est foir√© tu recommence ... 
me suis dit, ok c'est normal je jou en mode de difficult√© la plus dure, normal faut √™tre synchro ...
ce que je ne savais pas, c'est que le mode de difficult√© √©tait d√©sactiv√© et laiss√© sur 0 pendant le tuto.

Donc mon combat commence, difficult√© 4, en quelques seconde je perd 15 points de vie sans rien comprendre, je vais sur le panneau de sortil√®ge pour lancer mon sort, et l√† au lieu d'avoir mes trois touches √† presser ... il y en a facile 20 √† faire avec deux voir trois touches √† presser en m√™me temps √† des intervalles d'une demie seconde chacun ...

...

ok je remet la difficult√© au minimum, OUF √ßa repasse comme dans le tutorial ... 

je poutre un mob puis deux puis trois ... √ßa s'enchaine et l√† je peux plus jouer lol.
parce que si vous d√©passez un certain level, vous pouvez toujours aller dans le jeu, vous pouvez toujours bidouiller votre inventaire ... mais si vous voulez vous battre POUF le jeu plante, invariablement vous emp√™chant de continuer votre partie, bien vue hein ? ;)

alors je ne vous dirai √† quel niveau √ßa plante ... surprise xD

author: {'steamid': '76561198000181548', 'num_games_owned': 1575, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1455, 'last_played': 1358064000}
review: At first, this looks like a simple arrow-rhythm game and some RPG bits with a story thrown in. But then you start playing. The arrow-rhythm game is actually combat against a monster, with 3 screens, your spells (which decide when to trigger) defense (occasional arrows), and mana recovery (pretty much constant arrows). You jump back and forth between these 3 screens, juggling the 3 purposes. The progress of the RPG bits feel solid though not spectacular. But the story is just absolutely amazing. The pacing is perfect, with a few twists and an ending that ties back to the very beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012295667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1390187175}
review:
So I got this game for like 50 cents.  It's marked at 5$, so I'm going to treat it like it's a 5 dollar game.

It's not worth 5 dollars.  Want a decent 5 dollar game?  Check out Knights of Pen and Paper, or when you grow a sack get X-Com UFO Defense.

So why isn't this game good?  I've played tons of rhythm games and this one has 'decent' music, but has no real assemblence of something you could nod your head to and say: yea, this works in a rhythm game.  It simply doesn't and the input is bad.  Now to meet anyone that says: maybe you're just bad at rhythm games, maybe I am, but I the music alone is not motivating and doesn't telegraph much of a downbeat let alone figuring out the count.

The game tries extremely hard to be hip and ironic.  Using references of date rape, crystal meth, and getting stabbed by a hobo in less than 1 minute to get you to say: YEA, THIS IS HIP!

It's a huge grindfest that just wares down compared to other grind games [like Knights of Pen and Paper].  You have to find items by selecting monsters to fight, then craft items from those items found, but you have to spend xp to increase the rate of success.  If you fail, everything you bid is lost and you have to go back to the half-hazardly made ACID-Pro electronic music.

It's 5 dollars, sure, but it's not at all worth that.  

There's so much this game attempts to do that sounds really cool!  [That Bejeweled RPG game series that came out a few years back was actually cool!] This game is not!  It has a lot of things it's trying to do, but all of them are executed poorly.  If anyone can get through this rhythm game and say 'yea this music guides me', then you have an ear I simply do not possess.  The game even says, listen to the music not so much watch the arrows.  If you listen to the music, it will throw you off!  I muted this game and aced every monster I came across.

The music is 'good', but it's not good for rhythm based games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014757855', 'num_games_owned': 1678, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1386305439}
review: Self referential dialogue combined with pretentious text scrolling minutes at a time do not a good combination make.  Thankfully, it's possible to ignore the dumb story to play a great DJ Max clone combined with several RPG elements (I'd compare it to Beatmania, but the game is so simple it'd be a disservice to Beatmania fans).  I just wish there were more songs and less grinding... after playing the same song 10 times on one stage to obtain a rare item, it hurts to have to play it 20 times in another stage for an ever rarer item... ugh!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034513637', 'num_games_owned': 1793, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1543220102}
review:
This game, as an RPG, keeps you on your toes. The crafting system and leveling system is well-balanced, but a lot of grinding is required to be able to match up to later boss fights.
As a rhythm game, it's a tedious, but fun multi-tasking feature. Though it may be confusing at first, it's a blast to play once you get the hang of it.
The soundtrack is well-put together and something to move along to while playing. Also great to put in your music library!

The game, as a whole, is a great experience! Highly recommend this to any RPG and/or rhythm game player!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041833152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1485631581}
review: Gameplay wise it is just hit the correct arrow at the correct moment, nothing new or exciting but the setting makes it worth while. The music is surprisingly good but it is the sense of humour and voice acting throughout the game that make it one of those games that peope end up playing by chance but are so glad they stumbled upon it. I got it free for supporting another game from the developer on kickstarter but I think this one was the real prize.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992796569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1389908676}
review:
This game is a splice of a RPG and a rhythm based game. The gameplay itself is innovative and addictive. However there are two major problems that i personally have. Firstly its a massive grind, in order to get all the items you will have to battle each monster around three times if your lucky. This is about as fun as watching paint dry. Secondly the same songs are repeated a huge amount of times, when this is combined with the first point the game begins to grate on your nerves.
I give this game a positive review though because i enjoy it immensely but it is not without its flaws.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011537005', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 866, 'last_played': 1348642800}
review: This game took me totally by suprise. I bought it for 99p in a sale one time not expecting much - but holy cow, it's one of the most unique games I've played. In a cross between an RPG and keyboard version of DDR, you're a guy who's in a tower of killer monsters with no explanation as to why. The bosses have unique personalities and playing styles which means that as you advance the game never gets too boring. The only problem I might have with the game is it's lack of variety in the music department, but it's only a minor quibble for such a cheap game. Buy it now! It's that good!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001344322', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1663058645}
review: A bizarre, but highly addictive combination of game styles. The dialogue is oddly engaging, and left me wondering what would happen next. Reasonaby priced to boot. Definitely recommended for fans of rhythm games and titles with level-up systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042642481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1578, 'last_played': 1666001397}
review:
This game was that summer fling that you could never forget. I don't know why I bought it and when it was over a piece of me went with it.
Truely one of the few inde games you will apreciate.

Sure I like some fun rythm games every now and then and maybe some games that will challenge me to be a better player, but what keeps me hooked until the end is that storyline. I'm all about the feels and this game's storyline delivers it.

STORY: 10/10
Everything about this game feels like a budget game, but the voice acting and the music and thought put into the story developement drove it home for me. I truely felt like I was experiencing all of the hard work each person put into this game I even took a moment of pause and watched the credits. its that good.

GAMEPLAY: 8/10
Lets be honest, rythm games are very hard to be creative with. You can only do so much to make a person appriciate the music and stay with the beat before it becomes too difficult or too generic.  They did a great job with attempting to give you more than just a beat to hit some buttons with, they gave you enemies to hammer down and spell combos to add a twist to the mix of some pretty good beats. 

At first, juggling through 3 different rythm windows in a battle along with a timer taunting you to the very nano second to hammer out the best moves orElseUlolFail@life can be intimidating, but it actually makes a ton of sense and you feel like youre really battling it out with some baddies while head bobbing to the beat. For what they had to work with, this is something to really try out for yourself.

ART: 8/10
This isnt some blockbuster game that had millions of dollars backing it along with teams of graphic designers, so dont expect amazing CG movie like animations here ladies. The art for each stage is very unique and even melds with the music and the tone of the story. The characters do seem budget like, but by no means are they generic.

REPLAY: 5/10
Sometimes the replay has to justify the price, and this game definately had the opportunity to get some DLCs going of side quests, a battle arena for other players, hell even an after the tower storyline. I really did enjoy the game for what its worth, but after playing the entire thing including the extras in the first run I wished there was something more to comeback to later on.


Conclusion: I know you will pass buy this game as your browsing through the store looking for a quick fix and overlook it. I honestly dont recall what made me buy it in the first place, but I am glad I did and I am pretty sure you will be too. If youre that strapped, its just 5 bucks and you get a lot more bang for your buck from this game than you would for whatever 5 bucks can get you nowadays. Pick up this game and enjoy the adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067442059', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1403565668}
review:
So far it's an awesome game! This game is a pleasent surprise, one of my favorite games I bought during winter sale (though even at full price it would be a good buy).

It's fresh and funny. The concept of a rhythm game mixt with RPG is well executed. The voice acting is great and I Iove the light and humorious dialogues. The more I discover about this game the more I want to keep playing. 

Even if it's a great game, I wouldn't recommend it to people who have difficulties with rhythm (didn't look through all the difficulty levels though). As an exemple, it isn't a game for my brother... but he does enjoy watching me play it. Also, some might find it a bit repetitive, I could understand why but so is every RPG or RPG-like game. 

Personnaly, it doesn't bother me, and it offers an ok variety of good music and intersting small adds to the gameplay along the way to not mind the little repetetiveness. This game has also a great pick up and play feel to it. Sometimes I just don't know what to play, my mouse is far away from me and I look for a game simple (yet more elaborated than a phone game) and enjoyable while browsing my library and Sequence fast became one of those games that I would just pick up, quickly remember where I left off and get back in right away.

If you're ok/good with rhythm and looking for something different then you should absolutly buy it! Keywords: Fresh and Funny ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198003477737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1776, 'last_played': 1523107466}
review:
The true entertainment for this game comes from first the challenge of managing to actually beat anything, then listening to the hilarious dialogue. 

It's RPG element is kinda cool, but there ARE a very few points in the game where it feels like you're just grinding enemies to get powerful enough. The final bosses are particularly difficult; I got to them around level 30 and had to go get about 5-6 levels before I could even consider beating them.

If you really enjoy Rythmn games, the 'combat' is especially fulfilling if you pull off a successful cast while stopping all damage.
If you don't particularly enjoy Rythmn games, the dialogue may still even be worth the money to buy this game; it is HILARIOUS. They've taken every chance they've got to make a joke, while still maintaining a somewhat serious tone for the main story, which is actually pretty cool unto itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997130551', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1388391920}

author: {'steamid': '76561198022973811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1325577600}
review:
Brilliant mix of RPG and... rhythm game?!

Dance Dance Revolution style games have always seemed a little dodgy on a control pad, but Sequence amps up the difficulty by introducing three separate fields -- defense (missed notes hurt you), spells (getting all notes in a spell casts it) and mana (a constant stream; each note hit gives +2 mana).

Monsters drop various items, which can be crafted into new spells, weapons, armour, accessories, and the key required to face that floor's miniboss. My biggest issue with the game, as it happens, is that the various random events -- random drops, percentage to succeed/fail at crafting -- can be frustrating when luck is not on your side. You might find yourself fighting the same monster a dozen times before getting a key item supposedly dropped in 42% of battles.

But the art is good and the writing is great, even if the story does fizzle out somewhat as it becomes more serious. The item descriptions are especially fun; with very few exceptions they are awful, awful puns. (An example off the top of my head is the Lightwave Sword: "Also Lightparticle Sword." The description for Polish Remover is "Hitler".)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025515797', 'num_games_owned': 1129, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1381466391}
review: needs to work with a touch screen

author: {'steamid': '76561198052876380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1429839358}
review: This game is great.  Ronald Jenkees throws down his awesome tracks for the background music, what else need be said?  A fun twist on RPG playing, but probably one of the first in a long line of RPGing and exercising (if you actually use a dance pad).  I just played using a laptop and it was still great.  Fun animations, and very exciting once you get into the flow of battle/music.  Jamming out while ass-kicking, what could go wrong?  Only downsides I see are there only being a limited amount of monsters to fight.  Also, the constant streaming of arrows against the backgrounds can leave you dizzy, at least I get dizzy from time to time.  Don't know if this is one I could play through in one sitting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081963672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1370907929}
review: Great rhythm game, with pretty good rpg elements and funny dialogue.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997724945', 'num_games_owned': 4611, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1388010410}
review: I always heard great things about Sequence, how it mixed elements from your typical RPG with rhythm game mechanics in a very unique way. I don‚Äôt know why I didn‚Äôt picked it up earlier, probably because I wasn‚Äôt sure if I‚Äôd actually like it but truth is I bought Sequence on the Steam Autumn Sale of 2013. Well, it turns out rumours were right and my suspicions were correct. The game is great, it possibly has one of the best soundtracks I‚Äôve ever heard on an indie game and the arstyle looks absolutely beautiful with some nice visual effects. The combat relies on a typical rhythm match game, where you have to press each key at the right time and it‚Äôs probably better if you don‚Äôt try to press the keys when you see them on the right spot but when they coincide with the music ‚Äúbeat‚Äù. The combat screen is divided in three different fields, the Mana field which everytime you match a certain key you regain mana and mana is used to cast spells, the Spell field where you need to match keys everytime you activate one spell and if you miss one key of the combo the spell casting cancels and you still loose your mana and the last field is the Defense field in which everytime you miss one of the keys on this field, that key will deal damage to you. That is about it for the combat, everytime you beat an enemy you‚Äôll gain experience and loot, each enemy can drop three different items and those items are either equipables or crafting materials. The story takes you to a tower where you‚Äôre guided by a girl named Naia via an intercom and she explains to you how everything works and that you need to reach the top of the tower which has 7 floors and in order to proceed to the next floor you need to find the required materials to craft the key to unlock the door for the next floor and also defeat the guardian of each floor at the start of it, from what I understand these battles with the guardians are considered boss battles. On each floor you have a safe room where you can equip yourself, craft new items and spells and also learn and practice your spells and also this is where you‚Äôll unlock the door leading to the next floor and where you can choose to battle enemies, from what I saw there‚Äôs three different enemies per floor.  I‚Äôm gonna be honest and you can probably see by my playtime according to Steam, I only reach the second floor and I‚Äôm currently fighting the second guardian but I‚Äôm pretty sure II won‚Äôt play Sequence anymore, not because I don‚Äôt like it, because I really do, but because I‚Äôm extremely bad at rhythm games and I found the battles to be rather frustrating for me, which might end up with me taking alot of time in order to beat the game and that kinda makes me sad because I‚Äôd love to experience the whole story and unfold the mystery behind Sequence and its world, from what I‚Äôve saw thus far the story seemed to promise but I disliked the voice acting in this game but I do believe you can turn it off on the options menu if you don‚Äôt like it either. Sequence is certainly a very unique game and a very good one indeed, but like I‚Äôve said, if you‚Äôre not good at rhythm games you‚Äôll have a hard time with it, eitherways you should totally give it a try, it is totally worth your time and money but unfortunately it‚Äôs not my kind of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117255804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1387917074}
review:
You wake up in a room with no recollection of how you got there. The last thing you know you were getting ready for bed and now you're here. A girl over the intercom tell you you're in a tower with seven floors and that you have to get to the top to get out. That's it. Oh, and by the way, you have to fight monsters and floor guardians in rhythmic RPG-ish-style battles. Are you confused yet? I was.

This game features four difficulty modes and I have to admit I played this on the easiest setting, which for a rhythmically challenged person such as myself was hard enough on the last couple of boss fights. You are free to change the difficulty around in the beginning, though, since you can switch up until the third floor. 

The gameplay consists of fighting monsters by switching around three different 'fields'. There's a defensive, mana, and offensive field where you need to correctly push up, down, left, right according to the sequence they come down in. The trick is in juggling these three fields, since you're not able to play them all at the same time. When notes (I'll just call them that) come down in the defensive field and you miss them, you gain damage. To damage the opponent, you need to cast spells and hit the right notes in the spell or offensive field. To regain the mana you spent by casting spells, you need to go to the mana field where hitting the notes restores mana. There are quite a couple of spells in this game, ranging from healing spells to direct offensive spells to damage over time. At first it can be a bit confusing, but it does get easier over time. I personally played this game with a controller and often found myself pressing the wrong buttons when in a rush to reach the right field, causing me to miss notes. For me, the controls as such were something to get used to, but maybe it's easier when playing with a keyboard. 

After each battle you gain a certain amount of XP and there's the possibility of getting items. While XP is used to level Ky, the protagonist, up, it is also used as a currency. On every floor you are given a couple a recipes you can use to synthesize items, gear, and spells. In order to do so, you need to invest some XP into the synthesizing process, a little more if you want a better change of success or a little less if you want like gambling. Spells can be learned by synthesizing scrolls and then 'using' the scrolls - again, with XP. You then need to finish one of the songs with a certain percentage of correct notes or a certain combo streak. The spells learned can then be put into your ring of spells, which starts out with two slots but increases to six as you progress in the game. 

 Now, the music. The music was the high point of the game for me, as most of the tunes were catchy and didn't really annoy even after a reasonable amount of time spent playing. Outside of the battles I cannot recall any kind background music, though I'm sure it was there. Just not memorable. The sound effects were all right, nothing much to say there. The voice acting on the other hand I really liked. I think the characters sounded real enough, though the script was a bit of a hit or miss at times: I think the topics of conversation and references made might not be everybody's cup of tea.

And last but not least, the story itself. So you start out with only knowing you need to get to the top of this tower with seven floors and that your shepherd, Naia, will guide you through via intercom. I won't spoil the story, but you won't find out much more than that until the end of the game. The ending itself, while explaining everything, felt a bit disappointing to me. If this game had relied on the story for its success, instead of the gameplay and banter among the characters, I don't think it would have worked out. 

All that said, I do recommend this game if only for the fact that it's so cheap and quite a lot of fun. It's not a very long game, it took me a small ten hours to complete from A to Z, but the fun to cost relation definitely says that if you're thinking of getting this game you should give it the benefit of the doubt.

It is a fun enough rythm game, however there are aspects of a free 2 play game in there like the crafting that fails taking your XP with it that are really just in there to extend the otherwise fairly basic game play.

review: Sequence isn't perfect.  The story feels a little campy at times and the last 2 hours of the game are spent needlessly slogging back through old content.   That aside it's probably the most interesting thing to happen to the "Rythm and Action" genre since Dance Dance Revolution.  I mean that in the best way possibe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000481941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1387596341}
review:
Sequence is a great little rhythm game. The primary gameplay consists of you switching between 3 DDR-like boards during battles with monsters and opponents. One for defending against their attacks, one for gaining mana, and one for casting your own spells. The system works really well and each battle is set to some outstanding music (including a number of tracks by Ronald Jenkees). 

There are some RPG elements including a levelling system, crafting different weapons, armor, accessories from monster drops, and the ability to customize your usable spells. All of this is tied together with a decent plot and some cringe-worthy voice acting, but it's not enough to detract from the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056708842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1481183904}

author: {'steamid': '76561198039619971', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1359, 'last_played': 1450496746}
review:
Edit: Changed name from "Sequence" to "Before the Echo".  It was, at one point, called Sequence.


Before the Echo is a simple, yet fun rhythm game.

The plot isn't the greatest selling point of the game, but if you approach it as a riff off the Guitar Hero or Rock Band style game it is very enjoyable.  The music can start to feel a little repetitive at times, but the songs are enjoyable if you like the style.  Ronald Jenkees did the vast majority of the songs in the game, and many are available on his youtube channel for some samples.  

Your goal is to reach the top of a tower, while combating monsters with spells that you cast in a DDR style mechanic.  To complicate things, there are three "areas" that you have to swap between and work in- one for casting, one for regenerating mana, and one for defending yourself.  Winning a battle nets you some XP, and possibly up to 3 items.  The item drops and crafting mechanics seem designed to extend the length of the game, although I rarely felt like I was grinding unnecessarily.  There is something to be said for the practice associated with grinding drops and XP to burn on crafting, as the transitions in difficulty can feel a little rough here and there, and some of the spell casting sequences can take a bit of time to really feel natural.

The mechanics do feel contrived, but the game itself lampshades that fact.  Before the Echo doesn't take itself too seriously, and that is a good deal of the charm.  The music is great, and the art has a nice look and feel to it. 

 I have not tried playing with a controller, but the keyboard interface is simple enough to use that I don't think a controller is a requirement.  I was able to finish the game (including the "hidden" ending) on Medium difficulty without too much of a struggle.  I briefly toyed with the harder difficulty but I found that I enjoyed the game on medium enough that I didn't continue down the harder path.  The differences in difficulty seem to be entirely based on the number of symbols necessary to complete a sequence, and higher difficulties make more use of the two buttons at a time patterns (up+left, down+right, up+down, left+right) instead of just single inputs in order.

Overall, I think it was a fun game, worth a playthrough, and something I go back to from time to time just to play specific songs.  Worth the price of admission.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040883231', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1638412284}
review: I was excited to find a "puzzle quest, but as a rhythm game instead of bejewled" game.  I was blown away at the humor the game had, and the strong story (fans of the puzzle quest series know that it's a bit lacking there).  The items had joke descriptions, the enemies were humorous, the interaction between characters was fun.  I loved the boss enemies as well.  I thought the story was fun, and the twists surprising, but not out of left field.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989596025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1386481585}
review: I found this to be a great little game that blends music rhythm and RPG elements to create something rare and interesting. The story isn't made with a whole lot of depth, but it is unique and enjoyable. I love most of the songs so much that I want to obtain them separate of the game - but within the game, I find myself feeling soothed and relaxed by the sounds while at the same time my heart pounds as I "fight for my life" in keeping with the rhythm. Although I have completed the game, I can see myself returning to it just to have those normally-conflicting feelings every once in awhile...and because of that, this is one of the best indie games I have ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031276680', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1656989231}
review: A hidden gem in the rhythm game genre, Sequence combines DDR and RPG style battles to form a game completely addicting and worth coming back to. The story draws you in, and the artstyle of this game certainly helps in keeping things look fresh and interesting. There's also some better good humor between the characters which at parts can be silly, but not really be enough to make you feel like none of the characters cares about whats going on. However, the game suffers from some problems such as a rather small song catalog and the occasional grind, but it isn't enough to ruin the entire experience. Another thing to note is that this game is designed for controllers, while you can play with a keyboard, and I haven't had many problems doing so. If you're into this kind of stuff, buy this game as soon as you can, it's a one of a kind experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980793519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1403321282}
review:
Mix DDR and classic dungeon grinding RPGs and you get something that might resemble Sequence.  It's an excellent game with a really creative core and solid execution.  Full voice acting really helps to make the game feel more fully developed then the JRPG style 2D pictures would otherwise make you feel.  

Music is excellent and really well made, however grinding for levels and items does mean you'll hear the same songs over and over again.  In the end, I think it was a valiant effort but I can definitely see how some people would tire from the inevitable grinding necessary to progress.

If you do give it a try, make sure you have a controller (or preferably a dance mat,) as the game is clearly designed with a controller in mind.

Overall probably worth the price, but definitely not for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035059626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1472696050}
review:
Sequence is a rhythm RPG, which is, in and of itself, an interesting concept. It delivers this with surprisingly unique gameplay, an interesting story, and an excellent, albeit limited, selection of music to play along to.

In terms of gameplay, it's not unlike DDR in that you have four arrows that you have to hit to the rhythm as they reach the bottom of the screen while music plays in the background. However, the similarities stop there. Combat involves rotating between three screens: your damage screen, your mana screen, and your spell screen. The damage screen represents incoming attacks from your opponent, and each arrow missed on this screen will result in your health taking a hit. The spell screen is used for all of the abilities in the game, where you must select what type of spell you want to perform and then hit every arrow in that spell for it to succeed. The mana screen grants mana, for casting spells, with every arrow that is hit. As a result, the game turns into a very interesting experience where you have to time spells so that you don't take too much damage, and prioritize each of these screens so that you can keep yourself alive and deplete your enemy's health bar before the song ends.

When a battle concludes, loot is dropped. This loot can be used to craft specific items on each floor, such as new weapons and equipment, a key to get to the next level, and a few other secrets that are best observed within the game. Especially towards the end, there are some very interesting items that can be crafted, and a lot of secrets and hidden content. I highly recommend crafting every item in the game, waiting until after the credits, and then exploring a bit more based on what you learn. This game quickly becomes intriguing, and knows how to deliver on it.

One point of criticism I have for this game is that, if you're looking to craft all of the items in the game, it can get a little repetitive. Each enemy has the same song every time you fight them, and when you get close to the end, there are a few items that have pretty low drop rates. Having to repeat the same fight fifteen times in a row, as a result, can get a drab. Luckily, it's not the exact same pattern of arrows every time, and the gameplay is engaging and fun enough that I didn't find this to be much of an issue, but it is something worth mentioning.

If you're a fan of rhythm games, Sequence brings a twist on a traditional formula that makes it feel almost entirely new. I'm glad I put in all of the time that I did, and I think a lot of people would be surprised at how much they enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005026628', 'num_games_owned': 469, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1386519527}
review:
This game is basically DDR (on a controller/keyboard) mashed up with an RPG. If that sounds like heaven to you, then you're in for a good time. You battle monsters by completing sequences of notes, swapping between three different 'tracks' to attack, block, and charge up mana. 

The only major problem with this game is that it is *extremely* grind-y. To move past each level, you will need to craft a key, which requires collecting multiple items dropped from the monsters in that level. The monsters will only drop the items some of the time, and multiple items are usually required so you might end up fighting the same monster (and playing the same song) several times in a row. To make matters worse, crafting the items you need costs XP (meaning more battles to earn it back) and has a chance of failing (meaning even more battles to find all those items again). Playing the same song over and over again gets old very quickly.

Overall, this is a good game for rhythm game fans, but be warned that it can get repetitive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044948619', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1434679358}
review: I don't normally go for rythm games, but Sequence is beautful; I like its rpg elements, the story's decent, it's a lot more strategic than I thought it would be, and the music is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970286203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1385654650}
review:
Do you like rhythm games? cool, this is a rhythm game.

Do you like games where you can craft stuff? cool, you can craft some stuff in this game.

Do you like games with irritating bad voice acting? cool, this game has irritating bad voice acting.

Do you like games with Extremely Hip, Self-Aware, Fourth Wall Shattering Dialogue? cool, this game has that.

Do you like games where "easy" difficulty is geared towards the severely handicapped, "normal" difficulty is geared towards not-handicapped-enough-for-disability-but-still-awfully-damn-stupid-and/or-intoxicated, and "hard" difficulty is geared towards professional keyboard-DDR fanatics hopped up on energy drinks and I'm not even sure exactly who "extreme" difficulty is targeted towards but pretty confident they're probably not entirely human? Well then f¬≠uck almighty are you ever in for a treat here because that's exactly what this game is and exactly why I'm probably never going to bother with it again now that I've gotten the trading cards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001049803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1325059200}
review: I didn't find the game's humor funny at all. It's that standard Japanimation crap with an overly wanna-be-cool kid and the snotty overly smart/arrogant girl mocking him. I don't bond with either. The game itself I found confusing, whipping around between multiple simultaneously concurrent games like a mix of tetric and bubble bop. Bleah.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005647659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1027, 'last_played': 1693528042}
review: A fantastic game in which all of the mechanics have been honed to perfection. The DDR Max-RPG hybrid system works flawlessly, the voice acting is top notch, and the dialogue is great. Little touches such as being able to spend experience points to increase synthesis success, having a practice mode to work on your timing, and more are all done well. The hand painted enviornments look gorgeous, and the character and enemy designs are great, although a couple of the later enemies are palette swaps of the early ones. The soundtrack is great, with several catchy songs you'll find yourself humming in the shower later. Unfortunately, the number of tracks is rather limited, and each enemy is assigned only one song, but the songs are still good enough that they don't get annoying. The only flaw I can find is that there is no free play mode, as at this point I have reached such a high level that even the hardest battles only take around thirty seconds to win. Still, its hard to fault a game for not letting you replay it enough, so I'll conclude by saying that this is the single best indie title I have had the pleasure of playing on Steam. A fantastic game that should be enjoyed by all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969574352', 'num_games_owned': 666, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1385651669}
review:
Before the Echo (the game was known as Sequence previously) is an interesting RPG. The game plays like Dance Dance Revolution with the notes divided into 3 separate note tracks running concurrently on the screen for casting spells, defending against attacks and regenerating mana. There is a quirky story to pull you through to the end but what won me over was most definitely the music tracks behind the gameplay.

I can't really gauge how difficult it is to play for beginners to the genre due to my many years of playing rhythm games from Stepmania, Guitar Hero and my current timesink of Osu!. Anyone who has played such games should find no problems however with adapting to the mechanics.

Due to the RPG nature of the game, it can become a grind for specific items to drop on the monsters which are used to craft items needed to progress in the floors. The game does not come with any additional content beyond the story that I am aware of (I played mostly at release back in 2011).

Before the Echo wasn't the most challenging game personally but it sits in my game library as a comfortable purchase when I look back over two years. Give it a go if it is on sale but just be aware it may not be fun for everyone; the usual disclaimer case for most games in the rhythm genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008663743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1376317417}
review:
As a RPG and Stepmania enthousiast, this would seem like the perfect Indie game for me. And indeed, it was fun to play. It was unique. It was something fresh. And being a RPG fan, I am used with doing repetitive things in order to get that one rare drop.

One warning is that even casual gamers who would like to simply play the game and go through the story, might still face some moments where they have to engage battles over and over to get that last item for a recipe. Bite through it, the way you make story progression is quite slow in itself. Ronald Jenkees kicks ass, but not after the 6~7th time in a row. Yeah, having only one fixed song per enemy doesn't get you on your toes that much. 

On sales it's usually just one buck, so hopefully no buyer's remorse after you've even spent an hour at it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996737918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1379, 'last_played': 1385580539}
review:
I HATE rhythm games. They're tailored to those with ludicrous skills and timing and don't ever quite grasp the concept of balance very well.

I don't hate Sequence because it at least tries to be a bit more generous while still failing to grasp an equitable balance of difficulty. I found most of the experience enjoyable because it's an RPG and it uses interesting mechanics so despite my implied ineptitude, I could apply strategy and grinding to bypass obstacles. It has great audio composition (being a rhythm game, I'd expect no less) and an interesting story. It alludes to a sequel that has yet to come at the time of this writing and the game's been out for some time, but I would probably enjoy it too.

I played the game on the medium difficulty and found it challenging, but fun. That broke down when trying to learn the last spell where the difficulty suddenly went to extremes. Because there's an achievement dependent upon successful acquisition of this spell, I found it necessary to replay the entire game on the easy difficulty and still found myself frustrated by the difficulty leap at the same point. Even when I reached the target I was given, it still would not give me the spell because (while not indicated at all) I had to exceed the target. If you want to complete the whole thing, play on easy. If you don't mind missing the achievement and finishing everything else, play on medium. If you hate yourself and your life, there are two even harder difficulties. Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197967659504', 'num_games_owned': 1229, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1384306147}
review: A truly great and engrossing indie game.  The music is good. I wish there were a few more songs, they start to get a little repetitive as you near the end of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987497191', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 929, 'last_played': 1558811443}
review:
This game is regular rhythm game with small extra gimmicks but little content.

In this game, like in other rhythm games, you press different keys (in this case arrow keys) in the rhythm of music. The extra gimmick of this game is that you simultaneously fight against monster and there are different rhytm lines for Mana, Attack and Defence. See some videos about this, if you want to know more as I am not going to explain this further in this review. 

This little gimmick is not bad, but it isn't revolutionary either. In the end the game is extremely bland and for a person like me who isn't fan of this kind of genre, the game was waste of time excluding funny conversations that the characters make in the story that gave some delight. What makes me not to recommend this game is that it is very repetitive. There is only a few of songs and the gimmick that this game has is seen very quickly.


Grade: 5/10

I would only recommend this to a person who is fan of this genre and who has tried all other variations of this kind of games.

Last edit was to change Grade from 4 to 5 to be more in line with my other reviews.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028179042', 'num_games_owned': 5917, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1384725426}

author: {'steamid': '76561198089587298', 'num_games_owned': 170, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1385524485}
review: I can not begin to show how awesome this game is. Its like an RPG but with arrows so its a rythem game. It is mashed up so perfectly and the music is great. Definaty worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012079860', 'num_games_owned': 1864, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1385320244}
review:
Dance Dance Revolution meets an RPG. And as weird as it sounds, it's actually quite clever and really well thought out. The story is unique and interesting, full of funny dialogues and several thought provoking moments. The gameplay is solid, mixing a rhythm game with RPG mechanics and featuring some nice music tracks. The only downside is that the game's a bit too grindy, mostly due to random item drops. It may also take some time to get used to the controls.

Nevertheless, Sequence is definitely worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038561959', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1191, 'last_played': 1393555839}
review: Hilarious puns, very original concept. It is an RPG? Is it a dance-game? I just wish we had access to the soundtrack. Ohterwise, it's a near-perfect game for it's genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999132422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1327651200}
review: Not much content with a huge amount of repetition. Random dice rolls to determine whether you get to advance after beating a level are a massive waste of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042118407', 'num_games_owned': 6189, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1384454471}
review: Kind of a nice rhythm-rpg hybrid. Doesn't work quite as well as some of the better puzzle-rpg hybrids. A bit too busy at times in the battles, due to the shifting focus. Suffers for me from not being able to alter the difficulty by song. Some are very much tougher than others to do well during, and I just found myself turning down the difficulty instead of working to improve my coordination like I would with Rock Band/Guitar Hero. The sound track is mercifully quite nice to listen to, including a few real gems. The game needs some work to be really good, but I look forward to a potential sequel. 3/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198002601500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1087, 'last_played': 1326787200}
review: Its a fun game from what I remember. Despite what limitations it has it still has a worthwhile story

author: {'steamid': '76561198058818855', 'num_games_owned': 637, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 811, 'last_played': 1404547685}
review: I bought this game because I happened upon a fifty percent off cupon for it and figured why not just give it a shot. So far Sequence has exceeded my expectations on many levels. Despite being a DDR-like game that is fun and addicting in it self. With all of the spell pickng and the mana pools. It also has a very compelling story that makes me want to keep playing it even  when it's been 2 hours. On top of that the music is phanominal I only wish there were more songs. I highly reccamend that you play with a controller rather than a keyboard. While it is playable on a keyboard I can get tricky when selecting spells. All in all for a game I just picked up on a whim Sequence has been one of my best investments on steam thus far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034151680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1385110869}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993984598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1364626800}
review: This is a DDR RPG. Yeah, odd. It pulls it off pretty well, actually, though DDR games live or die on the quality of their music. The music has a bit of variety, but it's mainly electro-techno-kind-of-stuff. A couple of piano tracks if I recall correctly, but you'll be spending a fair bit of time grinding XP on the same songs, which isn't great, but it doesn't really outstay its welcome. Original and fun, all up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045248630', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1807, 'last_played': 1592658379}
review:
Sequence is "an one of a kind" game. In its core it is a rhythmus game mixed with some light rpg elements. You get experience, levels and items which make you stronger and you can craft some items and you fight monsters.
The dialogues may appear childish to some people (not to me) and the story is probably told in three or four sentences. But for me it was interesting enough and left me with a lot of unanswered questions which made me curious for a sequel.
While fighting monsters you have three "rhythmus screens" you can switch freely between: the mana screen (only for regeneration of mana), the defend screen (block attacks to avoid damage) and the spell screen (match the combination to attack with your spells). Watch a gameplay video to get a better impression.
As a sidenote you can not choose the music for the game. It is preset and there are "only" between 10-15 playable songs. Personally I found them quite enjoyable . Also you need to grind a tiny bit during the game in order to gain experiences and the right items. If those minor things are no problem for you I can only recommand this game to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042097905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 538, 'last_played': 1450473417}

review:
Un jeu musical vachement sympa, √† jouer au clavier en poulpe, ou au pad pour les gens normaux.
Y'a petit aspect JRPG sympa (on gagne des niveaux, on s'equipe, on decouvre des nouveaux pouvoirs). 

Le seul point noir, c'est le grind necessaire si on veut se faciliter les passages √† haut niveau. En gros, soit on joue HARDCORE et le jeu est dur mais un peu court, soit on joue HARDCORE et on grind les top skills pour pouvoir avancer.

review: A pretty damn awesome rhythm game that sells dirt cheap. The music alone is easily worth the retail price and if you like a bit of RPG sensibilities with your music gaming that has an actual storyline... get it now!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040573839', 'num_games_owned': 2228, 'num_reviews': 298, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1384355590}
review: A lot better than I expected! Combines a rhythm game with some RPG elements. It can be a little grindy trying to get randomized drops from enemies but I found it interesting enough to keep going.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998763476', 'num_games_owned': 642, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 492, 'last_played': 1488167840}
review: The best non-'pretend you're playing an instrument' rhythm game out there. It's really an RPG that uses a music based battle system.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985512939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1388520422}
review:
Sequence lives at the intersection of rhythm and decision making.  The combat is harsh but enjoyabile while the ways in which you craft your abilities and purchase items harkens to picking attacks in an RPG.  Finding the right mix can make you unstoppable but only if you execute those attacks in the rhythm challenge as well.

The major complaint is the speed at which the songs get stale.  This game could've had tons of replayability had I not gotten sick of the songs halfway through the game.  It's possible to push through that failure for the story, but it's a major low point of this title (despite the small selection being rather good).

author: {'steamid': '76561198052719588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1426986673}
review: Absorbing - this game does not have a lot of hours in it storyline-wise once you grasp the mechanic, but it's good fun, the story is interestin and it's something a little different. Would definitely recommend anyone who enjoys rythum games and old-style RPGs to give this little belter a go!

author: {'steamid': '76561198019070582', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3567, 'last_played': 1693611962}
review:
Shortly said: AWESOME GAME!
Fun rythm game, with a compelling story and AMAZING dialouge, that really keeps you wanting to play. I've played through this game multiple times, as you can continue to play it at higher difficulties.


Pro's:
Fun,
Unique and well done combat system,
Traditional but still unique rpg elements,
Good plot,
Amazing dialouge,
Unique and very diverse artistic animation and setting,
GREAT character development.

Con's:
Slightly grindy at 1 or 2 spots, but not enough to notice it much.


I would HIGHLY recommend it, and rate it:
10/10

Deserves to be more known.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002424451', 'num_games_owned': 2298, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1385745534}
review: A-M-A-Z-I-N-G

author: {'steamid': '76561197995314039', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 994, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1605823832}
review:
When I first stumbled across Sequence, I was poking through games I had coupons for. I was a little hesitant at first to pay even the 90% off price because the trailer on the store page made the game sound rather complicated, and I wasn't sure how the gameplay would hold up.

However, I wound up caving and figured I'd buy it for the heck of it, and I'm really glad I did. Sequence is an excellent, solid game if you can play through everything. The soundtrack is wonderful, the game's artwork is spectacular, and the writing is witty and interesting which makes for a fun playthrough. 

I've been actively trying to get my friends into playing because I wanted to share how wonderful this game really is. I'm commonly asked what it's like, which I'd have to say is really similar to Dance Dance Revolution, but played with the keyboard's arrow keys. It's definitely easier once you know the songs and beats, because you have to match hitting the falling arrows in time with the music, essentially.

Overall, I can't recommend this game enough. Sequence is a very excellent game.

review: A rhythm rpg? In the weirdest mashup since Puzzle Quest, this brilliant little indie game manages to create a unique niche and thrive in it. The writing turns some people off but I enjoyed it and found it relatable. Maybe that says more about me than the game itself. It definitely gets grindy, but the mechanics are very unique. Can frequently be purchased super cheap. Give it a shot, you'll probably be surprised.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966287779', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1403881490}
review: An interesting premise - a rhythm game combined with an RPG - but it ends up being really grindy. Which is strange. And annoying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023450647', 'num_games_owned': 709, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1480952064}
review:
This game uses the fantastic background art and fantastic music to create a fun and calming feel.
But dont get fooled for the game is quite hard for unexperienced players.
It mixes Dance Dance Revolution/Stepmania gameplay mixed with magic battle.
Wich takes you on a funny and very interesting adventure trough a mysterious tower towards freedom

The music is one of the best features about this game, featuring the brilliance of Ronald Jenkees. I will definitely be looking out for Iridium's further titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007901518', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1391741225}
review: Sequence is an interesting game... Amazingly, it is a DDR RPG (Dance Dance Revolution Role Playing Game) which, first thinking of, seems like a bad mixture. But this game pulled it together and perfected it in its glory. If you love Music, A good story, Quirky Jokes / Puns, The challenge, and RPG, THIS GAME IS FOR YOU. If you fall into any of those catagories above (Which is very likely,) Then please try it...

author: {'steamid': '76561198007124518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1325059200}
review: Really great DDR style game for anyone who thinks they're good at multi-tasking.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960602550', 'num_games_owned': 1424, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1498772842}
review: Funky music, nice independent game

author: {'steamid': '76561198024985000', 'num_games_owned': 1910, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1371401342}
review:
Interesting dialogue, really nice art, and an absolutely killer soundtrack full of Ronald Jenkees make this a good pick for fans of music games.  The DDR-inspired gameplay is a lot deeper and more engaging than it looks at first glance, and the difficulty options mean anyone can enjoy the experience.

Recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046029197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1233, 'last_played': 1388409895}
review:
Nothing about this game could really make me not recommend it. Upbeat, yet oddly fitting battle music. It's art style was clearly done with great care and interest, and the story builds up to the point that once I had done everything, left me completely satisfied with my purchase.

And I believe I got this game for less then two dollars. Utterly fantastic in my honest opinion, and unless you just flat out don't like any kind of rhythm/musical games, I would recommend it whole heartedly.

I spent about eighteen hours to do everything, and my only complaint is that I wish I could have more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030106749', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1388762662}
review: I generally don't like rythm games at all but "Before the Echo" really got to me. The RPG elements set the game apart from others of this genre and it has genuinely good characters, writing and voice acting despite being an indie game. I sometimes found myself tired of grinding for items to progress to the next level but the story really carried the game, pushed me to keep playing and it payed off in the end. If you don't flat out hate rythm games and if you can appreciate a good and original story, you should give this one a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983367876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1527, 'last_played': 1390317942}
review: Honestly, this is a fantastic game. Buy it, on sale or otherwise. It's a unique concept, excellently excecuted. Throw in catchy music, quality voiceacting seldom seen in even big-name titles, and a well-written story with relateable characters, and you've got what might be one of my favorite games of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020213340', 'num_games_owned': 1522, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 1079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 998, 'last_played': 1384699885}
review:
Are you into DDR? Do you like RPGs?
If you answered "yes" to both questions, then this game is for you.
Put the DDR gameplay and RPG battles into blender and turn it on. After blending add 75mg of a pretentious plot. The result will be this game.
It's a lot more fun than it sounds and it's worth every penny you spend on it.
Just buy it already.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994195296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1584720455}
review:
This game has a charming storyline, referencing memes and elements of popular culture that should endear the average media-savvy player. However, it's main draw is its unique (as far as I know) music-based combat system.

Find any youtube video of Sequence gameplay, TotalBiscuit for one. While you're watching, try to play along. Get in time with the beat and mime hitting the keys with your fingers. If you're liking the feel of it, buy this game. This feeling is enhanced once you have more agency in the game itself. if you've enjoyed any kind of rhythm game (Guitar Hero and etc.) and wanted to feel more like a badass while doing so, buy this game.

Imagine what it must be like to jam along with electronic rock/techno, and then to pluck those tunes out of the air and convert them into raw magical power, which you then convert into a righteous fireball. For a small sum, you too can feel this power. 

I am a Music Magus; hear me groove.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993730393', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1402844481}
review: Picked up in a sale at some point but never played. Actually a nice adventure game with a rhythm game for combat. Fun story, some good music and quite addictive at some points. However having now been through it once I doubt I'd ever want to go back to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025330902', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 935, 'last_played': 1373132440}
review: Clever mixture of rhythm and RPG. DDR-esque gameplay and a humourous, meta story sure to delight gamers. Offers a good challenge and opportunity for flow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007823333', 'num_games_owned': 568, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1507877831}
review: An intriguing little indie fusion experiment that serves as a tailored engine to get songs stuck in your head. Features an end moral that makes no sense either to the player or the characters in the game. Worth three bucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991441485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1618537098}
review: A neat music game with a focus on plot... weird I know. The writing is awful but the story ain't bad and the game itself + music is really great. Bought it for $1.99

author: {'steamid': '76561197977743756', 'num_games_owned': 2007, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1676432647}

author: {'steamid': '76561197979953970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 489, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1386252281}
review:
