author: {'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4498, 'num_reviews': 1009, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1384377567}
review:
Played this for a little more than 30 minutes and it's not what I expected. I expected an RPG with rhythm based combat, like it actually advertises. But it falls short on every level, except for the music. The music is actually something that I enjoyed listening to. The graphics are very basic; the art looks ok, but there are basically no animations. It feels very empty and simple. I'll admit I can't expect a 'retail quality' game for this price, it's true. But still, if you build expectations you better deliver.
The combat is a nice idea, but poorly executed. You pick an enemy from a list (I know, right?) and then fight it by pressing buttons on the beat of the music. It's nothing fancy, and about everything is text based, items included. 
You explore the tower by picking levels from a list as well. Wait, what?
There's just no style; it doesn't stand out. There are some cool ideas in it, but like I said, it's really, really poorly executed.
Sorry guys, it's not worth the money.

[Rating: 69/100]

author: {'steamid': '76561197993263732', 'num_games_owned': 1045, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1030, 'last_played': 1391928375}
review:
OMG *Frothing at the Mouth*

Ok. So this game is like... It's like 3 DDR matches going on at once. You have to beat one to stay alive, and another to kill the opponent. It's all about prioritizing, while still keeping up the rhythm.

It's got writing that's actually funny (like Recettear), and it's fully voice acted. I didn't think I would care at first, but the voices make the writing pop even better. It's definitely aimed at our age group, but not in the sense that it's corny like Saved by the Bell, but more like someone our age actually worked on it.

Also, it has Ronald Jenkees in it. I found that enough to be worth the $5 alone.

If you like DDR/Guitar Hero, and also like Chantelise, Recettear, or Gyromancer (basically anything that follows the simple 3 stat RPG formula. Maybe even FF3) then you should really like this game.

Also, I played it on hard mode and I'm now realizing that I really have no rhythm what so ever. Hard mode is actually hard!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991892563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1325059200}
review: This is slick and polished, especially for $5, but the RPG mechanics aren't enough to make me actually enjoy a rhythm game. Also, it turns out Ronald Jenkees music isn't nearly as much fun to listen to without being able to see Jenkees play it and say "Hello Youtubes!" In short, get this if you give half a damn about rhythm games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998844556', 'num_games_owned': 1579, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 841, 'last_played': 1333090800}

Pour ce prix, c'est donn√©, essayez-le ! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198010396848', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1569803267}
review: Impulse buy after seeing the screens and noting it was a rhythm game RPG. Equip gear and spells and pretty much play DDR across 3 panels. One is a mana panel which will replenish your mana pool for every correct "note" you hit. One is a Defense panel where when your monster attacks notes will popup and for every miss you start loosing hp. In your attack panel notes will appear depending on what spell you cast. Some will deal damage some will heal you and others will cast buff/debuff on the playing fields. The difficulty will change appropriately at least for people who have played the konami music games. A little tricky getting used to panel swapping but all in all a pretty interesting and well done rhythm music game.
